650mL bottle poured a deep ruby brown color with big off-white head with nice retention settling slowly to some nice lacing.  Aroma of roasted malts, wood and smoke.  Taste is roasted malty sweetness with just a hint of smoke and a bit of hops in the finish.  A nicely balanced porter with a nice mouthfeel.  Good job, Alaska.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2013 Rating is for the 2000 vintage.  Sampled at 2011 GABF.  22 oz. bomber.  Smelled like campfire.  Still very dark but with a lot of color bleed at the edges.  Tasted just like smoked bacon.  Lingering, bacony finish.  Not much else going on but so wild and distinct I will be getting some to lay down to share with friends on a chilly night. Not something Id want to drink the whole bottle of, but very unique and enjoyable experience. 

>>>Rerate of 09 had early 13 on draft at Falling Rock.  Sweet apple wood smoke nose.  Not bacony yet, just very savor smoke on dark toasted malt.
Smokey goodness.  Pours a dark brown with a nice head.  Great smoked flavor but well balanced by roasted malts and hints of sweet chocolate.  A great smoked beer.

poured dark and little to no head from 22 oz bottle 2010 bottle. scents of smokey wood chips led right into the same taste. sweet taste in the porter and smokey flavors. texture in the mouth is a smooth crispy caramel and chocolate flavor also. I am lucky to been to Juneau and need to head back soon
22 0z bottle.  Poured dark opaque brown.  Strong aroma of smoke.   Smelled like a campfire.  Taste of dark burnt malt.  A little bacon flavor.

2010 vintage 22oz bottle. This pours nearly pitch black with some mahogany at the edges and topped by a thin, tan colored head of foam that quickly recedes and rejoins the body below. The aroma is really nice and starts off quite smokey and meaty just like a smoker filled with barbeque. I get some of the salt cured pork in there as well. Further inhalation reveals some semi sweet and dark chocolate malt, caramel, oak, and roast. There is some balancing bitterness on the back end as well. The flavor follows with the dry, meaty smoke and wood up front followed by the dark chocolate and sweet caramel malts which add some nice sweetness to all the smoke and roast. As the beer warms the smoke mellows out and lets all the dark cocoa and malts shine through. The palate is nearly full bodied and viscous with ample carbonation that leads to a dry, smokey finish.  This isnt as smokey as earlier vintages that I have had, but still a great beer nonetheless. Awesome stuff.

750 ml Bottle 2009. Aroma:  Bandaids, dark, intense smoky BBQ sauce, bitter coffee.
Flavor:  Bitter coffee, smoke, bitter chocolate though with smooth body.
Comment:  Hoping that the bandaid aroma blows off.  Perhaps this bottle just didnt age well.

22 oz. from Chucks. Had this at SIB 2010 and thought it was undrinkable. Bought a bottle today and its not as bad as I remember. Definitely smoky. Solid robust stout once you get past the smoke. Not sure its 99th percentile good but its up there.

Bottle (from the november 2005 RB-tasting at Dixens place - notes have been damaged by flooding of my basement, but this was such an insane tasting for me as I was new to such massive tastings, so I gave up on the detailed notes quite early). Smoke! Delicious smoked beer! All thats readable from the notes...

2009 bomber. Dark brown with creamy tan head.Roasted malts, smoke and bacon (think mesquite or hickory dry smoked bacon), caramel. Thin, well carbonated, smoky and meaty, hint of sweetness but well balanced bitterness as well, quite dry, lingering smoke and meat on the palate. Quite interesting - and worth trying.

Shared a bomber with some friends. Poured dark brown with some tan head. I picked up the smoke in the aroma, but in no way thought it overpowering. I had aged it a year or two, so maybe that mellowed it a bit.

Flavor was of an excellent malty porter with a bit of smoke. I wasnt sure Id like a smoked beer, but I had no issues with this one. I picked up the bomber on a business trip to Denver. If I could get it in Indiana, Id be happy to drink more of this.

2010 Bottle. Fantastic. 8 Wired Big Smoke blew me away but I think this is better again ! Glad to have a few more bottles put away. Pours an oily black with a thick tan head. Never enjoyed the bacon note on smoked beers a great deal and this is fairly the same. A little better than most. Slight bacon and wood with roasted malts and dark fruits. Smokiness isnt overpowering in the taste at all. Constant peat and wood throughout. Fantastic beer

Pours an almost oily looking color. Used oil. thin off-white, creamy head. Fades quickly and leaves ample lacing behind. Lets get a whiff of this. Hmm. Smoke. Didnt see that one coming. A little malt and a bit of alder. Oily. Tastes much like the aroma at first. Smoky and smoky. A bit dry, but ample sweetness to balance it out. A very viscous mouth feel. A good mixture of dryness mixed with the sweetness in the mouth as well. Overall a very, very good beer. I wish I could get more of this and horde it. That and get a bit fresher to compare. I drank an 08 vintage.
Pours a jet black with coffe and cream colored head that is short lived. Nice lacing. Caramel and raisin aromas then smoke. Smoky taste and aroma but balanced not overpowering. Very Nice.

Deutlich rauchiger Malzantrunk, der wenige Hefenoten bietet. Die von Anfang an hohe Rauchgikeit bleibt bestehen, wird aber durch süße Noten ergänzt. Sie schwächelt zum Ende, in dem sie nur noch ausgleitet. Weich, wenig herb, die Rauchgiekit ist auch zum Ende angenehm. Vollmundig, dezent röstig. Wirklich gut. 11/12/13/13/13/12

Same bottle as pictured, Beer was really tasty stuff, pours black, aroma of smoke, taste is really nice, the smoke flavour is not terriblely over power and the malts that come through arent too much like other porters they are kind of sweet. Very tasty stuff recommend a taste
Had a flight of 02-04-08-10, I thought the 02 had the most distinct scent. The 08 and 10 has a sweeter taste than the other two.

Bottle. Had a flight of the 2002, 2004, 2008, and 2010 vintages. Very dark brown almost black pour. Minimal white head. Nice smoky nose, medium palate, and pretty much just a straight up smoked true porter flavor that fnishes slightly dry. Older vintages have the smoke recede a bit and the alcohol emerges.

A: The beer pours a dark brown color with some reddish hues and a short lived khaki head.

S: Big time smokiness to the nose with an intense saltiness and woodiness.  Theres a slightly meaty aroma to it, too.  Some roasted malts and a hint of sweetness underneath, perhaps toffee.

T: As expected, huge smokiness on the palate.  Burnt wood and ash with plenty of roasted malt flavor to it as well.  A slight chalkiness to the flavor and only a minimal toffee sweetness to the beer.

M: Medium in body with a medium level of carbonation.

O: The smokiness didnt work well with the other flavors here, it just takes over and really dries out the mouth.

Ordered this from one of the Oregon bottle shops. Served in a Jackie Os snifter

Pours a very dark brown and is nearly opaque. Good off white head with a bit of lacing and a good collar as it goes down. The nose brings quite a bit of smoked malt and a bit of meaty bacon. Theres also a slight amount of roast. Flavor is dominated by smoke and meat with a nice roasted malt backing. Medium body with a nice dry finish. Waited awhile to try this and it did not disappoint.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-03-2011

10 bottle.  Nice tan head on black beer.  Aroma is smoke over dry, roasted malt and a touch of char bitterness.  Smoke influence continues through the flavor and is joined by roasted malt, chocolate, and a small nip of sweet malt through the finish.  Light feel in the mouth.  Great beer.
Huge smoke aroma but not overly bacony or overpowering. Very refined smoke aroma. Sweet malty flavor up front with a massive malt bitterness at the end.
(draught - Schlafly Repeal of Prohibition) black with tan head. Aroma of smoke and roast malt. Flavor was overwhelmed by smoke - no subtlety.

[Bottle] 2010 version. Pours a very dark brown color with a thick cap of beige head. Charred malts, smoke, bacon and earth in the nose. The taste is very smoky and rich. Chargrilled meats, ash, dark chocolate, light espresso and some wood in the taste. Full mouthfeel. Light carbonation. Oily and rich finish. Lingering strong smoke notes. Very tasty!

650ml bottle, 2009. 
Aroma is nothing but smoke!! Sausages, soy and smokey bacon. Flavor is a mix of big smoke and loads of piney hops. The pine just covers your palate and the finish. Long dry bitter finish. Pretty nice stuff!!

2008 version from a 22oz bottle into my Orval glass.

The beer pours dark black with a disappointing light tan head. It only rises about half a finger and is gone right, poor lacing. 

The aroma is on the lighter side, giving off a lot of malts, very sweet on the front with chocolate and it finishes with a smooth smokiness with a hint of pork. 

The taste is actually pretty simple and boring. Its not overly flavorful, starts off with some minor coffee notes and finishes with some bitter smokiness. This either needs to be sweeter or have more smoke, but right now just not enough of anything.

I was really looking forward to this and sadly came away pretty disappointed.

Alaskan Smoked Porter. Pours out a black color with about a half inch light brown head with a creamy consistency. It has a very smoky aroma basically having the woody smoke source right under you. The flavor is very smoky as well and slightly fishy. It also has the bitter bite from the hops. Overall it has a huge flavor not to be underestimated. The light mouthfeel makes the porter seem almost creamy and the medium body carries the flavors and aroma very well.

2008 Bottle pulled from the cellar sampled 3-29-2009.
Pours a dark brown with faint reddish highlights on the extreme edges. Thinnish tan head dissipates almost instantly. Smells like a forest fire. Charred wood and burnt plastics meld with some chocolate and roast. Taste is chocolate and roast with that smoked burnt wood character. Carbonation is ample almost prickly, body is medium, mouthfeel is creamy smooth. Great smoked porter. Lots of smoked/burnt character. This is not something Id drink everyday, but its a nice sipper.

2007 bottle.
Poured into a snifter. ASP is onyx in color with a rich tan head. Low retention rate, with some mild lacing. Very sweet aromas. Breakfast cereal malts, and a lot of smoky characteristics. The smokiness is definitely on. Some bacon and smoked salmon flavors, tied together with some great roasted malts. Perfect carbonation level. Nice rich mouthfeel, but not heavy at all. A very nice change for me, but I think its a little too hyped from the beer community. Definitely worth a try but I didnt find it to be amazing.

Bottle. Pours pitch black with smallish tan coloured head. Great aromas of roasted malt and smkoed bacon. Really good. Flavours show plenty of roasted malt bitterness and a little sweet dark coffee. Mouthfeel is slightly on the thin side, but this is a very good beer.

Bomber from grub.

Appearance : Pours pitch black with a small head.

Aroma : Dark fruits with light smoke and light hops. Nice roasted malt. Nice notes of raisins. Very rich.

Taste : Light smoke with red dry fruits and some raisins. Finish has light notes of smoke with red fruits and light hops. Nice notes of dark chocolate. 

Overall : Interesting stuff. Well balanced. Smoke could be a bit more present. Nice fruits on nose and taste. Well done, nicely balanced but nothing outstanding.

Pours black with a thin beige head. Aroma is excellent very rich and smoky. Flavour is very nice flavour is smoky and rich without being over powering. This is an excellent beer very criminals and well balanced.I have no complaints. This is a great brew.

2004 Bomber. Pours opaque black, brown at the edges. 1-finger pale tan head, spotty lacing. Nose is big and smoky, as one would expect - nice cherrywood/beechwood smoke, some chocolate, big beef jerky notes, some creosote/sooty notes, also pencil shavings. Flavours of smoke, ham rind, love the smoke on this one. Perfect balance, insanely long finish. Lovely stuff.

Bottle shared by Sean at RBWG 2011, thanks. Im surprised to see that I havent rated this beer. At RBWG I had the 02 & 04. The 02 was slightly better, the 04 seemed somewhat thinner and milder 
Appearance: Black with a small tan head and some light lacing 
Aroma: Dark malts, smoked salmon and chocolate 
Taste: Roasted malts, ashy, smokey and chocolate 
This was a great beer, the 02 was very nice.

2010 Bomber. Pours a dark brown with thick tan head. It has a smoky aroma, not very complex, but not overdone either. The flavor is a nice complement of roasted malts, wood, bitter chocolate, and smoke. The bottle I had had a bit of a metallic taste to it but I didnt reflect that in my score seeing as someone I shared the bottle with has had this many times and said he has never experienced it before. I have a 12oz bottle from 2002 in the cellar that I cant wait to compare to this.

2009 version in 22 oz. bottle. Smoke aroma and taste were outstanding! More like fine smoked salmon than cheap bacon! Pitch black color with a tan head. Solid body and mouth feel equal to most stouts, rather than porters. Alcohol absent from taste. Really is one-of-a-kind!

@Josie Bones Colloingwood. Very dark brown, creamy head. Dark chocolate and woody smoke characters. Dark chocolate bitterness, some vanilla sweetness. Taste of rich dark chocolate, low bitterness and weighted towards the smokey side. Great style and very good.

The Alasken Smoked Porter poured almost black in color and carried a light smoky/roasted aroma. First taste brought light roasted malt flavor followed by an overwhelming taste of smoked wood-chips.  This residual smoky taste further remained  the powerful characteristic holding this beer together.

22oz bomber, 2010 edition, from Blackwells. pours a dark, cola brown with a thick, creamy, light beige head leaving thin, sticky rings of lace. aroma is great with thick, rich, smoked wood, salty bacon,  and light soy with notes of dark chocolate, campfire ash, and dark fruit notes of black cherry and figs with hints of roast coffee and topsoil as it warms. flavor is delicious as well with smoked malts, salty beef jerky, and dark chocolate up front backed by smooth caramel malts, ash, tart black cherries, plum skins, and earthy hops with hints of burnt coffee on the back end. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a wonderfully bitter, smoked, roasted malt finish. overall, a great smoked porter.

2010 bottle. Black with a light tan head that fades to a coat but lingers. Aroma of charred smoked pork, vanilla, a little coffee. Oily texture lightened by carbonation and some astringency. Taste has mild sweetness with some berries, roasted bitterness, less smoke  than suggested in the smell. Moderate but well defined roasted bitter finish. Intense flavours but remains nimble and easygoing. Very good.

Enjoyed from a 22oz bomber in an English pint glass.  The beer pours a very deep brown to black color, with a small tan head.  The nose shows a pleasing campfire smoked character, along with a note resembling smoked salmon.  Slight chocolate notes peak in the background.  The palate shows smoke, as expected, again a very nice campfire/smoked meat character.  Notes of wood also come through, as does a small amount of flavors resembling a traditional porter.  The overall flavor profile resembles the great smoked lagers of Bamburg.  The finish leaves a lingering semi-sweet note, along with a touch of smoke.  Overall, a beer that absolutely lives up to the hype

Aromas of dark chocolate, roasted coffee, tar and smoke. Smoke is definitely the dominant flavour, a great complement to the coffee/chocolate character of the porter. Full mouthfeel and some residual sweetness smooth out the edges and enhance sessionability. Lengthy finish is all smoke, bark and tar. Really enjoyed this beer.

Pours a beautiful, very dark brown with ruby flecks. Aroma is amazing smoke, with cedar. Like a log cabin.  Mouthfeel is medium with nice viscosity. Nice carbonation.  This is an amazing porter - nice, surprising crispness and beautifully balanced by the smoke.

Wow! Bottle at a tasting, 15th of January 2011. Pours a deep brown, with a light brown head. Aromas are quite chocolatey, roasted and of course some smoke. Flavour is quite similar, although the smoke didnt overpower the other flavours, really just complimented. Enjoyed this one!

750ml bottle. Black pour, thick texture. Oily lacing with a thin brown bubbly head. Aroma is very smokey. Woody characters with dark chocolate. The flavors are pretty smokey as well. Somewhat heavy on the palate,  but with a lot of balance and flavors.

From notes:

Pours a very dark chestnut brown color that appears black in the glass and almost completely opaque. Huge three finger frothy, pillowy mocha head that has excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that cots the glass with large chunks of soapy lacing.

Very smokey malt aroma with hints of BBQ, charcoal, bacon, butane and campfire. Theres also some roasted coffee bean, silky chocolate and burnt toast in the nose.

Full bodied, so much so you can practically chew on this beer. This beer has a huge smokey flavor with hints of bacon, charcoal and barbecue but it also has a creamy lactic presence mid-palate that provides excellent balance and complexity. Hints of silky chocolate, toffee, coffee bean, wood and more smoke. The balance, complexity and well masked ABV make this beer extremely quaffable. Although, it is one of the smokier beers Ive had, its not a complete smoke bomb. Even if you dont like this style and/or rauchbiers I still recommend that you give it a try. Excellent!
On tap at falling rock. Black with an inch thick cream head. Aroma is smoky licorice. Flavor is also smoke and licorice. Very nice.
Bottle (in NZ). Much vaunted, and much deserved. Everything you want in a smoked beer, one of the best. Was a shame I had to share the bottle.

Bottle 2010 Vintage. Pours very dark brown, almost black, with a rocky tan head that quickly shrinks to surface cover. Aroma is pretty smokey but quite malty also with molasses, bacon, ash, toffee and liquorice notes. Flavour follows the aroma pretty closely; the smokiness is more ashy and less meaty plus there is less malty sweetness. Thick, creamy mouthfeel with moderate carbonation and a lingering roasty, smokey finish. Smooth, really well balanced and very easy to drink, this is an outstanding smoked beer. I will definitely be picking up another bottle to age.

I do prefer this style of beer so my comments are pretty biased.  Strong Hints of chocolate and very smooth.  Not very complex but rather taste, a good desert brew. The ABV is just right and sets on the palate very well. A gift from a friend bought on the West Coast. Wish it was here in the Midwest.

Poured into dimple mug.  Chocolate, roasted coffee and smoke aromas.  Flavors are really similar.  Not too complex.  I like the fact the smoke doesnt overtake the flavors like in other beers.  Hops are hardly noticeable. The smokiness offsets the sweetness.  Really good porter.

2010 bomber. Pours nearly black with tan head. Aromas of roasted malt, smoke, and light chocolate. Flavors of roasted malts, tons of smoke, and a bit of chocolate. Really smokey aftertaste. Really well made but a little to smokey for me.

Bottle thanks to my friend frostyone. Pours an extremely dark brown to black with a small hea a no lace. Aroma is killer smoke malts, breads, caramel, smoked meats, smoked salmon, and light caramel. Taste is balanced sweetness and bitterness and not over the top with either. very balanced and drinkable. Smooth on the palate. Wonderful.

07 black pour ruby hue heavy smoke aroma and tastes like smoked salmon not much but smoke and lightly roasted 08 more dark fruit n caramel dry smokey and smooth 09 more caramel taste still dry less smoked 10 smoked roasted n caramel malt. Had all four vintages at a tasting side by side and they were all different.  Just the right smoke a good sipping porter/smoke brew.

22oz bottle pours a black body with a very thin tan head that doesnt last and thins to nothing.  Aroma is smoky roasted goodness.  Flavor follows, with a very some subtle sweet malt and a smoky bitter finish.  The smoke flavor in this beer doesnt mess around, but isnt overwhelming.  Its nicely balanced with the roasted sweetness of the malt.  Not my favorite style, but still an exception brew.

Bottle.  Smoked meat and toffee malt aroma.  Black-brown color with moderate head and nice lacing.  Sweet malt, smoked meat flavor with a mildly bitter grass hops finish.  Medium body - finishes a bit light.

22 oz bottle 2010 vintage. Black with a creamy brown head. Nose is smoke and roasted malt. Flavor is initially smoky, but then it mellows and smooth roasted malt and natural bitter cacao come through, followed by a mild hop finish. Medium bodied with dry finish. Very, very nice.

Now I know what all the hype is about! 2010 bottle, wish I could have one to age.  Dark black/brown pour with tan head, aroma is big smoked peat, chocolate, nuts, roasted malt, some coffee.  Taste is so smooth but so complex and big at the same time.  Big smoked taste, chocolate, coffee, roast, nuts, some smooth sweet and bitter notes with a touch of smoke at the end.  Fantastic brew.

Bottle courtesy of Eric.  Thanks!  2008 vintage.  Pours black with off tan head.  Aroma is smoke, chocolate, and some caramel.  Medium mouthfeel.  Flavors of smokey chocolate dominate.  In the middle there is a touch of coffee, then finishes with more sweet smoke.  This is a fantastic brew.

Vertical of 00-07.  Notes from 07 since that was a good one and fresh and most representative of the beer (notes were from the end of 2007).  Pours a rich deep brownish black with a nice lingering beige head.  Aroma is nice big woody earthy smoke, lots of smoked meats, yet, definitely distinct in its smoke from the alder wood being used gives it just a slight earthy minty grassy kick- lots of big chocolate and smooth nutty malty hints with light burnt and roasty hints.  Flavor is smooth, yet big smoked malts, earth, burnt toast big roasty dark chocolate, moderate sweetness from some caramel and pale malts, with a long lingering smooth ashy smoke in the end with a mild bitterness.  Great smoked porter and very unique to set itself apart from all the rest.  

Order of best to worst vintages from 00 to 07

04-  best, 07, 01, 06, 05, 03, 00, 02- oxidized to hell, yet the 01 held up nice!

22 oz. bottle 2008 vintage.  Pours a dark brown, near black color with large frothy, beige head.  The aroma is dark roasted malts, bakers chocolate and the ever present smoked meats.  The flavor allows the smokiness to blend effortlessly with the rest of the beer.  Roasted malts,  dark chocolate, dark fruits, and slight hints of coffee.  Mild bitterness in the finish.  The smokiness lingers.  Medium-bodied, fairly smooth.  This is good fresh or with age.   Probably one of the most consistently good beers Ive had.

2008 Bottle.  Pours a deep dark black.  I tried to shine a flashlight through the glass and couldnt see it.  Yes, very dark.  Aroma is a pine campfire smoke with a touch of sweet molasses and grain.  Flavor is smokey.  Not unlike that of smoked salmon, without the salmon taste.  And underlying caramel, pine and earthy flavor comes through in the middle with a hint of floral.  Finish is dry with peat and vanilla.  Very complex.   Very good.

Had this shipped to me from Puyallup Wash. to Ohio.
Pours a robust brown bordering on black with a thick foamy two finger mocha head that leaves little lace. The initial flavor is all smoke. As the beer slowly warms the smokiness fades some and the malt begins to make its appearance. This isnt a complex beer by any means, Smoke, Malt, A slight hop note to balance nicely.
The Smoke mellows, and really becomes  great creamy porter.
I have been waiting for this one for Years. And I also had 4 other Alaskan Brews shipped my way too.

Vintage 2010 edition.Pours a dark almost black brown with a creamy medium tan head.The aroma is a smokey sent that made my mouth water.The flavor is a very pornounced smokey, and robust coffee flavor.The full body gose down smooth and the aftertaste is a little bitter.Overall a very good beer indeed.

Poured a dark black with a thick tan head. Aromas are smoked malts and coffee beans. The taste is smooth rick coffee, dark chocolate, and smoked wood/malt flavor. A very good porter, Im glad I tried this one.

Vintage 2009, exact bottle date unknown. Pours out pitch black like a devilish stout, with a thick foamy tan head. Im getting aromas of very roasted malt and peppered salami meat, with just the faintest touch of chocolate. Oily mouthfeel with thick bubbly carbonation. The peppered salami comes through on the flavor, very clean and bright. As is definitely the quality of the style, the malt profile is as if they were grilled over a hearty backyard firepit. No noticeable hop flavor save for the mild bitterness at the finish. Hints of bourbon throughout the body lend a "barrel-aged" quality to the flavor, whether or not it actually was. Full bodied flavor without being overpowering.  A fine, fine brew.

2009 bottle from Crajun. Last of that shipment. Thanks. A very dark brownish black with nice frothy head and carbonation. Seems to have travelled well from AK to TX and now to MA. Nice sweet and smoky aroma. Flavor is very nicely balanced with the roasty malts, smoke and some hoppy bitterness on the finish. good stuff

2008 bottle from a trade with RCL. Pours dark brown with tan head. Aromas of smoked malts and chocolate. Smokey flavor up front with some sweet chocolate and a slightly ashy finish. Medium body with average carbonation. Thanks Ray.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2015 A healthy sampling from an 09 bomber at our club picnic. Poured a very dark brown, with creamy, tan head foam, and clingy ribbons of lacing. The aroma and flavor were similar, as roastiness, mellow wood, smoke and bakers chocolate. A subtle dryness and moderate bitterness were highlighted in the flavor. Recently shared a 2015 bomber poured to snifters. Smooth maltiness was key, with an added hint of leather in the nose, and a medium, earthy, smoky, and slightly tannic bitterness in the flavor.

If I was to rate this beer just on style alone, I would give it a... well 4.1 apparently.. If I was to rate the experience drinking this beer I would give it a 5. Taking a sip of this beer makes me feel like im camping in the woods. Absolutely amazing smoky flavor. This beer is camping in a bottle. Would like to see how it cooks up with some short ribs or a nice steak.
On tap at TCBF, pours black with a small beige head. Aroma is smoky, fire, though not overburdening. Flavour of roasted malt, wood and smoke. Very good.

Dark brown and opaque appearance with a creamy tan head. Bam! Smokey, woodsy smell right up front. With the first sip, theres a TON of smoked smokiness, bordering on burnt but never quite getting there. Theres also a hint of hops bitterness, but balance isnt the goal here for this porter. Pretty light mouthfeel, especially for the big flavor. If youre looking for a smokey porter, you wont be disappointed by this one. Ill probably pass on another as porters are out of my preferred wheelhouse, but theres no denying this one has big smokey taste.

22 oz bottle. 09.11.10. 2009 vintage
Poured dark chocolate brown with a one fingered tan head. The nose was peat smoked barley, smoked bacon, dark fruits, dark bitter chocolate, and slight hops. The taste was campfire smoke, smoked bacon, dark fruit (fig and slight raisin), slight hops, and extra bitter dark baking chocolate. The mouthfeel was creamy but smooth and the lacing was mild (like spiderwebs on the glass), and the legs were decent as well. Great smoked beer.
Nice aroma of smoked meats.  The appearance is dark brown, tan head.  The flavor is like the aroma, smoky, bacon, some chocolate.  piney hops, smoke in the finish.  Very good.

Dark brown/black color; Medium slightly creamy body; Aroma of smoked meat, burnt oak, and some dark chocolate; Flavor of smoky/roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee, and some dark fruit; Finish is slightly bitter; Nicely balanced; The aroma is almost as good as the Schlenkerla brews - but not quite; Overall, really good - I did enjoy it.

Toasty, chocolate aroma with a just-right amount of smokiness.  Head is small and isnt retained long.  The alder lends it a very similar smoke to hickory, but doesnt take center-stage.  It just adds to the overall sensation without making it taste like one big smoked ham.  Chocolate comes through with a nice bitterness at the end.  Surprisingly light for the style.  One of the best smoked beers I have had to date.
SMOKE! Lots and lots of it! Very dark, almost black color. head fades quick. Finishes super smokey and lingers in the back of the throat forever. Love it!

2009 bomber.  Pours deep black / brown with tan / brown colored head, which lingers around with nice lacing.  Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate, and most prominently smoked meat, pork, brunswick stew.  Taste initially reveals rich roasted flavors, which are sweetened slightly by chocolate, and then continues to smoked bacon flavors which expand in intensity and complexity on the finish.  This beer has a very nice palate, smooth silky mouth feel, medium to full bodied.  The smokiness on the finish is almost spicy, as if I was eating a pulled pork sandwich with some tangy barbecue sauce.  Yet I wouldnt go so far as to put the smokiness / roasted meat aspect of this beer on the same level as Aecht Schlenkerla for example.  This beer is more subtle, although the smokiness does dominate the aroma, it is more subdued in the flavor, which also features some nice chocolate / espresso tones.  Overall pretty damn nice, I like porters and I like smoke beers and this one does it very well.  Highly recommended.
Thanks thirdeye11 dude.  Smells like trash, but tastes like bacon.  I am not sure I have ever had anything from Alaskan that I like.  But Im new.

(22oz bottle 2009 vintage) Espresso brown pour, creamy
dark tan bubbles and fantastic lacing. Nose of brown sugar, applewood bacon, sweet bakers chocolate, cedar and smoke. Taste is chalky and dry, smokey fruit, cocoa, a little like an ashtray but still interesting. Creamy smoky finish.  Slightly thin. Wanted to like it more but the thin body and lack of sweetness sort of disappointed me.

2009 bottle sent from Alaska by 12many.  He knows I like smoked beers, thanks man.   Excellent smoked porter containing notes of campfire ashes, chocolate malts, and bacon.  I feel like I need to take a shower after drinking this beer, like I was sitting next to a bonfire all night.  Good stuff!

2009 22oz pours black with thick tan foamy head. Aroma is chocolate and roasted malts. Taste is smoked wood, like a campfire, roasted malts with chocolate, earthy, alcohol is present but still remains very drinkable. All around mellow and enjoyable.
2009 Bottle thanks to wavers1. Pours black with little tan head. Nose is BBQ, smoke and roasted malts. Taste is same.

A decent smooth smoky aroma settles in your nose, bacon is awesome. The dark porter oil color has a light tan creamy head. It is a smooth smoky striaght up porter flavor with roasty smoked malt flavors. You tasted smoked wood chips.

One helluva lingering smoke flavor, that is for sure. Unfortunately, thats about all that stands out. Kind of thin - not memorable from a mouthfeel perspective. If you are into smokiness, this is your brew for sure.

2009 bomber picked up in Colorado back in April.  Pours pitch black with a thin beige head and just a bit of retention.  Unlike the Smokejumper that was tasted alongside, the Alaskan had LOADS of smoke, making up the predominant aroma and flavor.  This one even had more of a mesquite BBQ flavor as opposed to the oaky nature of most imperials.  Not much in the way of yeast or hops here, this bad boy is a malt bomb that ran through an inferno.  Surprisingly boozy at the end for only 6.5%, this one is quite an experience!
brown, minimal head, tan foam, roasty, smoke, medium bitterness, average carbonation, light body, thin feel, long finish,

2008 bottle. Thanks again Gobs. Dark near black; medium khaki head. Huge smoke aroma - think Schlenkerla. Flavor is mostly smoke as well - salty hammy charred camp fire flavors. Some porter elements sneak in towards the end. All in all an extremely flavorful beer; medium bodied and remarkably drinkable, at least before the smokiness builds up. I wouldnt say its fair to compare this along with traditional porters, but this is very good any way I look at it.

Absolutely fantastic stuff, makes me regret living in the Midwest as many of the west coast beers tried on my recent vacation have been outstanding.  This was a very lucky find.  In the back of the Holiday Wine Cellar in Escondido, CA, they have a cold room with a bunch of overstocked items.  I was peering through everything when I found a rogue bottle of this Smoked Porter and gasped in delight as Ive heard great things about this one.  It doesnt disappoint at all.  Aroma of pure smoked malts with hints of coffee and very dark chocolate.  Appearance is beautiful, pure black with a frothy, creamy head.  Taste is of decadence, rather creamy, smokey, light on the chocolate with hints of lactose.  Really happy that I found this one.

Pours a deep thick brown with just faint transparency.  Head is a light brown and persistent.  Nose starts with bittersweet malt and follows with a deep smoky finish.  Full palate, bitter, smoky, and finishes with a burnt malt.  Lively bubbles.  Delicious.

2009 Bottle.  Aroma has notes of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, grassy hops and smoke.  Very dark brown hue that sits black in the glass with an average sized foamy tan head that managed to stick around and leave a decent lace.  Flavor is slightly sweet with a bitter smokey finish.  Palate is medium bodied with an average carbonation and a cloying bitter smokey finish that lasted just a little too long.  Overall a good brew with a nice aroma.

(2009 edition; 22 oz bottle). Pours black with off-white head.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, coffee, soy sauce(?).  Taste is bitter and smoky and a little sweet, but not much.  Medium bodied and a little thin-surprisingly. This beer is much better as it warms because the sweetness emerges and balances out the smoke.  I thought that when it was colder the smoke absolutely dominated so give the beer time to warm and you will be rewarded with a nicely balanced  beer.

Shared by levifunk...thanks Levi! - POurs dark, with a bubbly tan head. Smells like a campfire, but not in an overpowering way. The smoke is pungent without being over the top, though it doesnt let the malt peek out very much. Taste is smoky and malty, with a dark chocolate finish. Thin and watery, but smooth. This was a nice treat, and a beer Id love to have again.

Serving: 22 oz. bottle. 
It pours a very dark brown with a dense, light tan head.  The nose is a nice mix of roasted malt, smoked meat, and slight burnt notes.  The flavor is very roasty with great smoked malt notes.  Its a wee bit on the burnt and bitter side.  Medium body with a long, smokey and bitter finish.  Not something you necessarily want to session, but fairly tasty.

Sampled at SAVOR 2010.  Pours a medium bodied black with some cloudy beige head.  Nose is malty, toast, dark bread, chocolate, light smoke.  Flavor is sweet, malty, bready, light smoke, caramel.  Full bodied while still being easy to drink.  This was one of my favorites from the event.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2012 Bottle. Dark brown with a creamy tan head. The aroma is smoked malt, coffee, light chocolate and bacon. Sweet smoked flavour is lots of caramel and dark fruit. Light coffee notes. Bacon bamberg malty finish.
New entry: 2002 edition sampled 10 years later. Still quite peated with lots of tar and some roasted malt. Not oxidiced at all.

I found a local liquor store looking to rid itself of these 2008 vintage bombers, so I bought three for less than $10..  This beer rocks.  Its smoked but not overboard smoked.  I like the flavor that lingers.  Its an unsung find in my book.

2008 vintage bomber.  First rating for a Smoked.  Pours pitch black with one finger of tan foam.  Aroma is aromatic smoke, campfire, leather, salted bacon, some chocolate...really lovely stuff.  Flavor is more smoke, leather, chocolate, and lesser notes of coffee.  Rich creamy finish with some lingering ashiness on the tongue.  Would not be a go-to beer for me, but still really good stuff.  (951, 312)

2009 bottle received from crajun.  Pours a deep brown color with off white head.  Smell is smoke, chocolate, and roasted malt.  Flavor backed the aroma and was very good but it lacked the smoke that I was expecting.  A little more would have been nice, but still a good beer.

22oz bomber purchased from Liquid Solutions

Appearance: Pours a murky brown with a small 1 finger mocha head. Some retention and a fair amount of lacing.

Smell: Smoked wood, nuts, a touch of sweet malt, roasted barley, and chocolate. Well done.

Taste: After having some German Rauchbiers I was really expecting more smoke from this brew. Still a well balanced mix of flavors that encompass the same notes as the nose.

Mouthfeel: not creamy enough IMHO. Good but no wow factor.

Drinkability: A touch thick in body preventing me from giving it more than a 4.0 but still nice.

A good brew although I was expecting more.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-27-2009

A supreme beer of its style. Black pour with medium head. Aroma of islay scotch. Peaty, smoky and full of chocolate. Flavor is similar with added roasted malt. Hints of meat come along with the smoke additive. Burnt wood as well. Excellent.

2009 Bottle.  Pours black with thin creamy tan head.  Smoked peat and salmon aromas.  Liquid smoke, burnt malt, smoked salmon, coffee, and dark chocolate flavors with a bitter finish.  Full bodied with high carbonation.  Tasted a little weird at first, but the flavors grew on me and I ended up liking this beer a lot.  Very different.

UPDATED: OCT 9, 2011 Light rauch smoked, bonfire aroma.  Brownish-black color.  Smokey flavor...too smokey for me.

2nd try, same consensus (2008 bottle sampled in 2011).
Pours dark molasses in colour with a medium tan colored head.  The aromoa shows off the smoked qualities of this porter as well as the flavor.  An impressive porter and definitely worth enjoying.
Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is roasted malt, heavy smoke and liquorish. Flavour is roasted malt, smoke, liquorish and light maltacidic.

2009 bottle thanks to grownfool.  Dark brown-red, loose tan foam.  Great aroma, campfire ashy smokiness, reminiscent of a bit of bacon, but the ash really dominates.   Rich, slightly creamy body, chocolate, roast, ash, good smoke.  If this was readily available this would be a go to.

2009 batch, bomber.  Pours dark brown with a one finger khaki head into a pint glass.  Big smoked malt aroma, almost like smoked ham/bacon, coffee, dark chocolate.  Big, and I mean big, smoky flavor, finishing with roast coffee.  Medium bodied with a fluffy mouthfeel and a low to medium level of carbonation.  Definitely the smokiest brew Ive had, love this style with breakfast.
Vintage 2007 courtesy StFun.  Wow smokey. Its just present enough to make it awesome, not too overdone.  Good stuff.

22 oz bottle of the 2008 vintage. Pours deep dark brown with a lush creamy beige head. Aroma of mostly smooth smokey malt with a bit of the Porter showing through with some chocolate and coffee. Flavor of smoke which lends a bitter flavor but the rich chocolate malts balance and blend out the beer. Medium body with average carbonation and a thick creamy mouth feel. Ive been drinking this one for at least a decade and its always great, some years tend to be a bit better than others but I never turn one down.
pours really dark brown.  definately smells like a campfire. ha.  for some reason it tastes a bit like smoked salmon.  good feel and a bit dry.
From a 22 oz bottle, Light brown head,smokey,chocolate,coffee,black in color.

Bottle. Pours dark brown with a creamy head made of fine bubbles. Aromas is mainly smoke with roasty, coffee, woody, and resin also contributing. Tastes fairly sweet with a bit of a sour twinge and a bitter finish which is accompanied by a dry smoky coating on the plate.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2011 2009 Bottle. Pours thick with a nice black coffee color and a half-inch of creamy light brown head. Smoky sweet aroma with some roasted malt and dark roast coffee bean fragrances. Taste is intensely smoky with strong, dark roasted malt flavors and robust coffee bitterness. Also some hints of bittersweet chocolate and rum. It finishes dry, burnt and slightly boozy. Aftertaste is extremely bitter and smoky. This Porter is rich, bitter and loaded with smokiness. Not for the faint of heart. Id definitely like to try an aged bottle.

A nearly black, dark brown pour with a huge tan head on it that persists.  Leaves lacing as I drink.  Aroma is primarily of delicious wood smoke with creamy chocolate undertones.  The flavor of this has a certain burnt meat quality to it, between the rich smoke and the dark roasted malt flavors, along with some more creamy chocolate in the background.  Has a moderate body and drinks really easily.  How did I ever go so long before trying this?

2007 Bottle. Pours black with a large milk chocolate colored head, fine lacing all around. Aroma is very complex - smoky, roasty, musky, oak, and an array of other aspects that I cant quite pick out. 

The taste is extremely complex... heavy on the smokiness but with undertones of oak and molasses. Great beer.

Comes out of the bottle a deep opaque coffee-brown with an OK beige head. Rich, smoky aroma has an odd vinyl-like component to it - odd yeast? Hops?. Smoky, coffee-like flavor has a strong hint of molasses. Texture is smooth, fairly tingly and quite lively.
Bomber of 2008. Pours black with minimal brown head. Aroma of roast, bacon and smoke. Taste is less aggressive in smoke, only leaving an aftertaste of it.

Bomber. One of the best smoked style beers available. This is a very unique and solid porter with more smoke than a forest fire. Aroma is of course smoky and the taste is similar plus hints of licorice and, well, more smoke.  (actual tasting was on 2/19 - catching up on a marathon tasting session from a couple weeks back)

2008 Bomber courtesy of wavers1, thanks Baker, been looking forward to this one! Pours nearly black with a 2 finger, chunky, mocha head that has great retention. Aroma is smoke up front, mild roast, licorice, a hint of earth, and musty old firewood. Flavor is light smoke and a hint of dark caramel up front, the smoke flavor really evolves as the beer rolls over the palate as does the malt heavy profile. The light smoke and dark caramel give way to bittersweet chocolate and sweet pipe tobacco smoke, finishing with fantastic hardwood smoke, roast and a little salty, earthy wood. Palate is medium bodied with a creamy entry, slightly chalky and dry but still creamy middle and a more chalky and dry finish. Really the palate changes  compliment the evolution of the flavor profile perfectly, I would like to see how it would be with a slightly lower carbonation (it is a bit sharp for the style), but it is pretty awesome where it is now. I really love this stuff, if only it were available here....

From tap at Carlsbad. Pours dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma is smoked ham and bacon aroma, dark roasted malt. Smooth and smoked malt flavoured. Lingering smoked and bacon flavoured finish. Smoked and dry malty finish.

Bottle. Pours a pitch black beer with a lightbrown head. The aroma is smoke, licorice and roasted. The flavor follows the nose closely. The palate is smoke and roasted. Overall a good beer with good balance and complexity.
2008 version.  22 oz. bottle.  Aroma was of smoke and notes of bacon.   The flavor was of smoke and roasted malt.  A worthy porter.

Bottle @ J.C.G US Tasting Pt.2. Pours pitch black with a stable creamy beige head and lacings. Nose is smoked salami and coffee roast. Smooth and full bodied. Flavor is roasted coffee with ashy hints and smoke upfront. Fine

Alaskan Brewing Company--Smoked Porter	
1997 16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)	Rich Smoke Flavor and Sweet Chocolate Body.  Sampled 11/15/1997.

1998  16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.10%ABV.  (2.5 / 5.0)  Rich smoke flavor at start complements chocolate malt in body for a wonderful first taste, but smoke loses its impact immediately leaving a weak body with little flavor.  Nice dry finish.	 Sampled 12/2/1998.

1999 16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.10% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)  Clear deep dark red color.  Light smoky chocolate fruit front.  Tight carbonation spices taste.  Medium body tends to cherry ale sweetness with rich smoked toffee base.  Smoked spiciness lasts to end.  Sampled 11/2/1999.

2000 16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.10% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Clear dark black color.  Rich smoked spice nose.  Thin light chocolate head.  Burnt roasted mild dry fruit flavor.  Crusty body.  Mild spicy finish with trailing chalky roasted flavor.  Rich, pervaded by smoke.  Sampled 12/29/2000.

2001 16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV.  (3.75 / 5.0)	Clear dark black color.  Minimal head.  Smoky hoppy floral front.  Thin roasted body with smooth crisp dry flavor.  Roasted Smoke dominates light sweet fruit flavor.  Clean hoppy dry mild chocolate end.  Odd.  Sampled 11/25/2001.

2002 16 oz. Bottle Release.  6.10% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Clear dark red black color.  Light tan head and lace.  Rich alder smoked roasted mild espresso hop front.  Rich creamy sweet roasted black cherry fruity body.  Smoke lingers in rich earthy mild hop end.  Sampled 12/14/2002.

2003 16.9 oz	. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Light head.  Opaque dark black color.  Smoky tangy roasted mild hop front.  Chalky burnt dry sweet smoked espresso mild fruit cacao body.  Hot roasted hop end.  Mild black cherry citrus notes.  Smoke rules.  Rich.  Sampled 1/5/2004.

2004 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)	Mild lacy tan creamy light head.  Clear opaque dark obsidian black red color.  Crisp roasted smoky mild hop espresso front.  Rich dry sweet complex roasted espresso biscuit smoke body.  Clean mild hop end.  Sampled 11/20/2004.

2005 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Mild tan lacy head.  Clear opaque dark black red color.  Smoky aroma.  Toasted hop front.  Dry sweet thin crisp burnt malt body.  Smoky rich spicy hop end.  Nice but Overwhelming Smoke Notes.  Sampled 2/8/2006.

2006 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Lacy rich espresso head.  Clear dark obsidian red black color.  Smoky burnt hop espresso front.  Cloying thick roasted mild sweet chocolate coffee burnt biscuit body.  Balanced mild hop spice smooth smoky end.  Sampled 11/18/2006.

2007 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.5 / 5.0)	Big dense lacy rocky espresso head.  No sediment.  Clear obsidian ruby red black color.  Mild chocolate smoky mild floral hop front.  Mild creamy crusty mild sweet toffee black cherry chocolate body.  Dry balanced spicy lingering smoke smooth hop end.  Mellow.  Sampled 1/7/2009.  4 @ $5.99 each.

2008 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV--45 IBUs.  (4.0 / 5.0)	Thin dark espresso light lace head.  Clear dark black red color.  Rich smoky mild espresso toasted hop front.  Dry sweet roasted coffee smoked mild biscuit thin body.  Dry mild hot hop spice easy to drink rich too smoky unbalanced end.  Still tasty.  Sampled 2/14/2009.  2 @ $6.49 Each.

Alaskan Brewing Company--Smoked porter--Gold Medal Winner--2009 22 oz. Bottle Release.  6.50% ABV 45 IBUs.  (4.35 / 5.0)  Porter---Smoked--Lacy dense rich rocky long lasting tan coffee head.  Clear dark black color with pretty bronze red edge highlights.  No sediment.  Delicate alder smoke toasted coffee hop aromatic front.  Dry sweet rich burnt malt toffee cherrywood mild fruit light smoked Porter body.  Cloying crusty bitter black malt mild hop spice end.  Smooth well integrated smoke.  Not overpowering as in some years.  Sampled 2/17/2010.  2 @ $6.99 each.
Black with a small tan head. Roasted aroma with licorice notes, and strong smoke: Bacon and camp fire mostly. Dryish roasted flavour with smoke

2006 bottle shared by a friend at my Super Awesome Ridiculous Stout Tasting on 1/23/10. Darkest brown pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of dark malt, chocolate and bacon. Equally bacony flavor with some sweet malt and chocolate.

bottle, thanks to secret santa, 2009 vintage, pours dark brown with a tall frothy tan head.  Aroma is very rich with chocolate malt dominating and a thin layer of smoke in the background.  Flavor is rich coffee and chocolate flavors then the smoke hits and lingers on into a long finish.  Very nice smoked brew.

Picked this up when I was out in California.  Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Aroma of smokey malt.  Flavor of smoke, meat, and some chocolate.  Well done Porter, good flavor and very easy to drink.  Good brew.
Solid black, big creamy light tan head. Aroma of bacon, chocolate, cherry, vanilla. Taste is more bitter cocoa/burnt malt with a coffee finish and smoke throughout. Full bodied, creamy texture.
definite BBQ aroma.  pours dark brown with an espresso head.  smoke flavors linger on top of the porter base.  nice lacing left on the glass. not heavy at all.

2009 Vintage sampled 1/18/10.

Pours dark brown with an off-white head. The aroma is lots of smoke with some roasted malts. The flavor is heavy omn the smoke but you also get some standard porter characteristics like dark malts. Medium mouthfeel and low carbonation.

2009 bottle courtesy of smellysell...thanks Justin!  He also sent a 2005, but Im holding onto that one for a special occasion.  Pitch black pour with a mocha-colored head.  Smells of smoke and black coffee.  Like nice ground strong coffee beans.  Taste is similar...very roasty with a smoky background and definite coffee notes.  Head takes forever to dissipate.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Its a shame more breweries dont make smoked porters....I found this very enjoyable.
10th October 2008. Falling Rock. Clear dark brown beer. Heavy malt and intense smokiness. A little hops almost an afterthought. I like smoked beers but dont understand the reputation of this one.

Thanks to my buddy who traveled all the way back here from Colorado with this beer. Bottle was 2008 Smoked Porter 22oz. Poured a almost black color with a nice, creamy looking tan head. Aroma is a nice smoky porter, with touches of roasted malts, chocolates. Flavor tasted a lot more like what Id like from a smoked beer than Ive had the last few times. This one is a lot more subtle, with the smoke not overpowering the beer to such a degree that it tastes like Im drinking liquid smoke.

Smoked sausage, chocolate, black currant aroma. Opaque c olour, brown head, good lace. Sweet, chocolate, bitter, black currant and smoke. Light sandy, light bodied. Flavourful, easy going, balanced. Lovely stuff.

Gentle but assertive smokiness, like a fire burning in the woods. Allows the malt to come through as well, chocolate and roasty. Has a light fruitiness. Smoke fades into bittersweet, not acrid, roasted not burnt, toffee, coffee, cherry, plums, and then returns to linger on your taste buds. Vinous quality peeks into the nose. Flavor a bit like old ale. Slick, yet dry.

Alaskan Brewing 
2009 Smoked Porter 22oz.
Pours dark brown to black with a smallish creamy tan head. Aroma of standard porter beer with some liquid smoke added. Reminded us of a bacon cocktail, the new drink invented by mixologists. Aroma was not totally displeasing. Flavor was another matter. Tasted of burnt mesquite. Overpowering as if the beer had somehow survived a house fire and we decided to drink it. I hoped it would improve as it warmed. It got worse. Tasted terrible, poured it out.

Bottle of the 2008 thanks to BFC, thanks Jake.  Pours a just clear cola brown with a medium sized tan head.  Smoke and toast, light plum and prune behind it.  Medium bodied, light sweetness, with some caramel.  Roast and smoke on the finish with a light bitterness.

Bottle at home, 17th Aug 09, shared with BeerTart. Near black with a small tan head. Delicate smoky aroma with liquorice and carbolic soap hints. In the mouth, luxuriously smooth with a slight creaminess and then a fine drying finish. Flavour of woodmsmoke, coffee, dark malt. A case of this being a very good porter, that has smokiness layered through it, rather than a smoky beer that happens to be a porter. I can certainly see why it scores so highly.

Bomber, $5.99.  First of all, this has got to be one of the most attractive and elegant labels of any bottle Ive seen.  So point for that!  Pours dark brown, with a creamy, fine head.  Aroma is roasts, dark chocolate, and ashy smoke.  Balanced nose overall, nothing jumps out at you.  Palate is smooth, lightly carbonated, sporting a lighter-than-expected body.  Flavor starts with a hit of chocolate malt, layered nicely with roasts.  Espresso and smoke notes are present through the middle, leading into a bittersweet finish.  Overall, nothing to dramatic going on here, but a lot of nice flavors as well.  Reminds me of Stones version but just a bit smoother and less bitter.  Very good.
A typical porter by appearance.  Tons of campfire ash smoke in both aroma and flavor.  That smoke was way overdone.  A lesser dose would have made this a better beer.  A bit of a disappointment.

pours dark brown, nearly black. aroma is smoke, chocolate, dusty malt, herbal qualities. flavor is roasted malts with some mild smoke in the background. mid-bodied, mild bitterness and fading smoke in the end

from crackedkettle.com - pours a dark black beer under a fair and persistent dark beige foam; correct lacing leaved on the side of the glass; smokey notes come first soon followed by aromas of black chocolate and ashes; medium to full malt body, quite creamy mouthfeel and with a decent bitterness; a constant smokyness lasting long in a bitter aftertaste of ashes and cold coffee - very well-brewed and deeply drinkable

2009 bottle.  Deep mahogany pour with ruby highlights and a small white head.  The aroma has a really nice balance of smoke, cocoa, herbs and spices and brown sugar.   The flavor is also excellently balanced subtle smoke, cocoa, and a touch of spice.  Body is creamy, full with soft carbonation.

2009 vintage 22 oz. bottle- Pours charcoal black with a perfect head and excellent lacing. The flavor is smoky and malty, this beer is so much better than Stone smoked porter, which is crazy because I think Stone is a much better brewery. This is an almost perfect Porter, the aroma is the only weak point.

10 oz sample from bomber. 2009 vintage. Smoky, toasted malt aroma. Pours almost black with medium head, awesome lacing. Nice bitterness which lingers. Maybe a little thin, just a bit watery. Could have a bit more body. Excellent porter, despite these flaws.

2009.  Dark and slick in the glass and an oily whipped cream head.  Strong alder? smoked/burnt aroma.  Smoke character is so gentle, so persistent, so friendly.  It just hangs there and gets my attention without demanding it.  Evenly met by the dark and roast forward malt backbone, neither side competing.  Id cellar a bottle, but I hear the smoke goes away over time, who would want that?
2009 Bottle... Pours black with a thin white head... Aroma is smoke and beef jerky...Flavor is lots of dark chocolate, tobacco and smoke..Thin body and lots of carbonation.

22 oz. bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours near black with a small tan head.  Aroma of campfire smoke, wood, roasted malt, chocolate, burnt toast- very cool.  Flavor of smoked wood, chocolate, roasted malt, molasses, vanilla, hops.  Smoky, bitter, and roasty.  Good balance, as these often just seem like smoke over everything else.  Medium body.  This is a great smoked beer.
2009 bottle shared by phaleslu.  thanks peter!  pours a deep brown with a tan head.  tight lace.  smoke, camp fire, chocolate, roast, toast bread , molasses, and vanilla notes.  awesome stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2009 22oz. bottle, 2006 vintage.  Purchased from Bottleworks in Seattle in 2007 and cellared since that time.  Roasty, lightly sweet and nicely smoky aroma, notes of coffee, black bread, caramel, faint wood and dark chocolate.   Dark brown-black color with a lasting, fine tan head.  Flavor is roasty and sweet to start, some sugared coffee aspects, turning lightly fruity and bitter, the smoke and some faint bitterness coming though on the finish, along with suggestions of dark, dried fruits, toffee and chocolate.  Very smooth palate, the effervescence no doubt having mellowed somewhat but not to any detriment.  Body is medium-full.  Amazingly drinkable and refined.  Really nice.

Aroma of salty smoked ham, chocolate, coffee, and some burnt black malts. smoky ham dominates aroma
~Pours black with some dark garnet. The head is brown and creamy. Small but good head retention. 
~Smokey, woody, roasted chocolate malt flavor. Bitter roastiness. Balance in flavor leans more towards bitter malts than the smokiness. Good balance in flavor.
~Medium light bodied. Medium carbonation. No astringency. Lasting bitter malt finish. Dry.
~Good brew. Makes me wonder what this would taste like aged for a year or two. The body is a bit thinner than I would have liked. Very enjoyable smoked porter overall.

A solid and extremely smoky porter that could use some aging. The beer pours a nice black-brown with a healthy head, a pleasant surprise as I wasnt expecting much. It smells like a smokehouse that makes summer sausage and smoked salmon. This flavor and smell would probably smooth with age, but I know very little about cellaring. The taste is mostly smoke with some sweet chocolate or coffee, struggling to make it through the thick haze of smoke. I imagine cellaring for a long period would allow the other flavors to brighten up and smooth out the smoke. The feel is good, bubbly and mouth-coating.

Bottle from outwest somewhere in Colorado.  Pours a almost pitch black beer with a thin light tan head.  Aroma is soft smoky and malty.  Flavor is smoky with a light hop bite and a dry bitter finish.  nothing special here.  2008 bottle

acrid smoke character that dissapates into a muscatel flavor with touch of smoke. nice fresh malt flavor to this 2007 bottle the brew was like an english porter and light in body, for a porter that is. it was like an aged wine i suppose with just a bit of sugar.

Pours a coffee brown with a tan head. Smells of hickory wood chips, chocolate, coffee, apples, toffee and hops. Wow, nice carbonation taste is very smoky, almost like applewood smoked bacon, definite roasted malts as it warms, hops and warming alcohol in the finish, stellar beer. Id enjoy this on multiple occasions.
1999 draft at the Rare Beer Tasting at Wynkoop. Dark brown and filtered. Tasty brown ale with a lighter but recognizable smoke flavor. Lighter body and very easy to drink.
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text: Bomber.  2009 vintage.  Pours deep black with the thinnest of reddish-tan heads.  Aroma is very faint and hard to distinguish.  Some pepper, leather, and wood, perhaps?  Taste, however, is quite interesting.  Black pepper, tobacco, leather, all nicely blended and with a touch of licorice.  Mouthfeel is not heavy in the least, and the palate, though short-lived, is pleasant and does last and even produces a final hint of bitter chocolate as it lingers on the tongue.  Well done!

2008 Vintage enjoyed @ our cabin (seemed fitting in front of the woodburning stove with last years elk chili). Nose is sublime, smoky hardwood, hints of bitter chocolate. Taste is the smoky roasted malt and a really nice piney, pink peppercorn bitterness with just a fantastic mouthfeel. This bomber lasted about 2 minutes between a few of us. I was expecting it to be much more heavy and syrupy, but could have easily gone through another one. Outstanding.

On tap at Collins Pub.  Pours a deep brown black with a thin tan head.  Aromas of candy sugar and funk, in addition to the smoke, of course.  Smoke is the dominant taste, with some sugar and a bitter coffee finish.

Bottle. Pours deep brown with thick brownish white head. Aroma has grainy, slightly creamy malt scent, background is smokey - a woody, fine and controlled smoke scent. Aroma is tantalizing. Flavor is mild smoke and light bitterness, a perfect blend of the flavors of good tobacco and hearty rye bread. This is not for children folks. These are acquired tastes, and damn they are good. Light hop flavors and smokey malt roastiness in the finish. A great beer. Wish I had a keg all to myself for the next week. Where can I get a keg of this stuff?

Dark thin color from a bottle that cost me a lot of money.  I just had to mail order this beer and was not dissapointed.  I found the smoke flavor to be light.  A soft motor oil feel.  Some wood and carbonation.  Great with any barbeque.

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 25 Sep 2009) Black colour with frothy, beige head. Roasted, malty nose with dark bread, chocolate and a touch of smoke. Roasted, malty taste with notes of smoke, dark bread and well roasted coffee. Generous coffee bitterness in the finish. Slightly more than medium body, balanced sweetness. Great balance with lots of smoke, but it stills never takes over completely. Excellent beer.

Smooth jet-black body with a loose tan head. Rich aromas of smoky bacon and chocolate. Intense smoked malt flavor. Hop bite adds texture along with some raisin and toffee flavors that emerge after warming. Dry finish, clean but not too smoky. Unique and very good.

Clear copper color with an off white head. Mild to medium smoky meat n cheese aromas. Medium body. Lightly sweet pale malt flavor with mild smoke and cheese. Smoke brew lite. Draft@ Humpys.Earlier Rating: 8/16/2008 Total Score: 3.82007 bottling. Black with a frothy 2" head. Nice aroma is saline smoked salmon and beef jerky. Medium body. Good porter flavors of dry blackened malts with smoked meat and charred camp fire wood. Classic smoked beer here.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Taste is wood, ash, smoke, and chocolate with a surprising (and enjoyable) peppery finish. Smooth, full-bodied mouth feel with low carbonation. Outstanding beer.

Bomber. Opaque black and dark with thick going thin and disappearing light brown head. Roasted and smokey aroma that also consists of muted floral notes behind a more predominantly sweet roasty chocolate. tastes of chocolate sweetness with roasty wood ending sour and chocolaty. Smooth, clean, easy to drink, but very complex. Salty alcoholic notes throughout the whole beer. A real drinking porter!

22 oz bottle shared with a friend and from liquidsolutions. Pours a nice dark opaque pour, near black with some brownish lighter notes on the corners. A nice brown head that dissipates to a film and clings to the corners. Aromas are good smokiness, heavy meaty jerky smell, salty and marinated meat, light woody ashy smoke as well. A medium bodied porter preaches meaty smoke and ashy wood, a lighter roasted malt gives way to a good smoked malt which is a style I love. Lighter feel, emphasizing smoke is a good example of the style. Faint bitterness, largely a wonderful example of a smoky dark beer. A decent roastiness underneath leads to a good balance. Smokiness steals the show, meaty and lightly ashy.

2008 Vintage. A real WTF moment when I finally noticed I had never properly pounded out some notes for this beer.

Appearance: Pours out a dark brown, near black body with some ruby-hued edges and a topped by a frothed, beige head.

Smell: A distinct aroma with its alder wood aspect thats always suggestive of high quality smoked meats. Also some roasty and unsweetened chocolate notes as well as a waft of dark fruits.

Taste: Though the smoked alder wood is full and present in the flavor, it doesnt totally squash the beers other characteristics. Roasty, sweetish malts with some subtle chocolate tones and even milder hint of decaffeinated coffee. Touch of dark fruitiness in the background. Slight clean bitterness present. The smokiness remains beyond the drying finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Medium carbonation. Fairly smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: With its relatively lighter body and good balance, this one is just that much more drinkable and it can become quite difficult not to grab a few bombers and drink yourself into a stupor on the couch. Its a beer Im always happy to have regardless of vintage or time of year it happens to be.

660ml bottle (Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam)
Very dark brown, large dark doughy head. fairly subdued aroma, dry, lightly smoked, and a touch burnt. Quite lively carbonation, crisp palate, smooth too. Some burtness in the retronasals, more than smokiness. Taste is malt dominated, a burnt roast, with a little bite of astringency. Smokey phenols seem to reinforce the burntness rather than stand on their own. Finish is certainly interesting, theres a touch more smoke than the taste, but also some drying ashiness, a delicate little hoppy bite, and lasts pleasantly long. No chance of 6.5% ever making its way through the flavours in this one - gluggable! And yup, this was one thirst-quenching brew!
4 oz pour at the Oregon Brewers Festival in July 09.  Nice smokey palate and malty balance.  Extremely good throughout.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2009 1. On Tap at the Falling Rock Tap House, Denver 13/10/2008
Smoky roast aroma. Small tan head. Black and smooth on the palate with some alcohol present. A little rich. Crisp and slightly dry lasting smoked finish.
2. From the Bottle at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting, Wynkoop Brewery 25/09/2009 (1999 Vintage)
Big smoked and roast aroma. Beige head. Black strong in alcohol rich and a little sweet on the palate with a hint of dryness in a crisp coffee and fruit finish.
3. From the Bottle at the Denver Rare Beer Tasting, Wynkoop Brewery 25/09/2009 (2008 Vintage)
Smoked aroma. Yellow head. Black and smooth on the palate with some alcohol present. A little dryness and bitterness in a crisp roast finish.

A black beer with a nice 1 finger head. Aroma was roasty, & smokiness that comes out more as it warms up. Taste had a slightly burnt roastiness, & was slightly ashy, almost like a campfire in my glass/mouth. Very smooth & mildly creamy that left a nice lacing in the glass.This would be the perfect beer to drink next to a campfire on a cold night.
On tap at the brewery.  So good I bought a bottle there.  Dark and clear, with a modest head.  Very smoky, even in the aroma.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Bottle. Black pour with deep beige head on top. Nice smokey, roasty aroma. Tastes smokey obviously, with hints of malt, coffee. Very interesting beer but one is quite enough for me.

Awesome brew and many thanks to JD at work for sneaking me one of these.  Everything youd want in a smoked Porter.  Black with a nice medium head to it.  Aroma is obviously smoky and roasted.  Same notes dance across your palate.  Mild astringency but not nearly enough to damage the overall experience of sampling this little gem.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2014 re-rate 04/14  Dropped from  4.1....  drank a 2012.  this appears to be a beer that age doesnt help.  2012 wasnt bad but lack of hops took away some depth......Re rate 01/14. I have collected a couple verticals of this since my first rate 4.5 years ago. Drank a 2009 in 01/14.  Leaving rating as is. Bu after 4.5 years I got little to no smoke hops or carbonation. Still good. Trying a 2011 next
02/14.  2011 version.  better than 2009 but not as good as fresh.  lacks the complexity smoke of the original.




Found in Dillon CO while on vacation.

Black w/tan head.

I did not really notice the smoke tast, but thiw was a great beer.

chocolate, coffee flavor 

wonderful; whish I could find Alaskan brews in texas

Bottle @ GBBF 2009. A black colored beer, with a thick foamy dark beige head. The aroma of smoked malts. some sweet, and bitter, notes of chocolate. The taste of dark fruits, a little thin but there are smoked malts and bitter notes. A little sweet. The aftertaste is bitter smoked with a little sweet.

Appears black, nice three finger tan head. 

Scent of strong wood and some very light porter characteristics.

Taste is too strong on the smoke at first, gets a bit better and more complex as it warms.

Mouth is thin with medium carbonation.

In the range of smoked porters, Id rather have an East End or Stone, but this is still worthy once it warms a bit.
Bottle from GBBF, 2009. Pours jet black nice odours of chocolate, burnt sugars, coffee. Flavours of coffee, dark chocolate, licorice and smoke. Good woodsmoke finish.
heavy smoke and meat in nose, smooth on the palate, and flavor lingers - not a bad thing
Bottle @ Cuvee de Castleton release. Nice smoked porter. Would like to see how this ages. Dark pour with light head. The aroma and flavor are of malt and smoke.

Bottle. Pours black with small head. Nose is heavy smoke, sweet malt, some bitter and floral hops, coffee and dark chocolate. Flavor is a well balanced smoke and coffee mixed with sweet and burnt malt.

Hoo-ahh!  I could drink a LOT of these!  Purchased from a gas station (!) in Point Roberts, WA (where?), this was a great find.  It poured a brown head of lesser size, into a very dark and impenetrable glassful of delight.  Aroma was subdued but hinted of malt, however the taste was where the real business began.  Fabulous but understated smokiness underlaid with coffee and chocolate.  Mouthfeel was smooth and easy to drink, as was the aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours black with a decent size foamy tan head. Aroma heavy on the smoke. Also chocolate, and coffee aroma is in the mix. Flavor is very nice. Smoky, but balances nicely with the chocolate and slight hint of black coffee. Very nice beer.

22 oz bottle 2008.  Rich dark brown in the glass with a lasting creamy head.  Roasted malt, coffee, and smoke on the nose.  Cold its sharp and spicy/bitter with a touch of hops.  As it warms the sweetness and smoke is more prevalant, but not overpowering at all.  Some dark fruit and chocolate appear.  Yummy.

Bottled. Aroma has coffee roast and smoked bacon, very much like the Schlenkerlas. Black coloured beer with a beige, lasting head. The taste is slightly sweet, has some bitterness, roast and smoked bacon. Medium bodied, some carbonation. Outstanding.

Bottle courtesy of zathrus13.  Poured black with a thick frothy head and big sheets of lace on the glass.  Lots of smoke in the nose also hard roasted malt.  Pretty thin body with lively carbonation.  Flavor is smoked bacon  and slightly sour lots of roasted notes and some anise coming thru.  Finishes roasted with some wood notes.

Complements of alldaydrinker who was kind enough to swap a CL Rosso for an 05 of this. Pours a near-opaque black colour (a bit of ruby edges when held to the light) with a thin, but lasting tan head that leaves spotty lacing. The nose is of orasted chocolate malt, red grapes, dates, and of course, highly pronounced hickory-like smoke. The flavour is intensely smokey and wonderfully mellow. Notes of bacon dominate throughout, with roasted malts, lightly roasted coffee and dark chocolate coming through moreso in the finish, which is medium in duration. Even before the smoke hits though, there is a moment where suggestions of malted milk balls is distinctive, and delicious! The palate is silken with soft carbonation and a full body that coats tooth and gum. The aging process, though beneficial to the smoothness of the palate and melding of flavours, must have also cut away from the hop presence significantly, as there are almost none to be detected. Mild citrus possibly. Either way, this is an outstanding brewski. Thanks Jeff!

Got this in a trade from AlldayDrinker, cheers Jeff thanks for the 2005. The color is a dark black with some light brown on the edges as you tilt the glass. The initial pour has a thick tan head but it fades as quick as the pour. You can really smell the smoked  malt blended with the chocolate in the aroma. The initial sip has so much smoke with the right amount of blended chocolate and roasted malt. There is a small hop bitterness, but nothing distinguishable. This particular beer has been aging for 4 years so that may have diminished the hop flavors as well as some other flavor the brewer was going for. Overall it has great carbonation and is balanced but i wish i had it when it was first released.

One of my all-time favorite smoked porters. I remember the first time I tried it at home, and my wife asked for a taste. SHe wrinkled her nose, contorted her face, and I told her to spit it back in. Thats how good this beer is. The only way I can describe it is like the taste of charcoal briquettes after a steak has been cooked over them. Tasty!

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 22 oz. bottle (2007 Vintage).  This one was a gift from my Dad, so "Thanks Dad".  Dark black pour with a little head.  Essentially a very good porter with a nice, balanced smoky flavor.  Not as overwhelming as something like Smoke Jumper.  The smoke flavor is pleasant and pairs well with the porter.  A great and certainly unique beer.  Love it...I had the opportunity to try a 3 year old bottle today (11/14/2009, so that would make it a 2006 bottle).  I cannot believe how prominent the smoked sausage/bacon flavor is and how that actually makes for a good beer.  Really amazing stuff.

(bottle - 22 oz - 2008 vintage) Dark black pour with a fluffy tan head. Aroma is smoky and roasty with a good amount of malts and chocolate. Flavor is quite smoky but not overpowering. Blends well with the chocolate and the malts and leaves a light smoke finish.

Bottle shared with joergen and bager. Pours an opaque black with small light brown head. Low sweetness. Perfectly balanced between smoke aromas and malts. Hints of grilled sausages. Some maltyness. Álso hints of chocolate and coffee. Nice smooth mouthfeel.

22 oz from South Bay Drugs.  I must say that smoked beers are not my style, but this one is enjoyable.  Pours dark black with an oily tan head.  Nose is smokey as hell- campfire, band-aid, charcoal, with sweet roast, and a dark chocolate behind the smoke.  Flavor is similar, but not as assertively smokey.  After the smoke subsides somewhat I get the sweetness, and the smoke actually becomes complimentary to some of the sweet flavors in this beauty.  Silky and medium-bodied with a lingering chocolatey-ness.  Enjoyable smoked, which before this one I thought was a contradiction.
probably the greatest dark beer ive ever had, except for alaskans baltic porter.  aging causes the alder smokiness to give way to more vanilla notes... try it new, and aged.  a winner every time.

Thanks to MrBunn, I get to try this. Been eyeballing it for awhile. Dark brown to almost black pour with not much head. Coffee,ash, smoke and brown sugar are present, with the taste being pretty much the same, except  the smokeiness stands out a bit more. Finish reveals a hint of vanilla extract. Good.

Bottle with thanks to Mike.  Pours a dark brownneith a thin head and aromas of coffee, smoke and sugar.  Flavor has heavier smoke and a more roasted malt presence with a little bit of vanilla or cream.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bomber from South Bay Drugs. Pours a dark brown to black with a thin off-white head that settles quickly. Aroma is smoky and malty with notes of chocolate, ripe dark fruit, some light roasted coffee. Flavor is malty and smoky with notes of chocolate, light roasted coffee, some hints of caramel and toffee with just the slightest hint of ripe dark fruit and vanilla. Generally medium body with a pleasing malty, smoky finish.

Thanks Shawntana.  Brown with some ruby highlights and a tan head.  Predictable aroma of smoked malts, smoked malts and perhaps more smoked malts.  All I know is this one smelled pretty good.  Perhaps some light chocolate in there as well.  Taste of those same smoked roasted malts with mild chocolate and a touch of sweetness.  Smooth and tasty!
this is a great smoked beer! lots of that hickory smoke flavor along with the roasted coffee and chocolate malty flavors of a great porter. i have to get this every year!

Bottle courtesy of cmr1517:  Pour was a dark black with no head.  Nose was pure liquid smoke with only a hint of chocolate malt and a bit of ash.  Medium bodied brew with flavors of fing SMOKE!  Im shocked as to the love for some of these supposed smoked brews that dont taste anything like true smoked product.  Damn near every one of them tastes like a bottle of fake-ass liquid smoke and it pisses me off.  I know plenty about smoking shit...well except malt that is, and it drives me bat-shit insane.  Stop it with the smoking of beer!!!!!!!

2008 version. Black beer with light brown head. Smoky aroma, wet wood, chocolate, roasted malt. Vanilla like roasty taste with a nice bitterness in the end, the wood notes are lovely, bringing whisky into mind, the smokyness is there too but much more subdued here than I thought. I loved this beer.

(2008 bottle from Springs Liqour Outlet in Colorado Springs). Pours a black color. Medium tan head. Strong smoked flavor. Strong smoke flavor with light alcohol. Long duration. Good lacing. Moderate carbonation.

Bottle, one of several very nice bottles Alaskanwarren sent back with me from Denver. Thanks Brian! Shiny black, lots of fine tan bubbles slowly coming out of solution. Husky, nutty roast nose, a bit of leafy smoke. All the smokey dark intensity of high-percent cocoa chocolate, but with a much shorter palate presence.  Fine textured, delicate, and well-balanced. Smoke can so easily become too much of a good thing: this is just right.

Bottle from Bottleworks. Pours a super dark brown with frothy mocha colored head.  Smoke dominates the incredible aroma but you can pick up hints of caramel and vanila malts.  Smoke dominates the flavor as well, and this is a bit fizzier than I wouldve liked.  Okay finish on the tongue.

Tan foamy head, full dark body with smokey aroma not unlike liquid smoke.  Very savory and inviting.  Obvious smokey taste that made you want something to eat. Unique type of beer for me and very good. The one we drank was a 2006 yr.

The Alaskan Smoked Porter was one of the very first beers I purchased when I arrived in Seattle.  Its fame had trickled into Colorado through scattered channels, and bottles of it were everywhere in Seattle - about as ubiquitous as hipsters, but a little less judging.  Its a predictably subterranean dark beer.  Youd be better off using echo location to peer inside your glass.  The nose immediately comes off as smoky, even burnt, redolent with charcoal, seared steak and mesquite wood.  Im immediately hungering for a medium-rare ribeye, but dinners still lingering in the stomach, so I keep feasting on the porter.
