The second sampling of the aroma introduces more eats, and fewer incinerated smells.  Cumin, coffee, a hint of raisin make appearances.  I wade into the beer, now up to my mouth, catching jerky spices, black pepper, cumin, cured meat and enough raisin to balance against the spicy and savory flavors.  The palate is well weighted for this heavy flavor profile, burly enough to carry the assemblage of tastes on its mouthfeel palanquin with confidence.  It is a perfectly drinkable beer, and I think a welcome introduction to Alaskan Brewerys capabilities.  I eagerly await the 2009 batch of this affordable, densely flavored porter.

06 Bottle from dirtymartini, thanks Larry.  Poured a deep brown/black color with an inch and a half, dense beige head that slowly receded to a thin bubbly layer and left some nice webby lacing.  Aroma of smoke, some brown sugar glazed meat, chocolate, light roast, some charred wood, and a bit of light fruitiness.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry leads into a light bakers chocolate and a light woodiness followed by some sweet (brown sugar) meatiness paired with a moderate smokiness and some soft undertones of vanilla that finishes with a lightly dry woodiness and a bit of lingering smoke.  Low carbonation and moderate mouthfeel with a pleasing dryness on the finish.  Overall, a very enjoyable beer.  The smoke could have been a bit more assertive, and I imagine it was when it was fresh.  I am glad this is available in Colorado now, its a nice beer.

500 mL bomber. 2008 version. Pours a deep brown almost black with a thin, tan cap with good retention. Aroma of smoked bacon, barbecue pork, unsweetened chocolate. Taste is meaty with charred bacon bits, cocoa, molasses, and dry hoppy bitterness showing through in the finish. Nice medium body. Creamy on the palate. Very interesting.

Poured almost black with a nice head on it.  The aroma was nice and smokey with hints of chocolate, very interesting and probably the best part of the beer.  The flavor was chocolatey, malty, with just a hint of smoke, it doesnt really come through on flavor.  Very nice and very drinkable, something different.

Pours dark brown, almost black, with a sparse off-white head that has no retention or lacing to speak of. Aroma of cedar smoke and sweet malt; flavor develops smoked and roasted malt, slightly oily finish with a hint of bitter chocolate. Fairly rich mouthfeel, only slightly carbonated.
I love the smoke usage on this beer. A nice toasty aroma with some coffe and smoke. Pure smoke, no meat, no bacon, just burnt toast and smoked malts. Smooth and rich and very well balanced.

Bouteille de 22 oz partagée lors dune dégustation Ratebeer Montréal chez moi. Arôme: Odeur de fumée. Apparence: La couleur est noire opaque. Présence dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fumée avec une pointe de café. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Faible effervescence en bouche. Présence de fumée en arrière goût. (Rating #2336)

Cant believe I havent rated this but tried another just for the rating (twist my arm).  Deep mahogany pour with a solid khaki head that left a fair amount of lacing.  Aroma is chocolate, molasses and pork butt.  Flavor is similar...although the cocoa, brown sugar, smoke, ash, and maple syrup dominate the more subtle bacon flavor.  Medium mouthfeel...not nearly as aggressive as Left Hand Smoke Jumper but good.

Really enjoy this porter. Got a case right when they were released and Im drinking the last one right now. Its hard for me to recall but I do think the brew has improved with its aging. 

A smooth flavor with very little hop taste. Its got a light aroma and a great color. Pretty good mouthfeel to it. The smokey flavor is quite a joy in itself.

Would definitely recommend and Ill hopefully be picking up some more soon.
Dark brown with tan head.  Intense sweet smokey aroma with a taste to match.
black with light tan head.  smoky sweet roasted malt.  flavor is very smokey and earthy and is a little bitter.

Top notch smoked porter, very famous for a reason... Black with a nice head, ok retention... Aroma is smoky, peaty, much like a campfire in smell and taste... Much more smoke than the Stone Smoked Porter, i like this better... Smoke makes beer better...

(2004 version) Deep, dark brown with a molasses underpinning. Nice smokiness jumps off the glasss. Redolent of sweet, Southern smokhouse with a roasty backdrop. Dominant smokey flavor. A hearty winter brew fit for cold nights and enjoying the outdoors or Alaskan wilderness.

First off, Put out the fire this bitch is SMOKEY! I would like to give a shout out to Sparky27 aka Easy E 4 sending this brewski to Gabe aka G- money aka ur pants. This brew is black as the STREET! motor oil like(color wise)...didnt really have that much head sorta thin.....really liked the Aroma tho...very smokey like a camp fire smell... maplish/brown sugary flavor gave the taste of a up up up north flava flavor! Palate was a med medium one...not to thin but sorta thicky thick...I recommend this brew to anyone that likes the SMOKEYNESS of the NORTH! again thanks G-money n Easy E! 

Lata.
2008 Bottle. Pours a coffee brown with a lighter brown head. Nose is full of smoky malt. Flavors are nice mild hickory smoke. Notes of cola too. Nicely carbonated.

enjoyed during the opening round of March Madness 09. Deep dark brown body with a fluffy tan head and small web-like lacing, looks fantastic. Huge, agressive aroma of smoked, salted pork and campfire. Scents of crackers and tobacco add some depth. Malty and smokey with a light sweetness on the tongue. Medium to heavy bodied. Generous flavors of burnt wood, earthy peat and smoked meat. A bitter hop flavor comes forward and gives way to a mild chocolate aftertaste. I love a big smokey beer and this was better than I imagined it would be. Surprisingly drinkable for the style as well. Paired rather nicely with a slice of cheesecake topped with fresh strawberries."

From a bomber. Beer is very dark brown, clear. Head is initially largish, light brown, frothy. Diminishes mostly into a fluffy ring with a small centralized petri dish skim.

The aroma is malty with heavy notes of roasted grain, lighter notes of dark coffee; Moderate notes of salty smoky meat and campfire.

The flavor is moderately bitter, lightly acidic, trace sweet with a long, lightly/moderately bitter finish. Genuine camp fire retronasal aroma is pleasing. 

The body is medium, the texture is watery/velvety and the carbonation is average/fluffy.

Enjoyable, plotting on trying this out in the chili later.

22oz. Rather dark brown almost black pour. Not a huge dark cream colored head. It did last a while though. Roasty malt, peat some bitter chocolate aromas. Tastes quite similarly. Earthy, peaty malt with quite a bit of coffee and smoke. Some hints of chocolate throughout. Medium bodied lively enough to not be creamy. The bittering is what sets this apart from just an average or good porter. Nice roast finish. Drinkability is pretty good, the bite takes away from this just a bit. Worth trying.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: 22oz bottle. Pours dusky brown with a long lasting tan head that leaves a nice ring of foam that sticks around for the duration. Very smokey nose, with some pine needles, oak and caramel. Flavor up front is quite roasty with a smooth full body and very nice mouthfeel. Finishes with a wood smoked bacon note. This is incredibly tasty, one of the best if not the best smoked beer Ive had.

2006 651 ML Bottle.  Pours a black color with a decent tan head that lasts.  Taste is of smoke, wood, caramel, roasted malt and chocolate.  Similar enough aroma.  Very tasty, easy to drink and overall enjoyable.
really a wonderful beer worthy of every drop of praise .. . outstanding balance .. . full and rich and smooth, so drinkable and not overly done, just right! .. . Thanks Thirsty!!!

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2009 First off I am not a smoked fan, so my rating might be skewed. This beer confirmed my general dislike of the stly, even If I could appreciate it’s well balanced nature. Lots of smoke on this one and I struggled to finish the half pint. Wouldn’t go back for more of this.
Relatively light smoking, but very big malt with coffee and chocolate and a bit of fruit. Great palate, intensely smooth. Very well balanced and impressive.

2008 "vintage" 22oz bottle. Pours a basically black body with a thin, khaki brown head that leaves a petri dish, chunk lacing on the surface and a soft, but thick lace on the glass. The lacing actually expands on the surface when I touch the glass...pretty cool reaction. Aroma is big meaty smoked malts. A light amount of porter-like chocolates and roasts, but mainly a smokey campfire aroma. Flavor is very solid. Lots of initial smokiness with a big body. Light, but balancing amounts of milk chocolate and roasted grains come in before a slow, dry, woody finish. Some hops creep their way into the finish as well, but mainly a big, but not too big smoke finish. Really nice. Never gets overpowering. Palate is full with a light tickle of carbonation. Overall, a very impressive smoked porter. Great balance between a big campfire and milk chocolate porter-like taste.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2009 2008 vintage, 22 oz. bottle purchased at Food Emporium in Everett, WA.  Pours a VERY dark brown, bordering on black, with a light brown/tan head.  Flavor: Coffee, smoke (duh), and chocolate.  Im usually not a porter fan, but this one is damn good.
Poured black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate, spice, and smoke. Smoke flavor with some chocolate. Smoke flavor present but not overwhelming.
Crushed with Carythedude and Jakebra. Smokey, chocolate aroma. Ham and bacon in the flavor, with some liquid smoke. Velvet mouthfeel. Pretty awesome.

Bottle 2008 upon arrival to Anchorage.  Pours black into the glass with a tan head.  Aroma is of burnt rubber with coffee and chocolate notes.  Smoke is very apparent in the flavor, but very well balanced.  A great beer for a cold night.
Crushed with Jakebra and Honkeybra at the Falling Rock.  Smoked ham and bacon!  Awesome!  Nose is better than the flavor, but no real complaints.  Excellent smoked.

Pours an opaque dark reddish brown. Very dark brown head that dissipates quickly. The aroma is a little smokey and chocolatey, also plums and burnt sugar, a bit gamey. Smooth and thick bodied for a porter. The taste is creamy and smooth with the alcohol not at all noticeable at 6.5. Sweet and almost tart at first sip. Good bitternress, the smoke isnt as pronounced as I thought it would be. Thats probably a good thing. There are notes of dark chocolate, coffee, alder wood and dark fruit with a bitter, woody aftertaste. The bitterness and woody flavor dominate this one with good carbonation adding a spicy quality.

Thin brown head of fine dense bubbles.  Nice smoky aroma with some rich malts, teriyaki sauce and some spicy beef jerky.  Color is a very dark brownish black.  Surprisingly dry for a porter.  Lots of dark roasted grains, more smoke, light malts and some bitterness.  Quite zippy in the mouth.  Body is a little bit thinner than expected.  Quite tasty and flavorful though.  Finishes roasty and smoky but not overly smoky.  Just the right amount.  A damn fine porter.

08 bottle courtesy the Cheeseman. Pours blackish red with a beautiful cascading tan head. Aroma is smoked salmon, smoked malt and slight caramel aroma, very complex and interesting. Taste is smooth malt with hints of smoked salmon and smoked malt with a touch of caramel. Finishes dry and clean. A stunningly good smoked beer.

UPDATED: APR 3, 2010 22oz Bottle...  Poured dark brown, almost black with a frothy, light brown head.  Smoked grains and chocolate and a meaty character.  Well carbonated and a little dryness to it.  Smoked flavors were dominant allowing it to be pretty robust and charcoal/BBQ notes.  Finished a little sweeter with maybe vanilla

The smell is of hot dogs fresh off the grill!  Very interesting...  as with all smoked beer, I drink this wondering - is beer supposed to taste like meat?

The beer leaves you with a mild bitterness in your mouth.

One of the best smoked beers, maybe so.  Just not my cup of tea!

2007 vintage 22 oz bomber.  Poured a dark brown color with a two finger, tan head that lingered for quite a while.  The aroma was smoky, with notes of chocolate and meat present.  The flavor was burned malt, bitter chocolate, caramel and heavy smoke.  The body was medium/full.  This was a bit aggressive for my taste, but, overall, this is an excellent beer.

Poured from a 22oz bomber (2007 vintage) and served in an English pint glass.  The beer poured a dark brown, almost black, with a one-finger thick head of creamy tan foam that settled into a lasting ring.  The aroma included a note of mellow campfire smoke woven in milk chocolate.  Simple and straightforward, but still smells great.  The flavor consisted of ashy, charred wood, bittersweet chocolate, a hint of dark fruit, and a touch of caramel.  The smoke was heavy and aggressive at first sip, but this sensation subsides, allowing the smoke to meld with the other flavors as the beer warmed.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied and chalky.  Lightly carbonated.  The smoke is not subtle, yet it doesnt overwhelm the entire beer.  Very well done!

bottle: 2008  Very smokey wood smell that over powers the malt.  First taste was intensely smoked malt with bitter chocolate and coffe.  My first impression was "this tastes like a fire place", but the more I sip the more enjoyable... yes quite enjoyable.  Ends with a bit of bitterness and a slight smoke flavor.  I thought the smoke flavor was too much at first, but found it much more pleasant as I drank.

Pours about as dark a brown as you can get without being black with a thin beige head.  Aroma is smoke with a few roasty malt notes coming through. Flavor is lots of smoked malt, a little sweet caramel and roasted malts. I think this is one of those that you either really like or you really dont.

Found a bottle of the 06 and decided to give it a whirl.  Colour... black with a very thin tan head. Nose... smoked soy??  Palate... What the...?!! Phenolic! Band-Aid central! Is this a cross between Lagavulin and Dallas Dhu?  On the back of the palate theres smoked unagi, salt and brine(??). I have had the 07 and 08 and REALLY loved them. What might have happened here? Poor storage? Im stumped.

Pours dark brown with a tan head.  Aroma of smoke, roasted malt and coffee, caramel.  Taste is very smoked with lots of roasted malt, some sweetness.  Finish is dry and has a little bitterness.  Mouth is a little more than full bodied, little carbonation.

A- Pours an opaque brown/black hue, head is two fingers of tan, creamy goodness that is surprisingly sustaining, fair lacing on the glass
S- Nose is roasty and toasty malts, very coffee-forward with heavy tones of smoke, hints of caramel, chocolate, and butter as well
T- Initial taste is mostly subtle coffee and chocolate malts, nice smokiness and a touch of roast, finish is sweet malts with slight bitter hops
M- Medium-bodied ale, watery texture, slightly under-carbonated
D- Nicely balanced porter that is easy-to-drink and just in that session range, this is a solid Porter that does many things good

22 oz. bottle.

Pours a dark black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma is very smokey, however not overly intense.  Very rich flavor of dark malts and smoke, with hints of coffee and chocolate as well.  The finish is almost all smoke.  

This can be enjoyed by sipping all night, or used in cooking as well.  Ive used this many times in making caribou pot roasts in the crockpot.  They even have a recipe on their website, which is delicious.

I was informed that this beer has won more medals at the Great American Beer Festival than any other beer, quite an accomplishment.

Bottled 651ml. Vintage 2007. Courtesy of DuffMan. Appearance: It pours a dark brown beer with a beautiful mocha head. Nice lacework. Aroma: Rather smoky. A lot smokier than Stone Smoked Porter for example. Hints of ash, blue cheese and caramel. Very pleasant. Quite a lot of roasted malt. Flavor and palate: Strong smokiness. Very low carbonation. Smooth. Medium bodied. Hints of blue cheese, ash, basil, vanilla and marshmallows. Salty. Very subtle despite the strong smokiness. Wonderful strong dry finish reminiscent of smoke and ash. Overall impression: A very good Smoked Porter. Thanks a lot DuffMan!

Very nice beer. Served cold from 22 oz. bottle. Pours black with a very creamy off-white head. Very strong smokey aroma, rich flavor, hints of chocolate, coffee, and caramel. Finish is all smoke and a hint of bitterness. Very enjoyable porter.
Dark with garnet highlights with an ok tan head.  Intense smoke aromas.  Good with some cheese and crackers.  Good smoked malts add complex and rich flavors.

Bottle, 2008.  Rich, smoky, robust porter.  Nose of wood, earth, smoke, coffee and slight toast.  Mouthfeel is slightly acidic, burnt on the toungue.  Additional chocolate, espresso, carmel, smokeand slight pepper in the flavor.  Finish is lingeringly smoky and bitter.

Bottle, 2008. A beautiful marriage between a full-bodied robust porter and a Bamburg smoked beer only with a touch ashier smoke. Nose of campfire and chocolate, roasty, some caramel, some earthy hops in there. Ashy/earthy smoke. Flavor is rich with chocolate, roasty, campfire smoke, earthy malt, with a touch of acidity from the combination roast malts and smoke. Restrained hop bitterness towards the finish. Med to full body, fairly lush in the mouth despite the slightly evident acidity. Excellent.

2008 GABF. Aroma of almost a bamberg style smoked malt. Clear dark amber brown with small white head. Moderate grain astringency with roast and dark carmelized malts and light wood and smoke Very Tasty!

All the usual suspects - deep burnt malt backbone, near-burnt caramel, chocolate et al.  What really stood out to me was how great the smoke and wood came through and complimented the various accents of this complex drink without being too aggressive and overpowering.

Bomber, 2008.  Pours a normal porter color with a small off-white head.  Aroma is pure camp fire.  Beautiful smoky, woody, ashy aroma.  I had this on tap and my memory was it was pure bacon/ham, in a good way, but this is more camp fire to me from the bottle.  I also remember this being smokier on tap.  Anyways, a nice chocolate flavor is also present and some general roastiness.  This is all very well blended and melded.  I can appreciate a subtly smoked beer, like Stone Smoked Porter, but sometimes I crave an intensely smoky experience so Im glad this fits the bill.  Flavor is smoked chocolate, woody, grainy, phenolic, and super smooth.  This beer is great.  I really like how the smoke element is seemingly perfectly integrated in all aspects.  I wish this were available here.

22oz bottle. Poured very dark, looks like a little bit of brown peeking through. Nice smokey, roasty aroma. Very easy to drink, slight smokiness and a hint of coffee maybe. Very good, my first Alaskan SP in years.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 2008 bottle.  Pours a deep black with a large creamy deep tan head that left wonderful lacing.  Aroma of chocolate, roasted malt, smoked Gouda, caramel and nuts.  Flavor of smoked meats, earthy, caramel, sweet malty notes, toffee and chocolate.  Smoke is not overdone but instead balanced nicely with the sweet malts and touch of hope.

500ml bottle, 2007 edition.  Ive been eager to try this beer for years, being a huge Smoked beer fan.  Pours a thick, deep black with a smoked malt aroma.  The smoke is very present in the beer as well, very nice.  Somewhere in between medium and full-bodied.  Some chocolate and coffee flavors.  Some light sandy hop balance.  This is an awesome, world class beer.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2013 Re-rate 4/13: Bottle sample at a tasting at my place. Thanks zvikar. Black with light brown head. Great aroma of smoked meat and roastiness. Flavor is smokey, roasty and a bit sweetish. Finishes bitter and burnt. Medium to full-bodied. Great. 8/4/7/4/15=3.8

(11/1/08) Draught at Fathers Office in Santa Monica. Very dark brown color with a light brown head. Aroma of campfire. Sweet and smoky flavor with some BBQed meat, burnt wood, malt and some caramel. Medium-bodied. 7/4/7/3/14=3.5
I will trust the mob on this one. Very smoky. Taste of whitefish and campfire. Not my style. Im sure its good. Just not for me.

Bottles, 2007 one night, 2008 the next. Quite similar even with a years difference between them. Both are up front with smoked, salty meats, though the 2008 also finishes this thought with some sharper campfire smoke. Both have a milky, milk chocolaty maltiness that shines through more in the 2007, creating a greater balance with the smoke, though in the 2008, the smoke dominance is more interesting and lively with the campfire notes and a tangier, sweeter feel from the meat smokes. Long sentence. I did feel that the smoke and the milkiness in the 2007 were both solid qualities in their own right, but didnt seem to want much to do with each other, so the 2008 with its more dominant and interesting smokiness wins out. Tasty regardless. Numbers from the fresh batch.

2008 vintage.  Pours clear dark brown, almost black, with a puffy one-finger khaki head, good lacing.  Smells of smoke with some molasses, apple, and coffee.  Medium, crisp body.  BBQ smoke flavor, reminds me of mesquite, with notes of espresso, dark chocolate, some subtle fruit flavors, and minerals.  Slightly bitter pine and coffee aftertaste.  Well balanced and drinkable.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2009 2007 bottle courtesy of my Secret Santa!  Pours black with a thick tan head.  Aroma of smoked meats and roasted malt.  Flavor is sweet initially with smokey meats and oak in the finish.  Very nice smoked, even with a year of age.  
8/4/8/4/15 (3.9/5)

1/16/09: I got to try the 2008 version of this.  Nice and smoky with TONS of smoked meats.  Smooth palate, very drinkable.  This is an awesome beer and I underrated it the first time around.
8/4/9/5/17 (4.3/5)

2008 vintage, pitch black color, with a tan-colored head, leaving some laces, nice smoked bacon nose, with some canned smoked mussels and smoky beechwood, not as strong as a Schlenkerla on the smoky side, with a nice roasted smoky malt note, with a hint of black coffee and a dark bitter chocolatey aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a roasted, chocolate malt, mild smoked ham, beechwood character with some roasted coffee bean, dark coffee, burnt toast flavors, with a black bitter chocolatey, spicy liquorice accent, leading towards a mochaish, smoky, roasty bitterness finish.

2008 version. The aroma is awesome!  A damp hardwood smoke.  A deep brown pour with the brown thick head.  Flavor is rich, smoky with coffee and chocolate.  Not a one dimensional brew, roasty, smoky, portery, great.
Dark maroon with thin white head.  Aroma of subtle campfire.  Rich smoke throughout, especially in the finish, but it hides the porter to a degree.  Still a nice one.

On tap at Fathers Office Culver City. One finger head above a deep brown, almost black body. Good retention and very nice lacing. Chocolate aromas are detected behind the smokiness that was like sitting in front of a burning log in a fireplace. The smoke was even stronger on the palate, like biting into that log after the fire has gone out. But in a good way, really. Roasted coffee and coca are the strongest flavors. Medium body, pleasant malty aftertaste that lingered.
Brown black pour with a tannish head. Aromas of chocolate malt. Very smoky flavors with a mild hop accent. Medium body with a decent finish. Not a bad beer.

Off white tan head. Very dark black in color. Nice looking beer. This beer has a nice smoke/chocolate/ and coffee aroma. The beer smells excellent. I am getting more of the chocolate and sweet malt aroma. Nice chocolate and ash taste. Ah, the smoke is extremely nice. There is some chocolate, coffee, and sweet malt taste. I appreciate the the smoke more than anything. A great porter, but to call it a smoke is a bit misleading. This misses out on the clear focus of smoke/leather/ and ash. I love this as a porter, but a smoked porter, it is fairly good, but not the best.

Thanks for my brother for hooking this up!  Aroma is of beef summer sausage, some smoke, chocolate malt.  Taste is rich chocolate malt, smoke and light wood notes.  Palate is full bodied with a creamy finish.   Very good stuff and a most excellent smoked!

Thanks to TheCheeseMan for this extra treat!  Pours a pitch black with a medium mocha head that fades to a thin ring.  Aroma is meaty, summer sausage, fired wood, and smoky ash.  Taste is very creamy and silky smooth.  There is no harsh or bitter finish at all, but remains consistent throughout.  Taste is chocolate, maybe a bit of coffee, burnt wood, and ash.  This rocks hard!

Poured a deep black with very little head. Amazing nose of smoked hickory and sweet malts. Burnt chocolate taste, with a wood smoke presence, nice bitter roast ending. Thick on the palate, with a touch of fizz rather than cream. Amzing smell, wish the taste held up a  bit better, still great.

Wow, quite the impressive beer for a BevMo grab.  Extremely legit porter, best thing to come out of the far north since...well...ever.  Better than Sarah Palin at least. Pours black with a small tan head.  Strong porter flavor, coffee-ish taste with big-time smoke.  Smooth mouthfeel, medium body, low carbonation.  Makes me want to start smoking HOT TURKEY!

Hmm, smells of tasty bacon and sausage. First sip was full of smoke, followed by the nice creamy, roasty porter aspects. Not near as smokey as Urbock. Had a NG smoke on the porter to compare, they taste almost identical. For a real smoked beer nut, this didnt quite do it for me, but its still quite good. Nothing really can compare to Schlenkerla I guess

2007 bottle.  Ndarly a black pour.  Nice brown head.  Aroma is chocolate slight smoke and good roasted malts.  Initial sip hits with tons of smoke.  As I sipped it the smoke seemed to lessen and led to a wonderfully creamy and chocolatey porter.  Damn nice beer.

Tap at Pap.  Quite what I was expecting, though I was surprised by how close it tasted to a Schlenkerla, the standard for me in Rauchbier.  Flat black in the glass, smells of roast ham.  Flavor is even smoke, char and meat.  Porter is not distinguishable.

22 oz, 2008 vintage. Opaque black with a small lasting disc of cream that leaves delicate frosting behind. Aroma is alder smoke, salt and coffee. Piquant smoke, salty coffee, and char flavors are buttressed by just enough caramel and marshmallow to keep it from being a roasted and smoked malt onslaught. Medium-heavy body is sorta smooth, but has some flareups. Tingly and dry finish.

Pours a near black color with a small creamy tan head that lasts and laces nicely.  Aroma is very smoky, with coffee and roasted malt and grain.  Smoke does not come through in the flavor so much.  Lots of the roasted grain, coffee and chocolate present.  Not a bad porter.
22 oz bottle, 2007 vintage. Pours black in color with brown head. Aroma smokey, coffee and chocolate. Taste smokey and coffee with bitter dark chocolate finsih.

Bottle. a nearly black beer with a small and disappearing light brown head. The aroma is nicely smokey, though the other aromas are well integrated.Some coffee and caramel. Moderately sweet flavour, light acidity and a smokiness that is not overwhelming. Medioum body, lively carbonation, quite long finish, with almost medium bitterness. Nearly at the same level of Stone Smoked Porter, that maybe is smoother than this and less smokey.

Bottle shared with Gabe. Aroma is SMOKE! Poured black with nice tan head. Taste? well lets put it this way, I dont think you can get more smoke into a bottle, alon with malt and mild hops. If you enjoy smoked brews this is the one for you.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2009 Bottle from sleazy-eazy E. Aroma of smoke...duh... Good tan head. Taste is like standing in front of a fire and inhaling the smoke, that is as smokey as it gets. Roasted malts, a little coco and hops. Good interpretation of this stlye.. Thanks E for sharing.****Update***** 2007 bottle from sparky27... Nice smokey aroma. Taste is lots of brown sugar, maple syrup and smoked breakfast meats. Lots of campfire smoke. Light texture easy drinking. Thanks E for the bottle!
22 ounce bottle from kegbear. 2007. Nice deep dark pour nice malt aroma. Good smoked taste nice lingering smoke finish but not overpowering.I would love to try an aged one of these in the future.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: I don’t like smoked beer much, but among that variety, this is my favorite.  Dark brown with a lighter brown head.  Definitely smoked, but the malts and hops can be detected as well.  The chocolate is submerged a bit.  Probably not for everybody.

2008 version.
Black with a good three fingered tan head which subsides to a ring of tan. Plentiful lacings. Aroma is smoked chocolate.
Taste is big dark smoked malts with a good bitter cocoa hop finish. Some smoke in the finish.
Some underlying sweet chocolate makes this an exceptional porter. No wonder this is highly rated. Very nice.

Bottle courtesy of tpd975. Pours black with a one finger tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma reminds me of when I was a kid and my Dad would go buy smoked mullet and stink up the whole house. Taste is full on smoke with a touch of roasted malt. Medium mouthfeel with a mild to moderate amount of bitterness. Different but good.

I can’t appreciate this at all... This reminds me of when, as a child, I thought it would be a good idea to drink Liquid Smoke (the meat-seasoning liquid). This stuff tastes just like that. Awful flavor. Lokks and smells great however, strangely.

2008 bottle.  Quite possibly my favorite porter I’ve ever tried.  Deep and rich, almost stout like in quality.  A friend of mine claimed he could taste the smoked salmon that the malt is smoked along side of, but really its just the smoky flavor that comes through, not the fish. Wonderful beer.

Vintage 2008, 22 oz. bottle.

Pours a dark tan head, very dark black body with minimal light penetration.....nose of smoke, malts, bit of sweetish sensation....tastes of malts initially, then smoke, with a light hop finish. A good mouthfeel and great balance for the rauchbier style. I wonder about aging some to taste the evolution of the beer. 11/07/2008

Bomber. I know I’m against the grain here.This stuff was hard to swallow, I think I poured half the bomber out. It certainly is smokey, but I tasted no chocolate. It was more like bacon grease and campfire. I can see that others really enjoy this and that’s cool, its not for me. I have another bottle I will likely give away.

Inky black with a thick foamy tan head. Aroma is smoky (of course) with some salted chocolate and caramel. The smoke seems to be a nice subtle alder, or maybe hickory. There is a slight mushroomy sourness to it as well, like walking through the woods after a summer rain. The flavor is subtle and pleasant as well. The smoke, chocolate and caramel all come through, along with a nice fruity sweetness. Plums perhaps. Very light and airy mouthfeel at first. As the beer settles in the glass, it becomes a nice velvety medium bodied delight. I could gush about this some more, but I think I’ll just drink it.

2007 22 once bottle.  Pours jet black, with a tan head.  Nice smokey aroma. Taste of roasted malt, with a strong smokey presence.  A little bitter chocolate note in the background.  Not all that complex for a porter, mostly roasted malt and smoke. Not that there’s anything wrong with that.  I’ll want to try the 2008 version.

2008.  22oz bottle poured a dark brown with a ruby hue.  1 inch mocha colored head with some decent  lacing.  Aromas of smoke and smoked meats, burnt coffee and malts.  Very nice palate smooth and delicate yet packs a nice bite.  The smoke is just right, Its not overwhelming at all.

2008 bottle.  Pours a dark brown with garnet highlights and an average, creamy, dark beige head which settles to a small, frothy layer and leaves sporadic, tight lace.  Nose is sufficiently smoky with smoked wood and ash, bitter chocolate, and earthy coffee bean notes.  The smoked alder really comes through in the flavor and is more likable than I would have thought; other notes include scorched wood, bitter chocolate, lightly roasted earthy coffee, and faint notes of molasses.  Palate is medium, nearly lively, and creamy with some dryness from the smoked wood notes.  Finishes more dry and mostly bitter with smoked wood, bitter chocolate, and light acidity of the coffee.  I liked it more than I thought I would after smelling how smoked the beer was from the nose.  The flavors actually melded pretty well together and the smoked notes were dominant but still balanced by the other porterish notes.  Surprisingly good, and from AK Brewing.

Nutty smoky nose with chocolate notes.  Deep dark black/brown with with a soapy tan head.  Bittersweet chocolate syrup, balanced effortlessly by an understated smoky bitterness.  Full body, lively carbonation, long chocolaty finish with constant, yet subtle smokiness.  Extremely sophisticated beer, not overpowering with its smokiness, was hearty, but elegant.

22oz. ’06. I drink this salmon smoothy every year and i am finally getting to rating it. pours dark with creamy tan head. aroma is smoke and some roasted malt, coffee. mouthful is just pure yummy smoked goodness. i look forward to this every year.
’07Dark brown/Black, creamy, sweet,  caramel, coffee, roasted malts, little chocolate, light hop finish.

[08 Bottle] Pours a very dark brown, near black, with a small tan frothy head.  Earthy chocolate aroma, some coffee beans, and light smokiness.   First taste is of coffee malt, off-dry, some creamy chocolate,  metallic bitterness, light roasty smokiness.   Medium/light body, a bit vague with larger soda carbonation.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2009 Smelled like smoke, followed by a bag of beef jerky.  Poured a fizzy midnight brown with a decent, yet subsiding head. Tastes of smoke, wood and hops. Overall, a really balanced example of a smoked beer.

Vintage 2006 Reviewed in Sept 2009
Appearance:  Pours a very dark brown with an oily layer of swirls at the top.

Aroma:  Smoked wood and smoked meat, beef jerkey, and rubber tires.

Taste:  Strong wood notes to start off, liquid smoke, ham. After getting through the smokey woods so to speak, I find roasted malts with a spicy hop finish.

Mouthfeel: Thick and fizzy.

Overall:  I thought the smoke would be subdued after time has passed. This seems far more smokey than the 2007 and 2008 batch when it was fresh. I do remember 2006 being a real smokey beer, and I am glad it stayed that way.

2007 bomber - Pours black with a thin tan head.  The aroma is almost all smoke, a pleasant, woody (the bottle says alder) smoke.  The flavor is led by the smoke and followed by some roast malt and a touch of bitterness in the finish.  To me it was all smoke when colder, but as it warmed the other flavors came out more.  Well done.
Smoky and dark as sin, this one is a feast for the senses and makes me feel like I’m a kid again out camping with the family. Slightly over malted but that’s a very minor complaint. Very damn tasty!

2006 22oz. bottle, pours a dark brown with a creamy dark tan head, minor lacing.  Aroma is a nice woodsy campfire smoke with peat and light chocolate.  Flavor is more peat, smoky malt and light chocolate.  Very smooth, creamy and enjoyable on a cool evening.
Excellent smoke beer.  Campfire aromas and flavors of hickory smoked bacon.  Delicious!

WOW!! thanks to jjpm74.  this poured black with a thin brown head.  aroma of liquid smoke, malt, and some chocolate.  flavor was a great smokey flavor, chocolate.  had a medium body and medium carbonation.  this is a great smoked beer.
Draught. High brown creamy and lasting head. Pitch black body. Coffee smoke aroma and flavor with a good deal of hops bitterness, high carbonatkion and a long bitter aftertaste.

2008 Bottle. Pours a deep black color with a medium tan head. Smoked aroma, with some burnt malt and caramel. Some dark chocolate in the background. Nice, balanced taste. Roasted coffee, chocolate, and nice aged malt. A really good Porter.

Bottle thanks to ericandersnavy. Pours a deep black with copper hues, tan head. Aroma of beef jerky, nice. Flavor of obvious smoke, dark roast, with faint sweetness, light bitter. Mouth feel is medium body, medium body. Overall, pretty tasty.

2008 Bottle - Pours a dk dk brown with a quickly dissipating tan head...aroma is lightly smoked, roasted grain and a bit of subtle oak...smoke isn’t over the top, nothing is really...the flavour is that of a pretty average porter, good tasting but average...starts off bitter, toasted grain, coffee, smokey oats, finishes with a lingering taste and mouthfeel, and slightly watery...I assume that this is a brew that demands age in the bottle, we’ll see...
Bottle. Pours a deep rich brown. Smells and tastes like a campfire. Tastes mainly of smoke, but some malt and chocolate come through.  Not bad but the smoke is a bit strong.

Pour is a black with a small tan head.  Aroma is smoky but nothing over the top.  There is also a nice roasted malt in there.  Flavor is again more roasted malts and coffee then comes the smoke to balance things out.  Finish is a little bitter but goes down smooth.  This would be great sipping on cold winter nights.

UPDATED: JUL 24, 2009 2008 vintage.  Pours opaque black with a dark thick brown head.  The aroma is very strong of smoke, dried fruits, roasted matls, and a hint of chocolate!  Tastes of rich roasted malts beginning with hints of dried fruit and chocolate.  Then seems to explode with a powerful smokey flavor.  Has a medium body and the finish is delicately bitter with the smokey flavor lingering.  This is one of the finest porters Ive had.  Ive been looking for this beer for over a year and it was well worth the wait.

2007 vintage- pours a dark cola with quickly dissipating beige head. Nose- sweet smokiness and some dark fruits. Taste- initial wave of smoke, then blends into a fairly light bodied dry porter. Not much heft to it. Carbonation is on the high side. Finish is quite bitter. The smoke really makes the beer, otherwise would be a pretty boring porter. Drinkability is good.

If miller high-life is the champagne of beers, this is most certainly the scotch of ales. A bold and forthright smoky aroma smolders out of the glass as you pour this beer. A patient nose will also reveal hints of coffee, chocolate and vanilla. But make no mistake, the other smells are singing back up. The flavor isnt much different, a medium bodied, malty porter with big Smokey overtones. This beer would go great with a cigar.
22oz bottle from Joe - Pours a nice rich dark color.  Hint of coffee flavor and a bit of smoke.  Great balance.  Great beer.

2006 vintage.  Pours dark color with tan head.  Aroma is smokiness mixed with some nice roasted malts and a little bit of caramel.  Flavor has that "eating a smoked ham" character to it, but it isn’t overbearing in any way.  A little coffee, roastiness, and overall tastiness going on.  Palate is pretty full-bodied with a nice balance to the carbonation.  Pretty good beer.

Aroma: The smokiness mixes very well with caramel and roasted malt. Some coffee in there too. The smokiness is balanced, not overpowering. The finish is excellent with lots of roasted malts, coffee, a some rather quenching smokiness. Good thick mouthfeel with moderate carbonation. Great balance between porter and smoked.

Drinking this one for the Biden/Palin debate. Dark brown pour, thin wispy tan head. Meaty smoked aroma. Also malt and coffee. Same notes come through in the flavor. Flavor goes from roasted malt, to smoke, to a chocolatey finish. Very tasty. Mouthfeel might be a little bit on the thin side, but is still quite nice. Tasty beer overall.
From bottle.  Part of April Dayton Beertasting event.  Pours black with a off white head. Sweet smoke smell. Taste is filled with malt, chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Strong effort as usual.

2007 bomber.  dark dark brown pour with very little head.  tons of smoke in the aroma - like a smoked salmon vibe. tingly light bitter taste mixed with the smoke throughout.  finishes with a touch of sweet malt.  definitely interesting - though not something I’d likely crave.  k-6

Bottle courtesy of colemgm8 pours pitch black with slight, quick diminshing head. Aroma is the best smoke and chocolate malt smell you will ever experience. The first taste is really light chocolate malt and it suprisingly well balanced. Somewhat creamy with little carbonation. The ending of this beer is the best. I think I could blow a smoke ring after drinking this one. I saved this beer to celebrate the birth of my second son, born on 9-6-08. Brought him home today and had to crack this one open. Well worth the wait.

A nice pretty black in the glass, smell of chocolate biscuits. Very creamy on the tongue with a slight carbonation...very slight. Highlights on the palate: chocolate milk, cocoa, cafe latte and the finish ends with a kiss of smoke. Very easy drinking here, my friends.

Bottle.  Pours a coal back color with a medium tan head.  Deep roasted malt and coffee aroma.  Flavor begins with a deep raosted malt taste, then you’re hit with the smoke midway, and finally, you’re left with a slightly bitter smoke aftertaste.  A bit thin on the mouthfeel.  Good stuff!  I’d like to pair this brew with a low-and-slowed smoked pork shoulder, homemade cole slaw and garlic mashed Yukon Gold potatoes.
bottle, black color with coffee colored head, malty campfire coffee nose, flavor is an oily smokey tar with some coffee and burnt toast, very nice

2007 bottle.  Dark yet thin in both taste and appearance.  The smokiness ends up tasting fake to me (like liquid smoke used in cooking).  A robust dark brew but the thinness destroys it. Very conservative. Gets better as it warms.

2007 vintage 651ml bottle. Pours black as night with a nice off white head. Great smoky aroma. Taste is complex bittersweet chocolate, coffee, malt, smoked wood, vanilla with a bittersweet smoky finish. This is an incredible beer, I look forward to it every season.

651ml 2007 bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. Black with small foamy tan head. Great hickory smoke alarm setting off aroma. Taste is complex but too mild. Bittersweet, dry, oily, woody, vanilla, malt in the taste. Bittersweet smokey wood after-taste.

Pitch black like a stout with a medium brown head. Be aggressive with the pour and the head is quite impressive and worth a photo. A bit more carbonation than a stout. Loads of tobacco, chocolate, malt, and a thickness on the mouth feel, that again, teaters on being a stout. Fun beer, unfortunately, i live in bf egypt, so i may never get another chance.

Smoky, game meat flavor.  I remember it having a similar taste to the moose sausage I would try a few days later.  Light coffee flavors begin, but shoved abruptly to the side by more toasty malts.  Light floral hops.

Bottle.  This beer tasted like Alaska: huge notes of smoked salmon, meaty, some coffee, and a bit wild.  Admittedly, I’ve never been... but it matches my image of Alaska, at least.  Very good, and great use of the smoky meat flavors.

Poured black with a small filmy head. Smell is of smoked meat, kind of oily like a tuna can. Taste is definately smoked but its more subdued than in the aroma. Some definite coffee on the back of the tongue. Palate is velvety smooth and medium, nice for the style. This is a nice brew, probably the best I have had in this style.

OIly black with little to no head, but leaving a ring around the glass.  Obvious smoked scents, infiltrating woody coffee, chocolate and vanilla aromas.  Band-aids and pine as well.  The taste is similar to smell with generous smoked prevalence,  a light acidic sparkle with a bittering hoppy dryness and mocha/espresso flavor on the exhale.  A nice smokey coffee porter, solid and tasty.
Black bodied with a tan head.  Aroma is malty sweet, similar to malted milk balls, and brown sugary.  Flavor has a nice roasted smoke up front with a bit of chocolate.

2007 bottle, thans to Harry. black body with some small head, nose is smokey campfire with some nice sweet dark malts. flavor is similar smokey with sweet choc malts smoke is not overpowering but very nice , small amount of bitterness finishes. very very nice!!!

19-Jan-08 (Draft: Connoisseurs Session, 2008 Great Alaskan Beer and Barley Wine Festival in Anchorage, AK) 1996 vintage What a treat to try a 12-year-old Smoked Porter.  Its very smoky, but more campfire than bacon.  Also very roasty, but only a medium level of bitterness.  Dry on the palate, not very sweet at all.  Medium-full in body and medium in carbonation.  The nose is smoky but less roasty.  Dark-brown, almost opaque, and the small, dark-tan head settles to a wide ring.  This beer has held up wonderfully, so Ill keep holding onto my private stash of bottles. (8, 4, 8, 4, 16 = 4.0)21-Jan-06 (22 oz bottle: $4.99 at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) 2005 bottling Revisiting this beer just to see if I still like it as much, and yes, I absolutely believe I do.  Big, roasty maltiness, sweet chocolate and molasses work in unison with the strong smokiness to absolutely thrill my taste buds.  The smoke is pretty powerful, but not as intense or dominant as in the Schlenkerla Rauchbier lineup.  Plenty of roasty bitterness balances out the sweetness.  Some yeasty flavor in the background.  Aroma is sweet, roasty, malty and smoky, but because of the level of sweetness, it doesnt smell like smoked meats.  Body is rich, thick and heavy, well-carbonated, smooth and velvety on the palate.  Very dark brown, pretty much black through the center, ruddy brown highlights at the edges.  Light tan head rises to over half an inch, but settles fairly quickly to a wide ring, leaving spotty, patchy lacing on the glass.  Just an incredible beer...it doesnt get much better than this. (9, 4, 9,5, 18 = 4.5) 14-Sep-04 (16 oz bottle: $4) 2003 Vintage Sweet Jesus! A strong smoky aroma emanates from the bottle as soon as the twist-off cap is removed; It pours so thick and viscous, its like motor oil; Its so black and opaque, the motor oil comparison is still quite apt; Once in the glass, the smoky aroma is intense, like walking through into a recently burned out building; The flavor is, you guessed it, intensely smoky, one of the smokiest beer Ive tasted; Its fairly sweet, but not overly so, and whats extraordinary, is that this beer starts out dry, bitter, chocolaty and very dark roasted (burned is more like it), but the sweetness picks up strength in the finish -- very unusual; With how viscous the beer pours, the full bodied palate isnt as heavy or sticky as I expected; Dark tan head is of modest size on the pour, and its very slow to form through the thick viscosity of this beer, but once formed, it demonstrates very good retention; Some of the head sticks to the glass, but quickly fades away, leaving no trace of lacing; However, with all the superlatives of this beer, the lack of lacing is of no consequence to me, and doesnt diminish the appearance score because the absolute blackness and head retention of this porter is very impressive; I thought Stones Smoked Porter was a pretty outstanding effort, but this beer makes Stones taste like Porter Lite, and we know thats not the case; I mean, wow, this is an incredible beer, Im totally blown away; It has to be a top 20 beer all time for me. (10, 5, 9, 4, 18 = 4.6)

Dark brown with a small, beige colored head. Nose has roast and chocolate/oat and a just-right amount of smoke. The smoke really hits in the flavor, and it couples with the roast nicely to leave sweet milk chocolate and slight fruit in the aftertaste. Creamy medium body with a little alcohol to liven it up, and only slightly bitter. A nice, not-overdone smoked.

Pours a thick black with a small mocha head. Aroma is sweet chocolate and smoke. Flavor is light chocolate, roasty and big time smoky. Finishes long and mostly smoky. Medium bodied, rich texture. I really don’t get the whole "smoke" concept.
bottle thanks to bhops.  black pour with a huge 2 finger caramel head.  smells like bbq, charcoal and malts.  very smokey flavor that finishes quite nice with roasted malts.
2007 bottle. Pours black/dark brown with two finger head.  Aroma of ash, smoke and roasted malts. Flavor is also smokey.. all bbq and charcoal.  Medium to thick mouthfeel.  Good smokey porter.

Bomber from Bottleworks. Deep black pour with a smallish head. Solid nose of chocolate, coffee, and smokehouse. Delicious flavors of super dark coffee and cocoa powder blend well with the meaty smoke notes. This is the least "meat" flavored smoke beer I’ve had, definitely the smoothest, and my favorite by a landslide. I really wish I could buy this locally as I’d love to keep some around and try aging.
UPDATED: DEC 28, 2008 2007 bottle from Liquid Solutions. Quite excellent. Good balance, rich and dark taste and complexion. This is one fine beer. Thumbs up!

2007 bottle from Chuck and Laura in WA.  This is the first beer I’ve had from the Smoked genre.  It very much reminded me of standing next to a charcoal BBQ and drinking a dark beer.  The palate was surprisingly smooth and the flavors were distinct (chocolate and licorice).  Very interesting brew.

2007 bottle shared with Timfoolery. Poureed a dark black with just a little bit of an amber hue. The head almost disappeared instantly. Smoked with chocolate and even a little bit of licorice were the main flavors. Smooth on the palate. Very drinkable beer.

2005 bottle.  Taupe head, dark body with a crimson scarf.   Smoky nose.  Not campfire, not harsh.  Smokehouse with a slight cedary spice.  Roasty malt and slight bacony flavor wraps around the rest of the leather.  Smooth palate ,refreshing chocolate.  Seemless body leads into a clean finish.  The CO2 has diminished a little and sends this traveler towards a wine-like refinement.  Excellent with Humbolt Fog, the cheese that is.  Glad I waited this long.
2004 bottle.  Thanks for sharing Mike.  Pours black with a diminishing head.  Very strong smoke aroma and taste.  Chocolate, sryrup.....very interesting.  Held up nicely over time.

wonderful aroma, fresh brewed smell even though a year old. Great smoked flavor, been trying to smoke pork shoulder lately, and found this aroma better than anything ive made. reminiscent of chophouse smokers with...   *pauses for sip* man thats good. Subtle sweet on the back of the tung, very gentle though. Its great in my humble opinion. would love to be cold breathing fresh air as I drink it.

Very bold in its presentation.  Smoke is not overstated in its name as the flavor is smoky, peaty and earthy.  Balanced perfectly by the rich, dark malt flavor, this beer is a complex pleasure to enjoy!

Thanks to joeyiowaherkeye for this 2007 bottle.  Black pour with a small off white head.  Aroma is smoke,  sausage,  heavy malt,  an caramel....Hey,  I gave the flavor similar qualities,  some wood and more caramel.  Long lasting smoke finish.  This one was nice,  I always love the classic 8/4/8/4/16 for a good 4.0 beer.

22oz bottles 2006 & 2007 from freind who was back from Alaska. Poured dark brown with an average brown frothy head that was mostly lasting with very good lacing. Moderate to heavy chocolate smoke malt aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Medium bittersweet roasted smoked flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of moderate duration. Complex standout beer with 2006 the best.

22 oz bottle; 2006 vintage. Poured Black with a nice medium sized brown head. Aroma of heavily smoked malts, slim Jim, and a bit of chocolate. Smoke taste for me was right on.  Nice chocolate malt with a slightly dry finish and a great body. Very smooth and drinkable.  This for me was the best smoked beer I ever drank.  I want more.

Sample at the Most Honorable SuperHappyFun Stout Tasting, thanks Dogbrick:  (2006) Dark pour with a ring of white head circling the glass.  Aroma is sweet and salty.  A little bit of smoke.  Flavor is smooth, and not as salty as I anticipated.  There is a great, yet muted, smoked character here that lends way to a very tasty beer with an ever-so-lightly hopped finish.
user_location: I F&ckin hate those guys from, Ohio, USA

text:
22 oz bottle, 2007 vintage.  Pours a dark brown with a creamy tan head that goes to a thin film and laces the glass.

The aroma is chocolate malts with quite a bit of liquid smoke.  

The flavor is sweet chocolate malts up front followed by liquid smoke and some BBQ.  The finish has a good amount of bitterness (slightly plasticy).  The mouthfeel is medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, not very complex (chocolate and smoke), but its fun.  The aftertaste was a bit off, otherwise this would be higher.
bottle @Hoboken#1-pours a disappearing light tan head and black color with red tint.  Aroma is smoke.  Taste is smoke, dark malt, some dark fruit.  Occasional.

this porter was delicious. At first it tasted as if i was drinking liquid smoke. however, as the beer warmed up i enjoyed it more and more. Pours a deeo dark black which is somewhat see through. taste is of smoked chocolate and campfire. quite yummy once you get your mind used to it.

A fine porter. Pours a dark brown almost black with a tan brown head somewhat frothy. Has a strong smoked almost burnt aroma of chocolate and caramel, almost like it was cooked on a barbecue. The flavor here is very smoky all around with an upfront burnt chocolate malt and a hint of caramel. There is a long lingering smoky aftertaste that was pleasing. This was one of the most smoky porters I have ever had.

As almost everyone has stated; I have waited a long time to try this beer. The aroma is fantastic, if I hadnt started drooling, I would have just smelled the beer for hours. It is very dark with a thin brown head.
The smoke flavor is not obtrusive at all, the bittering hops however, are (in my oppinion). The combination of smoke and chocolate maltiness made me sit and sip this beer for about an hour. I like it alot.

UPDATED: FEB 1, 2012 2007 Bottle.  Pours with a small, light brown head that reverts to a ring around the glass quickly. Aroma is of dry, rich coffee, vanilla and a touch of smoke. Taste is coffee with a nice, but strong smokey finish. Nice, creamy mouthfeel with light carbonation. A bit too much smoke for me to drink by itself in large quantities, but just fine to pair with the ribs I made tonight.
2002 bottle thanks to tyleranderso. 473ml. Huge, massive smoke flavor. Lots of alderwood. Mild oxidation that seems top marry quite well with the flavors of the smoke. Still good carbonation. Impressive and better than fresher examples.

Very good porter.  2005 bottle thanks to Steve Olson.  Pour was dark with strong notes of chocolate and smoke.  Flavor was a bit more roasted finishing with a very natural smoky character.  This was a very good and flavorful porter.  Would buy, well receive as a gift, again.
pours very dark with a small head.  scent is of smoke and roast.  taste is the same.  strong smoke flavor.  Pretty good beer.

Bottle @ Kolding Bryglaug Americans tasting.
[thank you, After4ever!]
Pours deep red-black with a deep, beige-brown head. Light lacing. Aroma is very smoky, light chocolate and hard roasted malts. But it sure is powerful smoky :o). Fine mouthfeel. Flavour is super balanced though, still lots of smoke, but chocolate and very hard roasted malts with good hops create this balance. Dry finish.

Pours a dark brown with ruby hints when held up to light.  Very little head when poured and lacing was minimal.  Smell is nice and, of course, smoky - smoked bacon and charcoal.  Underlying sweet malt notes also present.  Sweet roasted malts are much more prevalent in the taste up front before giving way to the smoke taste in the finish.  There are also definite coffee and chocolate notes in the taste though they are supporting the smokiness.  The finish also has a bit of pine hop bitterness.  Mouthfeel is smooth and pretty crisp with the hop finish.  Not a lot of carbonation in the body.  This is definitely one of the better smoked beers Ive tasted and probably the most drinkable.

roasted scent without the expected smokiness, nice dark brown pour with a brown head, somewhat disappointed with the lack of smoked flavor that I was expected based on the name, if you gave it to me and just said it was a porter though Id have nothing but good things to say about it.
Bottle: Brown w/ a brown head. Wonderful smoky aroma, but thats it for aroma. Flavor is very smoky w/ some roasted malt in the background. After some warming. Well...it tastes the same.

I have had this for a while and finally decided to drink it it poured a nice dark brown with a tan head and a nice smoked flavor,I am a fan of these beers and i enjoyed this one with flavors of wood and roasted malts.CHEERS!

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2009 Bottle 2002 at Pauls Hoboken Gathering: Deep brown pour with some amber in the light and a tan ring for head. Nose has a rich smoke presence. Meaty aroma with some peat and dark chocolate. Creamy body. The flavor has a great blend of chocolate, smoked wood and roasted malts. The finish is long and smoke-filled. Nice stuff, and Im surprised the Smokiness has held up for 6-years. I wanna try it fresh and perhaps give it a better score.

I have tried this stuff several times since then, and its always mindbogglingly good. Probably the only smoked beer that can be used in the same sentence as the Schrenkerla line up. Fantastic!

Bomber bottle...opague dark brown with a light brown sugar head...smoked gouda aroma--pungent....smoky smoky and good...only problem is not much else is showing through...I get some dark roasty malts...and a bitter coffee/toffee but it takes a minute to register....ok letting it warm up a bit....44 minutes later its basically the same, very overbearing in the smoke department, a bitterness(very mild)in the finish..this would be great with a smoked gouda and bologna and cheese sandwich...just in general...a food paring with this beer should be had...like a spoonful of red raspberry preserves...whoo hoo!
Bottle.  Probably the best smoked porter ive had.  Dark black pour.  Flavor is chocolate, smoke, malt, bacon.  Mmmm bring on the BBQ.

(2007) The beer pours almost a pitch black. The nose is a rich mix of smoke licorice coffee and chocolate. The head pours a very active light brown that is mostly lasting with a thick lacing that follows down the sides of the glass. The brew taste great with a rich mix of roasted malts and just a hint of the fine smoke taste. I was worried that the smoke would over power the beer but it works nicely.

Bottle purchased from local store in Northwest.  Poured black with 0 head and 0 Head retention.  This beer had the aroma of   burnt bacon (Not Good).  I would compare the flavor to chewing on a used match extremely harsh.  As I choked this one down  my stomach began to rumble causing me to run to the head and lose it all.  I woke up with the worst hangover I have ever had and I did not even catch a buzz.  BUMMER!

From bottle - 2007 : Pours very dark and pretty carbonated.  Big brown head, about a finger and a half forms, with thick lacing.  Somewhat smokey aroma, with some meat smells.  Roasted as well, with some toffee and dark fruits.  Taste is alot of the same as the smell.  Not as much toffee though.  Medium body, with a smooth feel going down.  A sticky sweet aftertaste.  Pretty good.

2007 22oz bottle - pours deep brown with a faint tan foam that dissolves to a light skim of fine bubbles on the beer surface.  Aroma  is smoked meat and light roast.  Flavor is similar with a slightly salty smoke, roasted malt & faint coffee & burnt toffee notes.  Smoke is firm and assertive but a little less pervasive than some other smoked brews.  Finishes with a light bitter flavor.  Medium palate and low carbonation.

rating is for a 2005 version drank in 2008.

the appearance of this beer is opaque black with some nice thin tan head. 

the smell is very complex. i detect smoke, toffee, chocolate and upon swilling the beer, the smoke seemed to rise from the glass. i also detect some nutty malty sweetness.

the taste is as complex as the smell and consistant. this beer has WAY more dimension than the 2007 i tried not too long ago.

the mouthfeel is very heavy and full and should be an example for this style.

overall, i could easily drink a whole big bottle of this by myself, but would love to share with friends.
Poured a very dark brown/black. Aroma is very smokey meats and soem coffee.  Flavor is also very smokey as well with some coffee and chocolate notes hidden behind the smoke.

2007 Bottle in trade from Snojerk321 (the man, the myth, the legend)- bottle poured into my eager stein- while reading about all the mishaps at the 08 DLD, I thought I would crack this baby open and have a good gathaw while reading about some of the disheartening experiences there- poured blacker than midnight, non transparent, medium carbonation of tiny bubbles, tan head in ring formed around the glass.  Aroma of dark smoke (AHH!) from hardwood (assuming oak and birch), peat, meat, with a tiny note of lab quality sucrose.  Hits the mouth with a heavy wide body, smoke comes through very nicely with a bit of cream in the backdrop, very thick on the palate overall, nice dark bakers chocolate comes in on the backend, finish... well, it cant finish because I keep on taking sips!!!  This brew is a great interpretation of the idea that you dont need a gimmick to make a great beer- just make a good one and let nature take care of the rest.  Highest score thus far I have gave any brew- HOMERUN!!!

UPDATED: APR 28, 2008 2005 bottle, somehow the only one chilling in the cooler at Deluxe foods in Aptos about a month ago.   A really dark, near completely black body with a tight tan head that recedes into a ring.   The aroma has plenty of smoke, but its not quite as intense as a schlenkerla.   The chocolate and burnt marshmallow aromas bely a spot on smore next to the campfire.   Lots of smokey, salty dark chocolate flavor.   The smoke is more prevalent than other smoked porters that Ive had, but still is well integrated.   Medium bodied with light, creamy bubbles.   Age has treated this well, but not having had it fresh, I really cant compare.   I could definitely put down a few pints of this.   At first the smoke is a blast in the flavor, but once you adjust to it it works wonders.

2007 bottle.  I was pumped to try this one.  VERY DARK with a great tan head.  Very smokey taste with the unmistaken roasty porter flavor.  The smoke taste may have been a little overbearing at first but after a few swigs the full flavor takes over.  I am going to try to age a bottle and see how that treats me.
pours a think black with a short, small tannish head. almost no aroma at all, a faint smoked scent. taste heavy with smoked malts. slightly creamy body with a mostly flat carbonation.

Pours a dark brown with little head.  Aroma is woody and smoky, with some bacon and sausage notes.  Unlike my previous smoked beer experiences, Im actually liking it.  The flavor is hoppy with some hickory and smoke flavors, but the smoke is not overpowering; rather, it blends nicely and compliments the other flavors.  Tasty stuff!

Bottle courtesy of Sparky27. Pours a dark brown with a nice tan head. Aroma is like "Liquid Smoke". Tastes of lots of smoked grain. Finishes with a vinous flavor. Havent had a lot of smoked beers, but I enjoyed this one.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 2005 bottle, courtesy malrubius. Pours a deep brown color with red highlights. Thin watery white head, and nice lacing. Smoky roastiness, surprise surprise, hits the nose first. Some caramel and chocolate, too. I like where this is going. Roasted chocolate is the biggest thing I get flavor-wise. The smokiness is, to my surprise, somewhat subdued. Could be the age. Caramel is strong, and adds a fine touch to the overall experience. Medium-bodied, and very drinkable. Id say its held up well, but Id like to try a fresh version.

2007.  Pours charcoal black with a glimmer of mahogany; topped with regal, laced espresso foam.  Soft of aroma of brown sugar, mexican chocolate and maple cured ham; a sharp expired waft of coffee grounds and clangy citrus oils whimpers in a little but suffocates quickly beneath the weight of charred roast beef, rustic and full of muscle.  Flavor has a delicate red wine quality that suggests what Merlot should taste like; dusty, quieted, refined silky fruit characteristics in stride with a dark, decadent sweetness.  Full swallows yield warming bursts of cinnamon, anise, and heavyweight african coffee beans; sips the smoothness of pine smoke and meandering citrus sweetness.  Middle mainly of blackberry.  Palate is unexpectedly light in weight but simply could not be smoother or more caressing; body is medium with polished carbonation and full sensual creaminess.  Finish shows some tartness and a finalizing, salted bacon and rich malt smack.  Rustic but classy; it would fit just as favorably as a fine aperitif or as a dirty outdoors cigar accompaniment.  Thanks Andre!

My wife bought this one for my b-day, in recognition of the ten years I lived in AK. It certainly reminded me of Alaska;sitting by the campfire with old friends, cooking up some fresh Silvers. My first smoked porter, it threw me off at first. Halfway through the beer, I found myself enjoying the smoky flavor. It has a meaty flavor with a touch of coffee. A nice dark brown appearance and medium body with a long malty finish. While I dont believe smoked porters are my beer of choice, this was a pleasant drinking appearance.

2004 bottle, super thanks to EDA.  Deep brown pour with some medium sized beige head.  Aroma is very meaty, with some light roast and oxidation as well (although the oxidation goes well with the meaty smoke).  The palate is very soft, but the flavor is also extremely meaty (bacon?), and a little salty.  Some light roast in the finish.

In a trade with blackdonald 22 oz-bomber Pours dark w/a foamy tan head-looks like a Pepsi-sure doesnt taste like one! The smoked aroma hits you right up front. Very full & flavorful-chocolate-coffee-roasted malt-sweet cherry/vanalla even, but befinately a big smoked flavor. This is a big beer with a long flavorful finish. Makes you feel like you should be sitting around the campfire sipping it after youve just finished the Moose hunt!! Thanks for the trade, this was a good one!!
Wow! Agent Steve was right totally reminds me of smoked salmon. I only wish I could get my hands on some Coho or Sockeye, not these days. Neat beer, glad I had a chance to enjoy it.

Strong smoke aroma once poured into my glass.  A beautifully dark black with fluffy tan head, great lacing.  Flavor is up front smoke and bitter biscuit malt, roasted dark malt as well.  Great body and nice finish.  Smoke to the end.  Great beer.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2009 1999 Draft sample at The Denver Rare Beer Tasting event during GABF week on 9/25/09.  pours a deep brown towards black pour with a tan head... the smoke has diminished a lot over 10 years... dark fruit notes have really come forward in addition to some lingering chocolate... thin to medium body... very smooth and well balanced for being 10 years old... a bit roasty on the finish... Overall this vintage was a joy to try... although I prefer it within a couple years of birth... 

06 bottle.  I found this in a bottle shop in Missoula, MT and have been looking forward to finding it for some time... it definitely lived up to its hype.  Pours a deep dark brown with a 1/2" tan head... huge smoky aroma.  The smoked flavor pulls through quite well... not too much and not too little.... it is really quite perfect.  You can tell they really smoke these malts in a perfect smoke house.  Overall, it is very smooth with a medium body... a bit of coffee and sweetness on the finish.  Very drinkable and worth every bit.  Highly recommended.....

So I see this every time Im at BevMo, but always figure I can get it anytime, so not today. Someone brought this to the NorCal Tasting, and I gotta say, I loved it. It was like drinking smoked salmon covered in applewood bacon. Im a carnivore at heart, and I love beer, so man was this a treat.

Pours a deep brown to black with a small tan head. Nice smoke aroma with some cocoa and barley as well. The taste is of smoked barley, some meat flavor, a little malt and coffee with a nice smooth finish. The smoke is really well balanced on this one as its not too smoky and not undersmoked. Good stuff.
2007. poured black w/ tan head. smelled very smoky and sweet. Tasted just like a porter but smoked w/ some sweetness in there. Overall I thought it was bit smoky. I have one being aged, well see.

This is one of my favorite beers and I treated myself to a 1999 vintage that I had hidden away. The pour is a deep ruby brown with a nice 1" head. Smoke, cocoa and caramel on the nose lead to a great smoke flavor. Not a heavy beer for me, but just tasty!!

This black beer poured with a modest tan head and a very smoky aroma. The flavor is robust, filled with roasted malt, coffee and toffee. There is a lingering bitterness at the  finish. Overall, a very tasty treat.

2005 Bottle. Thanks to Santa. Poured a deep black body with thin head. Aroma is smoke, roast, bitter coffee and chocolate. Flavor is bitter chocolate, heavy smoked meat, and light roasty character to it. Went well with the meal I had - pasta with melted smoked mozz.

2007 22oz. Bottle  Pours deep rusty brown with a small 1/8 inch, dark for tan head.  Average lacing, slightly under carbonated.  Smells of smokey malts, sweet almonds, liquorish.  First sip is smooth, smokey, malty, followed by pleasant bitterness.  As is warms, the complexity increases with tobacco, coffee, caramel, and chocolate slipping through the smokey malt.  Not over smoked, not under smoked, this one gets it right.  Very Drinkable

Aroma is a smoky chocolate scent.  Color is black with mellow carbonation and a small tight tan head.  Taste is super smoky.  Starts with a lighter medium body that goes down smooth with a fizzy feel.  Finish comes in with a strong smokiness then a roasted almost burnt flavor end with a slight bitterness starting.  In the after taste the roasted goes sweet for just a moment and then leaves you with a bitterness that lingers for a while.  Its not bad but it is a bit too smoky and the body is a touch light.

Im with Andrew on this, way out of my league.  I knew it was going to be a smoked beer, but Damn!  Aroma is a nice charcol smokey BBQ.  The taste is alllllllllll smoke and nothing else.  This beer is just not made out for me.  I see where they are going w/it, just let those who love smoked beers enjoy it.  Highly rated to those who enjoy smoked beers.
Pours deep black with small brown head. Strong aromas of smoke!, malt, and some wood. Couldnt pull much flavor except SMOKE. Too overpowering for me and couldnt enjoy this one.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Big thanks to Sparky 27 - Smokey roasted malt. Nice clean reddish dark brown color. Head disappeared quickly. Smoke, coffee, chocolate in taste. Nice smokey, roasty, bitter finish. Very drinkable. A fantastic porter with great smoke flavor and one I would love to try again!

Via liquidsolutions. Pours a dark brown with reddish edges. The head is 1 finger thick creamy tan. Very nice smokey aroma, meaty, light coffee and roast. The flavor is very smokey, coffee, light waxy hops, a nice bittering quality. Nothing special on the mouthfeel, a good hop side.

Dark chocolate brown, almost opaque.  Coffee brown thin head.  Roasted malt and big smoke aromas.  Mid to full bodied with good low carbonation.  Roasted malt bbq flavors, espresso coffe notes.  Full of smoke flavor that doesnt overpower the palate.  Lingering light smoke finish, clean.

Pours a deep coffee color with a dark tan head that subsides quickly, leaving amorphous lacing. Nose is smoky and slightly sweet, with hints of caramel and molasses. Taste is redolent of coffee, molasses and burnt wood. Hearty yet slightly watery mouthfeel. Aftertaste reminds me of what my clothes smell like after sitting around a campfire.
2007 Vintage. Bottle. Pours almost black, tan head that falls. Nice lacing. Nice smoky roast aroma. Smoky foretaste, nice body, great beer.

Vintage 2005 

Pours opaque dark brown, with barely translucent edging of muddy amber. A beige head rose to a half inch, and fell quickly to a mostly bare surface, with some tight foam on the edges and a whisp on center. No lacing except for a couple of dots. 
Aromatics are full of porter character, with light smoke. Bakers chocolate, toffee, caramel, coffee grounds, and smoldering twigs. 
Mouthfeel is somewhat creamy and thickish. Lingering viscosity. 
The pallet is filled with roasted cocoa nubs, dark coffee beans, and an afterthought of embers. Hints of vanilla, burnt ends, and Kahlua follow through. 
Finishes with lingering smoke and some mild acrid character. 
The smoke seems to have faded since 2005, but the brew has picked up some nice complexity. 
A well balanced beer, but Im left wanting an "Imperial" version.

Bomber.  Notes are from memory.  The nose had a wonderful smokiness to it, a mix between a campfire and 12-hour smoked ribs.  The palate shows some bitter hops toward the finish but that melded nicely with the smokey edge.
Bottle at cgarvieuks sunday sojourn. Black with thin beige head. Smoky, roast tones. Liquorice, syrupy tones, gulpable. Good, alright.
Bottle thanks to cgarvieuk. Aroma is smokey, roasty slight liquice note. Taste is similar thinner than expected, quite drinkable.

Bottle at home with Tom ...  Thanks to the TheCheeseMan for this ... Deep Solid black ... very typical slightly fishy smokey nose ... im getting mostly the smokeyness off this ... but its got some porter character ... growing on my as i sit with it... Sorry FIn should have shared this with you, it would probably have been just up your street.
Smokey aroma, bacon, with some roasty burnt notes.  Pours black with a tan head.  Smokey, roasty, vanilla finish, with hints of chocolate.  Very smooth.  Great beer!!

2007...22.oz.  Pours black with a brown head that leaves a fairly nice lacing.  Aroma is malty with detectable smoke.  Nice smokiness in the flavor with hints of bbq with sweet malt and roasted coffee and chocolate.  Nice finish.  Very enjoyable...pairs well with any smoky food..cheese, meats etc.
Tap @ Toronado.  1/4/08.  Pours black with a light brown ring head.  Nose is roasty and full of malts and smoke.  Taste is malty full bodied and smoky, great brew.

2006 bottle. This one poured a not quite opaque black color with a small brown head. Aroma was actually smokier than i thought it was going to be. Had a nice chocolate and light roastiness to it also. Pretty solid beer that was easy to drink. I just am not the biggest fan of smoked beers or porters.

2006 bomber.  Black, active cream head. Intense aroma of burnt oak and spruce and spices, like somethings burning that probably shouldnt be.  Full flavor of smoke with some sweet malt and a hint of chocolate.  Clean and nice.

2007. Pours pitch black. No light escapes. Big, brown head, fades, but maintains a good collar to the end of the glass. Aroma is rich, smokey and complex, with lots of dark malts, some faint dark fruits, and a bit of chocolate. Smoke is big, but very smooth, backed by a real nice, rich maltiness. Not too sweet. Hops are subdued, and not apparent, except in balance. Aftertaste is quick, clean and softly smoky. Really nice, with some great notes from the alderwood.
Poured black with a creamy tan head. Aroma of chocolate and spice. Chocolate flavor backed by some smokiness. Not alot of smokey character.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2009 Bottle from Bottleworks in Seattle. Pours black with a dense brown head. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Aroma of chocolate and smoke. Initial flavor of milk chocolate, tobacco, and black patent malts, countered by a good amount of bitterness, char, peat, and tobacco. The finish is very ashy and peppery, with some astringency. Out of the fridge, its too bitter and smoky. At cellar temp, the malts and residual sweetness blend in to tame the finish. Very well done, but perhaps a bit too smoky for my personal tastes.

2005 Bottle. Nose is smoke, coffee, teriyaki, and oak. Black with minimal creme head. Lots of depth in the flavor, barbecue and liquid smoke with coffee and a mild sweetness. If this beer had a bit more body it would be a much higher rating, but its smooth and drinkable nonetheless.

Bottle:Pours dark brown to black, small head, beautiful lacing. 
Aroma: Molasses coated chard wood chips. 
Flavor: Hickory smoked chocolate with a soy sauce flavored coffee finish. Thin porter palate but full and smooth
Very heavy smoked flavor and aroma.  Pours very dark.  Tastes of smoke, malt, meaty.  Smoke hits heavy on the aroma and finishing taste.

Sampled at the RBPG; bottle courtesy of Linus_Stick. Really nice smoky aroma, but still maintains that malty porter quality. Sausage and smoked grains, malty sweet with some light hoppiness. Dark brown-black clear with a thin off-white head. Medium watery body with medium carbonation, just on the thin side. Starts mildly sweet, with that malty dry-roasted grainy quality of a good porter, then the smoke hits. Meaty and smoky sausage notes with a good amount of carbonic acidity and light dry hoppy finish. Has a nice mellow balance.

I love my smoke beers and this was something I was looking forward to. Aroma was all smoke but was a little weak. Pour was a dark brown with no head. Tste was strong smokieness with not much else going on. There was some lingering bitter aftertaste but not enough to break through the smoke. Unfortunately for this beer I had an East End Smokestack afterwards and knocked it down a few.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Picture your favorite smoked cheddar or smoked salmon. Thick heavy smoky flavor. That does not belong in beer. I love a good porter, this is not one of them. Beyond the intense overpowering taste of the smoke flavor, its pretty much your basic, non-complex porter. Very little hoppiness. Goes down with almost no bite. Nice dark color, good clarity. Aroma is pure salmon smoker.  Bottom line, a would-be disapointing porter without the horrible overpowering smoky flavor. I will never drink one again.

Had the pleasure of sampling this at the 1/27/2008 Pittsburgh ratebeer.com gathering upstairs, Sharp Edge Creekhouse. It will be a long time, if ever I am invited again and I see a spread of bottles like I did there - ever again. I am not good enough for the beers that were that we sampled! For example, how about this beer; Alaskan Smoked Porter from Linus_Stick, thanks!  Very smokey aroma of wood burning. Looks like root beer. Barely any carbonation. Taste is really burned and smoked wood, what else? Leathery tanned at times. Small amount of bitterness but Im not sure if it is from the brew or from the smoke? Very unique in its own way.
