Pours black with a small off-white head.  Aroma is sweet fruit with a touch of smoke.  The taste is sweet, and can be best described as a coffee-flavored chocolate bar held over a flame.  Roasted coffee finish.  Doesnt have as much complexity as I expected, but very smooth indeed.

2004 - 22oz - Smokey smell but not over the top.  Also hints of crispy malts and a bit of coffee.  Opaque black with a medium brown head and good lacing.  Flavor is smoke, malt, carmel, and a touch of coffee.  A very well blended porter that has complementing flavors that do not overwhelm each other.  I think that a few years in the cellar will smooth it out even more.

poured dark opaque brown with a tanish brown head. nose dominated by smoke and burnt aromas.  palate follows the nose with huge almost cloying smoked wood flavors with a bit of roasted toffee coffee background support.  in my opinion smoke flavors are too dominate and overpower the beer. maybe after a year or so of cellaring....could get better.

Poured a dark brown, almost black, with a medium sized brownish head. Aroma was chocolatey, malty and maybe some coffee malts. Flavor was obviously smokey, but it was really smooth, which made it very drinkable. Im glad I picked this brew up.

NIce dark brown color with a bit of off-white head an splotches of lace. Nose is roasty, chocolaty and of course quite smoke, but not overpoweringly so. Flavor is likewise with a nice slick mouthfeel punctuated by medium carbonation. The most drinkable smoked beer I have tried with a noticeable smoke flavor. Thanks to Heemer77 for this bad boy!

Finally!  After over a year of searching and begging I got a few 22oz bottles (thanks to LiquidSolutions).  2004 bottling.  Very dark brown/black color with a small to medium tan head and good lacing.  No question about the smoke in this one.  The smokey aroma almost set the smoke detectors off.  Roasted malt and piney or oaky aromas as well.  Big smokey flavor on top of the roasty, dark fruit flavors and toffee.  I would describe the overtones as more of a smoke cured meat than smoked fish.  Strange to see that in type while at the same time saying that its a really tasty beer.  Probably not for everyone simply because it is such an unusual flavor and the smoke is very strong but I really liked it and Im glad I didnt give up on my quest for the Holy Smoked Porter!

Bottle, 2004.Nearly opaque body with a thin beoge head. Smokey, woody nose. The taste is sweeter than I was anticipating. Nice smoke, tanninc, woody,bacon,  meaty, caramel notes come through. The finish leaves a strong burnt/smokey taste and is quite bitter. This is good. Smoked beers are not my favorite, but this is one of the better ones.

I sampled the same bottle of 2001 thanks to Mullman.    The strong aroma of smoked malts stood out as the dominate quality of the 2001 bottle.  2004s aroma was toned down.    Very nice blend of flavors in this smoked porter.    Ive only see this beer in Northern California, it was nice to sample one in PA at hopdogs gathering.

2001 bottle thanks to Mullman. Black in color with a small tan head. Beautiful aroma of mild smoke, sweet malt, caramel. The smokiness is more pronounced in the flavor. Mildly sweet roasted malts with just a hint of hops.
Excellent! Tasted side by side with a 2004 bottle. The newer one had a much more mild aroma, was hoppier and less smoky. Definitely ages well.

Beef jerky aroma. Smells also like a campfire. Light brown head. Fully diminishing. Rich, smoked essence is very apparent. Good hop profile. Very solid. Almost the perfect porter. Could use a little more alcohol, but at least you can have a few without being under the table. The smoked aspect is done perfectly.

On [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Port Solana:  Dark brown almost black in color. Small (bar pour) tan head. Aroma of smoked ham. Flavor is malty with smoke and a light stout like bitterness. Light palate.  I probably would have liked it more if it was not served so COLD.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2007 Reminds me of a nice camp fire at a camp where the counselors are horny and theres a masked maniac roaming the woods with a chip on his shoulder... Very tasty.  Let it get to almost room temperature before you drink.  Trust me.  Nice, NICE bits of smoke and burning wood.  The taste immediately transports the imbiber to a simpler place, where the day begins with the sun and the day ends with the last spark of the campfire.  Exquisite mouthfeel that spreads the smokey goodness throughout the mouth.  Not to be missed.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 From a small bottle.Near black in colour,nice head,Kippers and dover soul sprang to mind,full and bitter,not much fun for me.

2004 edition - 23 oz.  Wonderful wife had 6 of these shipped to me for Christmas :-)
Definite smoky aroma and taste, but not too much.  Gets even better as it warms - a refined taste.  Didnt taste chocolate, a hint of coffee though.  I have four left Ill save for special occasions.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 2004 bomber. This didnt seem like it would blow me away considering that it smelled like smoked salmon, but it tastes great. Smoke with salmon and bacon hints and a creamy, almost vanilla finish. A smooth, unique, and delicious beer.

poured a near black with a light brown head. smoke is evident in the aroma. i spent a minute just taking it in. sharp almost like a smokehouse full of cured meats. mmmmmmm,(insert homers drool here)cured meats. flavor is chocked full of smoke flavor with a bitter edge. roasted coffee and ham flavors that are strange yet wonderful together. i couldnt see myself drinking too many in one sitting, but this is a damn fine brew that i will look forward to having again. wow, this beer truly gets better as it warms.
thx. santa!  Ruby, near black.  Smoky fishy nose - iodine/single malt esque.  Sweet cocolate at first, then a smoky fish/bacon/iodine thing.  Fishy iodine finish.  Overwhelming but interesting.
2004 Version- Deep black in color with a creamy tan head.  Lots of roasted coffee aroma with a thick creamy coffee chocolate taste.  Bitter finish.  Such a lively taste on the tongue.

2004 bottle. Dark brown color, almost stout dark, tan head that disappears quickly. Aroma is a mild blend of dark chocolate malt and a hint of smokiness. Great smoky flavor dominates with notes of dark chocolate malt, very earthy. A hint of hop bitterness comes through in the finish. Mouthfeel is quite smooth. A solid offering, makes the smoke in the Stone Smoked Porter seem pedestrian.

Dark brown coloured body a nice tan head. Aroma of smoked peat and about nothing else. Medium-bodied; Full smokey flavour with a nice full taste. Aftertaste smokey and dark. Overall, great to drink and very nice to be able to sample. Thanks to EyedrinkAle for this beer! I sampled this 65 cL bottle after the RB party at Founders in Alexandria, Virginia at Mikes (the_beer_god) hotel room on 20-November-2004.

aroma of delicious smoked salmon, nice very dark porter, light brown head and thick lacing, nice very robust taste, rich smoke flavor, thick malts, very thick for a porter, bitter at the finish, hoppy, scrum didily ohhh!

I have always loved smoked beers such as Rauchbier or Steinbier.  First tried this beer on draft at a bar in San Fran and fell in love with it.  Very dark porter with an excellent darkish red head and smoked aroma and flavor (from Alderwood).  I just smoked some pale malt with Alderwood and have tried my hand at homebrewing this one.
Darl black colour. smokey campfire type nose. smokey malt taste with bitter after taste. slight lace

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2005 Smells like bacon.  All I could taste and smell was liquid smoke flavoring.  Watery and lacking in body and complexity.  Couldn’t even finish the pint.  I had the opportunity to do a vertical tasting of some previous years...   The 03 was smoked bacon, dark fermented fruit, flowers and a slight coffee note.  It was smooth and creamy w/ a dry finish.  The 02 was roasty and smokey, dark fruit, and a slight coffee note.  It was smooth and creamy, slightly wet finish and well-rounded.  The 01 was roasty, smoke, coffee, and big chocolate/mocha note.  It was smooth, creamy, and a dry finish.  The 01 was much better.

2004 Bomber. This beer comes with a lot of hype.  I was afraid it wouldnt live up to it.  The pour was smooth black.  In the glass it sat quietly with almost no head except for a thin cream around the glass.  The color was flat black.  Almost like it absorbed the light.  There was only a slight smoke aroma that was mild, unlight the more sour burnt hay aromas I have found in others.  The mouthfeel was thick and smooth like a good porter should be.  I didnt find a lot of smoked flavor, only a hint.  This doesnt even come close to Aecht Rauchbier Urbock in smoked character.  Subtlety is the name of the game with this beer.  The finish is dry with a faint aftertaste of smoke.  Had I not already known this was a "smoked" beer, I doubt I would have called it that.  I found this an exceptionally delicious and well done porter, but as for the "smoked" label, I found it lacking.

This smells like lox, very strange.  Beautiful black color.  The smoked flavor is very strong and intriguing.  Light for such a dark beer.  The best thing about this beer is that not too sweet, like the majority of porters.

2004 bomber...nearly opaque pour with a medium tan hot chocolate head.  Metallic, roasted malt aroma.  Smoke evident also.  Metallic smoke flavor to start.  Some acidity in the middle...smoke lingering in the finish.  Tastes like just after coming out of a house fire, almost a little too much.  A little thin.

Smoked beers tend to divide opinion, but I like em. Very dark colour, with insignificant head. The smoke dominates any other elements in the aroma, but, somehow, its not too overwhelming. Coffee and chocolate put in an appearance in the flavour, with smoky bacon again to the fore. The mouthfeel is rich, but not too heavy. Unfortunately, I neglected to note down which year it was. Overall, I thought it was pretty good if not exactly subtle. Bottle at the DC gathering aftermath, courtesy of eyedrinkale.

On tap.  Deep brown, small mocha head.  Aroma is coffee and smokey, earthy,  roasted malts.  Very rich coffe/earthy/smokey/malty flavor, with a long aftertaste that lingers with smoke. Nice medium body and feel.  Very very nice.

Bottle post DC/MD/VA/WV/PA Ratebeer Gathering 11/20/04, courtesty of eyedrinkale: Dark brown/black bear with a tiny tan head.  Lots of earthy, peat smoked malt, burnt chocolate, smoke, very dry.  Finishes with a smokey molasses taste.  Just a bit too thin.
dark black beer with a tan head. Great smokey aroma and taste with a slight aftertaste. A very good beer.
UPDATED: DEC 12, 2004 2004- Aroma is chocolate, bacon, and grease.  Quickly dissapating tan head.  Mouthfeel is very nice, and chewy, and silky.  Taste is smoke, bacon, oak, chocolate, and espresso.

2004 bottle.nice black body with a "root beer" style head.smells a bit like liquid smoke ,and soy suace.lots of smoke in the flavor.almost like the same taste as a nice smoked piece of bbq.pretty much smoke all the way through.very different but very good.

2004 Bottled.  Pours a dark brown, almost black.  Small frothy tan head that fades to lacing quickly. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla and smoke.  Rather thin malt flavor with coffee, chocolate, vanilla and slightly acrid smokey tastes.  Good beer right now, Im betting even better this time next year.
04 Bottle- Pours a darker brown, small vanilla head. Aroma of smoked cofffee, choclate, very smooth smoked flavor. Nice brew, thanks to Heemer77 for sharing this one!

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2008 Recent rerate of a 2007 vintage in 2008, thanks, iowaherkeye. I gave it pretty much the same notes and overall score and thought it was a little more smoky than previous vintages that I tried. Still a great beer. Got this in a quick trade, thanks again Flipbrewer 2004 vintage. The head is thin and off white with tan coloring. The body is very black and no light penetrated my glass. The aroma is a nice smoky oak with caramel and toffee. There is not as much smoke in the taste. It has oak, walnuts, caramel and woodchips. The mouthfeel was a little thin with with plenty of carbonation. While this is a great subtle beer, I almost want more smoke flavoring. I hate to knock this very well balanced beer based on that perception. Another one that would be interesting to cellar.

Very dark brown body.  Woody, smokey aorma with muddy smoked fish notes.  Caramel and hickory smoke as well as subdued raspberry sweetness round out the flavor.  My first smoked beer that I actually enjoyed, not just tolerated.  I think its the sweet fruity portion that helps break up the smoke that I normally dislike.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2006 rated 3/28/06 thanks to blake for sharing.
Black pour w/ a thick small bubbled creamy tan head and some great lacing.  Smells of burnt malt, nice smoky notes like near a natural wood fire, hints of smoked fish, some roasty light chocolates as well.  Palate has a nice light texturs coats well and finishes lightly creamy.  Flavor is a bitter chocolate bar eaten next to a natural wood fire.  light coccoa taste a bit dry in the finish suggests a light hopping.  A very nicely done smoked beer or porter or both.  Wow has my palate changed.

11/2004 early career rating:
poured a very dark color w/ a dark tan quickly dissapating head.  Smelled of aotmea, coffee and burnt wood.. the burnt scent is initially overpowering but after letting it sit for a couple minutes the smoky scent milds out nicely.  The pal is a little spice and has a nice creamy texture.  The flavor reminded me of eating something next to a campfire it was hard to get past the smoky taste which covered hints of carmel.  Overall this beer was very different than what Im used to and was my first smoked beer.  I think if the smoke taste was calmed just slightly it would be much better.

2004 Bottle:
Pours out a nice dark brown with a slight hue of red. It has a nice smoky/sweet aroma with a small lacing head. The taste is awesome,  with notes of chocolate, roasted malts and a nice smoky flavor with notes of woodchips. Awesome brew, cant wait to try one of these when its a year old

Whoa, am I the first 04 rater?!?

< beam >

Pretty much the same label except for "2004" on top and it now under the ABC logo it states "Gold Medal Winner: Weve applied the Alaskan tradition of alder-smoking to the malts of this rich, intensely flavored porter, a recognized leader among the worlds smoked beers. Enjoy it now or age it for severeal years." Oh, and the alcohol is now 6.5% ABV.

This is my first sampling of this fine beer. Fair warning: "smoked" is not applied flipantly to this fine beer. If you dont like BBQ, jerky, or out-door cooking, you wont like this, which is fine because then there will be more for us special folks. This is actually my first sampling of this style, so Im going somewhat blind here.

Pours a chocolaty redish brown with nice head and some lacing.

The scent is like I walked into a smoke house; so strong I almost wanted to hold my breath. Very malty other than that.

Taste; and I thought it *smelled* smoky. The smoke almost overwhelms all other tastes, especially for the first few sips. Then the complexity kicks in. This is a great beer. It has all the coffee, toffee, and dark fruits of an awesome Porter with a nice smoky undertone.

Palate is thicker than a typical Porter and still has a bit of a mineral mouthfeel reminicent of Sheaf Stout, but not quite as strong. This is nicely done.

Overall, this is awesome. I will be trying more of this style. I just looked down and realized this is top-rated, which may mean Im ruined for this style, but Im glad I didnt first try crap and then was turned away from ever trying another one. This is a definate must-try!

03 bottle drank in 04. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma is of chocolate and a woody smoke. Flavor is of woody smoke, burnt chocolate, sweet chocolate. The flavor is layered very well. Smoke is a pleasent accent and not overdone. Nice beer.

2003 bottle.  Pitch black with tan head that is medium sized for a porter and ends up flat like one.  Aroma is sweet and smokey with chocolate and malt.  Flavor is toned down a bit but some bits of chocolate,brown sugar and black coffee bean shine through.  Thin creamy texture while still remaining smooth on the palate.  Not a easy find.

2001 bottle. Murky brown color, no head. Aroma of chocolate, smoked malt and alcohol. Flavor of smoked malt, alcohol and roasted malt. Bitter finish. Light body, liquorous texture, soft carbonation. Still very good after a few years.

Soy sauce, brown sugar, hickory-like smoked aroma. Opaque, dark brown, almost black, with thin, tan head that recedes slowly to ring. Roasty up front with plenty of distinctive smoked malt character. Vegetable-like flavour in the finish detracts from overall enjoyment. Lasting sweetness and roastiness in the aftertaste. Fairly still with soft carbonation. Bottle (2001) enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and a gang of bierophoux.

"best before 2006" bottled. I can only echo those who have gone before me. Does exactly what it says on the bottle. Very much how I imagine a porter should be - black, full and an appropriate amount of alcohol. I would guess the C19th porters were similar, with stout being in a higher alcohol bracket, around 8-9%ABV. The word stout was used in the sense of strong, so you can pour away those pissy 4% stouts straight away.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 <ReRate 2005 edition> Still amazing as ever, plus, the body seems a little fuller and more satisfying with medium, fine-beaded carbonation. 

2003 edition. Got this in a trade with DarkElf. Pours an opaque black with a quickly disappearing brown head. Aroma is godly - smoked meats and roasted malt. Taste has the same qualities of the aroma plus notes of peat, chocolate, coffee and molasses. Moderately sweet with a slightly burnt aftertaste. Mouthfeel is thinner than I would have expected, medium bodied. Overall, an awesome brew.

This Porter pours very dark brown,The aroma is, smoky with a heavily roasted malt aroma on the nose. Theres lots of chocolate and dark coffee notes.The taste is big and bold. There are hints of dark chocolate, molasses, coffee, but the overwhelming flavour is smoke . The smoky flavour is not overwelming, just a perfect balance. Theres a little sweetness near the finish, which helps the balance, slightly bitter aftertaste. This is quite possibly one of the best made Porters in the world. Its not for everyone but is definitely worth trying!

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2006 GABF, 2004.  Pours a nice black color with a nice tan head that leaves decent lacing.  Aroma is very sweet and smokey, meaty, malty, very impressive. Very smooth taste going down, tastes of dry roasty cocoa and coffee,  leaving a great smoked flavor behind, almost like a smoked cheddar and bacon or something along those lines. Nice and rich with a slightly bitter end.  I havent liked a lot of smoked beers, but this one is great.

Bottle (2004) pours jet black, small tannish frothy head, with fairly sticky lacing. &nbsp A lovely smoked wood aroma on the nose, not at all like cigarettes or an ashtray which really put me off. &nbsp Flavor is moreso heavily roasted malts than smoked. &nbsp Definitely not as heavy as last years. &nbsp Good body, somewhat smooth mouthfeel. &nbsp Long smokey finish, heavy, dark, and roasted. &nbsp Really enjoyable for a smoke ale!

2002 bottle. Small fizzy off-white head, not lasting. Clear mahogany body. Looks like a nice shiny brown liquor after a while. Aroma is medium bodied and sweet with chocolate, a light non-overwhelming smokiness, and pear. Very good porter flavor with again, slight smoke. Light lactic feel w/ semi-sweet fruit and bitter chocolate. Full bodied and soft palate. Delicious.

Pitch Black. The head is dense, off white, thin, mostly diminishing 

Vanilla, mesquite smoke, sweet malts, chocolate, coffee and cocoa in the nose. Smells like a very good porter with subtle smokiness. 

There is really no better to way to describe this but to say that it is a wonderfully complex porter along with a very subtle smokiness. Roasted malts, chocolate, toffee, coffee beans and vanilla . Pleasant smokiness throughout but what I like about it is that it finishes with the porter notes and leaves the smoke behind. Very nice finish. Lingering. Great Beer.

1999 Vintage:

4.0
4.5
4.5
4.0
4.5
UPDATED: MAY 8, 2006 GABF2004... Poured a dark brown color with a tan head.  Roasty, smokey, and cocoa aroma.  Burnt, roasted malts and chocolate.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2004 Draft at the brewery: Dark black in color; creamy tan head. Rich texture, not too heavy and not too light. Dark roasted malts. Notes of toast, chocolate and subtle espresso. Very nice level of smoke (and I dont like smoky beers, so Im sensitive to balanced smokiness). Sweetness and bitterness are at a very pleasant level and in perfect harmony. Drying bitterness. 1999 vintage: Big smoked salmon and bacon in the nose (very different from the "newborn" version I had months ago). Super smooth and creamy texture. Light, but complex smokiness. Big chocolate notes. Mellow and relaxed. Fully flavored, but easy to drink. Very tasty. 1998: Big salmon nose. Chewy and smooth. Tame and mellow hops. Notes of wood, bitter chocolate, and a hint of citrus that was buried in the bitterness in the finish. Nice layers of flavors and aromas.

This beer exemplifies the very definition of the style.  It is an excellent, robust porter with a HUGE smoke dominance in the flavor profile.  The porter flavor characteristics are completely overshadowed and engulfed by the smoke flavor in this beer.  It hits the palate from the beginning and lingers through the finish (and lingers....and lingers....and lingers....).  Flavor is reminiscent of good beef-jerky.

Pours very dark and thick looking. Aroma is super smokey. Smells like coffee and smoked 
brown sugar and maple cured bacon and chocolate. Very robust flavor. If you want smoked this porter gives it to you. Starts of really smokey and settles down and gives you some smoked sweetness toward the end. A very full and rich brew.
A nice beer once aged for a few years.  Wow, its smoky.  Its like a bottle of liquid hickory smoke with some hops thrown in.  The Waffle House analogy is particularly apt.

Aroma is smoked bacon, coffee, and ham. Like smelling your Waffle House breakfast plate. Appearance is pitch black with a tan head. The flavor is somewhat bitter with some charcoal and bacon present. It tastes a bit burnt but not in an offensive way.  Very interesting and smokey. Non fans of the smoked style need not apply.

Very smoky, more so than the other smoked porters Ive had. Delicious. The malt is luscious and full but starting (? not sure...?) to get touched by some acidity. Hops subtle, not pine like, well, you know.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Im not a big fan of smoked beers, but this is one of the better ones Ive tried. Very dark brown coloured, with a thin head. Other things going on apart from the dominant smokey attributes; sweet and malty, smooth and full bodied.

Jet black in color with a little caramel head head.  Smoky and roasty aroma, my wife says it smells like a freakin wood fire.  Luscious, velvety and oily mouthfeel.  Nicely bitter, burnt chocolate flavor.  A winner of a porter, that is for sure.  Props to Flipbrewer again.

(Bottle)  Pours a nelarly black color with a small hot chocolate-like head.  Aroma of chocolate and smokiness.  Flavors of smoke, nuts, roasted malt, and chocolate.  The best smoked beer that I have tried.

Bottle 2001 Pours black with a medium size dark tan head.  This goes down pretty quick but the lacing is fine and even.  Aroma is very chocolate and Smoke, mesquite axactually. Also some licorice and molassas.  Wow, taste is VERY Smokey. Cant taste much hops...or much of anything else.  Feel is moderately thick and the finish is creamy and smooth.  A specialized beer for a specific taste.  Good Stuff.

2003 Bottle. Very smoky, nice taste though. Roasty, coffee. Small head, little retention.
Good brew.

2003. Pours black, little head. Smells of malt and liquid smoke. I admit I was afraid to taste it, as the smokiness of it didnt seem fitting for beer, but rather meat. Lots of roasted taste, mixed with smoke and coffee... An odd combo but it works. Im glad I was able to try this one. Thanks for the trade, Darkelf!

16 oz bottle, 2003 vintage.  Jet black, thin light brown head.  Smoked ham-and-eggs aroma isnt as agressive or complex as that of the A-S Rauchbier Urbock, rather more delicate, lightly sugary and inviting.  Smokiness hits immediately upon tasting, dry and meaty as an aged steak...mouthfeel thinner in the middle, lightly vinous, with light chocolate and heavy espresso entering to give the finish a huge wallop.  A bit of cherry-licorice slowly develops as the beer warms and a few sips have been had...this is not quite on a par with those amazing Heller Trum beers, but it is a top-notch smoked and a very good porter, and as Im a fan of the style, it gets a high mark from me indeed.  Not a beer to start with if youve never had a smoked, unless youre quite adventurous.  Thanks so very much Flipbrewer!

Just about as good as it gets. Ive found that I like the older vintages a little more as the bitterness seems to fade and leave more room for the smoke.  This is nearly always my last beer of any session.

02 vintage Well, according the Buckster, this has lost some of its smoke character with age, but here goes. Dark brown with a medium tannish head. Some lacing. Small smokey aromas, chocolate, roast malts and raisins. Bigger smoke in the flavors, but not overpowering. The malts are very similar to the aromas. Bitter palate and a smokey finish.

This is one of the finest beers ever made. Cant think of much of anything wrong with it. Excellent balance of malt and smoke. Ive never aged mine because it never lasts that long, but this is one beer you could probably lay down for awhile. MMMM.

In the immortal words of Jimmie Walker...."DYNOMITE!"  This smoked porter knocked me out!  It was a great marriage of flavors and aroma. Even though this is a smoked porter the smoke aroma dosent overpower the brew, unlike some other smoked porters(like rogues smoked porter). I would Highly recommend this beer paired with a good full-bodied cigar--Ashton VSG

Acquired via trade. 2003 Bottle: The beer is an almost opaque dark brown color with a thin light brown head. Thin and sticky lacing. The aroma of course has a strong smoked character, along with malt, soy sauce and coffee. Medium-bodied and mellow, with flavors of coffee, cocoa and malt underneath the smoke. The finish is dry and lightly bitter. I have been waiting awhile to get my hands on this beer and I was not let down.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2006 2003 Bottle. Pours very dark, smokey coffee sweet aroma.  Excellent balance of flavors, almost stoutlike sweetness and body, hint of smoke with coffee and perhaps a bit of currant and a somewhat salty finish. Enjoyed this very much.
2005: Seems like they dialed up the smoke in this version, just a bit more than I like - lowering my rating.

Had at the brewery.  OMG -- this was wonderful.  Wish they distributed this in my area.  Nice deep brown/black body with quick finishing head.  The Alder smoke really sets in mid-taste - wow so good.  Silky smooth with notes of coffee throughout.  Still, i think a fresh batch of Anhor Porter would be better, but its really hard to say.
user_location: Palm Beach Gardens, FL, Florida, USA

text:
Bottled in 2003 Thanks to Eyedrinkale for bringing this to Brewtopia 04.
Black with minimal head. The aroma is smoky, yet the malt aroma comes through with hints of dried fruit. The flavor is also malty with a good smoky presence which doesnt overpower everything like some smoked beers do. Very nice.

2003.  Pours a dark brown.  A good amount of smoke in the aroma.   Good body as expected from a porter.  Strong smoke flavor but worked well with the maltieness.  IIt should age well.  What I liked best about the beer was it was smooth and the flavors tasted natural, unlike some of the smoke beers that taste like liquid smoked was poured in by the gallon

Sampled 1998 and 2003 in the bottle at the AHA AHC 04 in Vegas.  1998: Smokey salmon like nose.  I smell some slightly sweet malt too. Not much head or lacing.  Taste some astringency  and roasted malt with a nice background of smoke. Thin in texture.  No oxidation! (Pretty good for a 6 year old bottle). 2003: More head and lacing than the older sample. Roasty nose with some smoke. Notes of plum and cherry in the flavor.  I little bit thicker than the older bottle to. Not as much smoke which is strange.  Now I know to hold on to this beer as long as I can.
Bottle at Brewtopia, thanks to someone. Dark brown. Tan head. Awesome smoke. Love it. Flavor has carmel, chocolate, smoke. A great combo. Love that smoke aroma!
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: 2003 - Aroma of smoked meat overlaying sweet malt.  Appears opaque chocolate brown with a very thin brown head that dissipates quickly but leaves lacing.  Flavor is smoky, sweet, with roasted malt and a lingering burnt flavor.  Palate is thinner than expected with refreshing effervescence.  Overall, this beer is slightly greater than the sum of its parts.

very malty like a imperial porter with a touch of smoke. deep ruby red almost black brown head lots of malt.
2003 edition

2003 version--- pours an almost black/brown with no head, just a ring around the top.  Aromas are amazing.... The flavor of smoked salmon is taking over my sense of smell.   Chocolate and coffee, as usual, is in the aroma...  Flavor is very smokey and all else isnt that upfront.   As with many other smoked brews, the smoke flavor takes over all of the of the original flavors of the brew..  I wonder if age will mellow out the smoke and let the rest of the beer shine through.  There is a slight bitterness and a flavor that leaves a warm belly.   rerate-- And after about 12 minutes and 37 seconds, this brew, as every brew, opens up so much more...  the complexities of a robust porter come through and the initial over-smoked flavor disapates.  15 minutes ago, I gave this a 3.2 which was a little generous at the time... but now it is at about a 3.8,

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 2003: Opaque deep dark brown with a quickly phasing out light brown head. Forget some chocolate over your fireplace, put some bacon to medium fire, cut a slice or 2 of smoked ham, mix it all up and take a big sniff. Its mostly light, pretty much all about the smoke figures, but seems well done and balanced. Body is mostly light with moderate carbonation which could be less intense. Very mild acidity on the tongue, leather, herbal characteristics. This is not as good as Id hope. Dark roasted malt, licorice, molasses, very dry coffee lingers. I must say Im much more keen on the smoke focus in the aroma than the a little of everything on the palate where I lose the fire and woody characteristics that I love. I prefer a calumet or revenante.  2001 aged sample in october 2004. No head, firecamp aroma, bold malt flavors, woody, lightly earthy. Light tartness, rather creamy, but flavors got a bit subdued and overall, it's less interesting than the 2003.

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2004 2002 version from a 660 ml bottle.  Prominant smokey aroma.  Dark beer with a fast disappearing head.  Molasses, sweet caramel malt and brown sugar.  The flavour was much more subtle than the aroma, the smokiness accentuates a well balanced brew with piney hops, grassy flavour and just enough bitterness to finish and round it off.
2003 version
Very dark brown with a thin dissipating tan-coloured head, leaving a ring of foam around the rim of the glass.  Smoky, beeckwood aroma layered over the top of a fairly prominent coffee character.  Flavour however, shows coffee on the front, light acidity which then explodes into a load of smoke on the finish with a lingering bitterness on the finish.  Quite different from the 2002 however, but almost as good.
Ar 8, Ap 3, Fl 7, Pa 4, Ov 15
2003 Edition.  Great wet campfire aroma, mixed with chocolate notes.  Smooth and very drinkable.

2003 edition.  This dark brown-bodied porter poured with a minimal light tan head.  Smoked malt aroma carries over into the flavor- I felt I was drinking liquefied smoked chubs (oh, so good!).  Salty cured meat with toasty, roasted malt flavors carry the body.  Rather thin-bodied.  Also rather unidimensional.

2003: Aroma of smoked salmon or maybe lotz. Near black with translucent shallows and an off white head that give a very rich and fresh look. Carbonation is medium-low and the flavor smokey, grapish and well roasted. It is sweet and fresh (as opposed to earthy/musty/dank). This must be brewed from salmon juice instead of water, but in a positive way (if thats possible). The big thing is that the smoke flavor doesnt dominate or taint the beverage but is subtle enough to really enhance the overall flavor. Good stuff.

2002 bottle.  Opaque black and a tan head.   Aroma is of smoke and chocolate.  Tastewise, the smoke is subdued, and balanced with the other flavours - choclate, plum, raisin.  The smoke comes out in the finish.   Really good stuff.  Much thanks to slikwily for this!

Thanks to Flipbrewer for this one.  Pours deep black with a nice tan head and lace.  Aroma of malt, coffee, chocolate, smoke, berries, and some licorice.  Tastes smooth, malty, with a nice, sweet dark chocolate taste combined with a roasty, smokey malt flavor.  Finishes super smooth, smoky, with some black licorice, malt, smoked salmon, and poontang overtones.  The smoky aroma and flavor do not taste phony at all.  Great complexity, and a great, complex finish.
2002 bottle. Nearly black with a small tan head. Smokey, meaty, malt aroma. Light smokey flavor with some cocoa and a dry roasty bitterness. A slight hint of plum as well. Quite nice.

Vintage 2003.
A pitch black beer with a foamy tan head. Smokey roasted malt aroma with coffee tones. Smoke is penetrating in the flavor. Also roasted malt and liquorice and a bitterdry finish. Nice and soft but maybe a little thin.

UPDATED: JAN 15, 2005 2003 vintage tasted on 5/2/04. Dark black in color with a large tan head. Aroma dominated by smokey smells but also hints of roasted malts, coffee and chocolate. Smokey coffee tasting.   Tasted 2001 & 2004 vintages on 1/14/05. The 01 is my favorite out of the 3 vintages Ive tasted. Based on the 01, I rased the overall score for this beer (ages real well).

2003 vintage, aged 1 year. Pours a nice black color with a nice tan head that leaves decent lacing. Aroma is very sweet and smokey, very impressive. Very smooth taste going down leaving a great smoked flavor behind, almost like a smoke cheddar or something. Nice and rich with a slightly bitter end. I was very impressed with this beer, alaskan brewing had not impressed me much in the past.
Bottled, thanks rauchbier! Near black. Smokey licorice aroma. Firm and rounded, but a bit clean. Intricate mix of burnt malt with smoke. Salty finish.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 2003 Vintage, bottled. Pours very black with a medium tan head, slightly red/pint tinge to the beer, and to the foam, which soon melted down to practically nothing.. It has low to medium carbonation. Aroma is Smokey, just like smoked cheese (as opposed to the smoked ham of the Schlenkerla) . First sip is of smoked cheese; a little roasted coffee and a bitter/sour feel on the back of the throat. As I work my way down the beer the smoked flavour becomes more subdued, it is very mellow, making this an accessible smoked beer (I was about to type cheese there!). Towards the finish it becomes drier, but still soft of the tongue, however the alcohol becomes more apparent at this stage. I put this off to the last of my recent American beer buy, but this was one of the better examples from the lot. Brilliant beer.

[Vintage 2003] A black beer with a chocolate brown collapsing head. The aroma is smoked yet sweet with notes of tar and blubber. The flavor is sour malty with notes of wood and only slightly smoked. But the alcohol runs over the tongue even though the mouthfeel is thin yet soft.
2003 vintage. Almost black coloured. Smoked aroma of bacon. The flavour is roasty, malty and smoked. Soft mouthfeel. Mild and pleasant.

Damn! I shouldve cellared this for a while....I have no patience. Last one I had was vintage 2000, I believe, this one is 2003: It pours with a rocky head thats  pretty small; not an overly smoked aroma, but its there; oh, man, this is good, rich maltiness followed by a lingering bitterness wrapped in camp fire smokiness; espresso and bittersweet chocolate flavors
; next time Ill get two and cellar one. cases, that is

God placed alder wood on this earth to make this beer.  A wonderful smoky aroma that curls up your nose.  It pours a black opaque with a small tan head.  The aroma is of beef jerky, campfire smoke, hickory sauce; smoky but kinda sweet.  The palate followed the nose with roasted, smoky flavors; burnt toast, beef jerky.  The bitterness was nice and sustained to balance the late sweetness/smoke.  A great/bold beer.

1998 reserve, yeaaaaaah boyeeeee!!!  thick and bready tan head that leaves quicly, but strong lacing stays all along the dges.  black body w/ brown/red edges.  beef jerky nose.  chocolate coffee flavor, slight jerky flavor.  super smooth hop exit and smoked malt aftertaste.  sauteed raisins flavor after warming.  nice fine carbonation for 6 years wait.  Id have scored the Adam better if the cigar flavor was more like the alaskans alder smoke flavor.
This beer is a delight. Dark/black body with a creamy tan head. Complex flavors. Licorice, chocolate, coffee,roasted malt. Smokey and delicious. One of the best smoked beers I have ever had.

Bottled.  Smoked ham aroma, jet black colour with no head.  The taste improves throughout the sample.  At first the smokiness and the oily roastiness seem disjointed and there is little balance, but with time the smokiness takes over, and that is a good thing!  A very good beer in its class although I have no doubt that this would not be everybody's thing.
Very dark brown with a small tan head. Smokey, meaty aroma. Flavor of malt and smoke. The smoke flavor is not the overpowering ashtray flavor that other smoked beers have.

This is one of those beers I've been aching to try for years, and, thanks to Liquid Solutions, I've got my chance.
I can smell the smoke before popping the cap, somehow...and it pours black as the wintry night sky, with a thick, toasted tan head atop.
Aroma hits it's mark immediately: SMOKE! Surprise, huh? With underlying...nah, I can't pick it up...I arch the old olfactory glands wider to perceive greater and clean the usual porteristic characterics and they're very well hidden underneath that smokeyness. Some of them are down there, somewhere, but they're totally dominated.
Taste: ...yup, it's all in the flavor, too! Very smooth and mellow, malt is full and damnit, wouldn't you know, that smoke effect is actually pretty tasty! And, mmmm, I'm tasting the cocoa and the coffee, too, just underneath.
Quite an interesting and enoyable beer, one that I'll make an effort to return to again and again, to see if I can pull out more from it. As for this big, beautiful bottling, I had quite a time.
Jet black with a tan head.  Nose is definitely smokey.  I usually don't care for smoked beers.  This one was good.  A little on the thin side.  The smokiness masks some essence of coffee and fruit.

Nose is heavy smoke with malts underneath. The appearance is darker  with active brown head and thin quickly discipating. Thaste is smokey but not offensive, malts in bakck with hops finish at the back of tounge.
Dark brown body with a thin beige head. Aroma is wood smoke and roasted malts. Flavour is smokey ,but not disgustingly so, with coffee bitterness. Finish is dry and acidic.
By far the best smoked porter I've come across. Deep in colour and nose, lots of body, and thick hardwood smoke throughout. Dry, bitter finish leaves palate refreshed and longing for more
Coffee colored with a small tan head. Hardwood smoke in the nose, with some caramel, licorice. Wonderfully smoky flavor overlaid upon a a medium sweet, chocolatey body. Ends with a nice bitterness.

473 mL bottle [2002, sampled in April 2004]: Perfect pour  English pint glass with a full creamy tan foam that tops off nicely at the brim.  Golden brown.  Sweet peaty aroma  bronzed ham, fiery embers and sweat fill an interesting, unique and strangely pleasant aroma.  Nicely carbonated and a perfect amount of smoke  airy smoke particles and enough malty porter flavour to keep me very happy.  Complexity increases as it warms. . . many different woody flavours and good bitterness, very well done.
This is a really good smoked porter, best I've ever tried.  Lots of burnt wood flavor and rich complexity.  give this one a try

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2005 2003 bottle.  Interesting stuff here.  At first I think, well they went and forgot about the beer.  But as it warmed and I sipped it, I picked up a lightly hoppy amber ale in the background, a nice distinct hops quality was definitely there.  Great smoke flavor, not quite as deep (well nowhere near really) as the aecht schlenkerla line.  Good though, medium light body is a big drawback.  19641968.  If you think this shit is good, try the aecht rauchbier urbock.  That stuff will rock your world.  This is practically unsmoked compared to that.  Still a good beer, but in need of a serious injection of malt.  Looks good, though its filtered.  Dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of light smokey bacon and burnt fat.  Its funny how some beers just hint at goodness and make you want to go out and buy the better example. I am off to purchase some aecht schlenkerla.

Jet black beer with a beige loose head.  Intense aroma of liquorice, smoke, 
kippers, roasted grain and a hint of alcohol.  The flavour starts smokey and burnt, but rounds out to a rich, smooth full palate and the finish is increasingly bitter although with a hint of sweetness and a full-on bonfire smoke and burnt toast taste.  Very complex and tasty beer which disguises it's strength well.  (sampled in bottle from Booth's supermarket, Knutsford, Cheshire)

This beer poured a dark black with a thin beige-colored head.  The smell was smoky but overdone, and the taste was roasty with just the right amount of smokiness.  This is a well done beer and one worth trying.

This one was unique. Take a porter, pour a bottle of liquid smoke into the glass, and you'd pretty much have this stuff. The heavy-handed smokiness of this brew made me think of a lot of things: smoked fish, smoked cheddar, and worst of all an ashtray. The beer smells old, aged, almost wise. The flavor has hints of chocolate and coffee but I can't seem to get past the smoke - it overrides everything.

Bottled 2003.  Poured clear, dark brown.  Black in the glass with minimal off-white head, quickly gone with no lacing.  Nose is predominantly smoke with caramel malts, pleasant soy, light coffee and something else, like uncooked bacon or other raw poultry(bananas as it warms).  Silky carbonation that softens up considerably to flat.  Sweetish undertones with smokey flavor, very roasty and bitter.  In the end, the body is meduim(watery character, but still thickish), like a porter ought, but until then it's very stoutish.  I assumed warming would help this beer a lot, but it was really better cold.  The carbonation died with warmth and the smokey//roasty bitterness with some coffee aftertaste(long lasting) began to unblance the beer.  Needs some work, but very enjoyable and somewhat complex.  I'll try another bottle to look for better carbonation.

2003 bottling.  Black, with just hints of translucence.  Meaty bacon-like smoked aroma. Chocolate malt flavor is quickly hijacked by substantial smoke character.  Decent sweet malt character, and moderate bodied.  Reasonably balanced, and I see its charms, but it's not the kind of beer I would seek out on a regular basis.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2007 2006: This year the beer strikes a nice balance between the smoked peat and the roasted malt. Superb.
2004: MUCH more smoke in this one compared to previous vintages. I was expecting the subtle smoke to be gently blended with a rich malty backbone. NO, not this time. 2004 is the year of the rauchbier. Crack the bottle and immediately the fumes of smoked peat hit the nose. Give me a second to adjust because this is not what I was expecting. The smokiness completely dominates the flavor and is thus quite one dimensional. My preference goes to the previous vintages which were much more complex and smooth. Not as smokey as Aecht (thank goodness) but I cant really enjoy much else about this one. But you know what? Its still a damn good beer. Cant wait til next year.
2003: Opaque brown/black in color. Thin brown head sits on top. Lightly carbonated. Aroma is mostly of roasted malt, small bit of smoke can be detected. This beer begins tasting like roasted malt and ends tasting like smoked bacon. This beer is extremely smooth going down. This finish is the best part about this beer. Leaves a real nice meaty/smokey taste in the mouth. Cant wait to crack open one of these next time I bbq.

Ok this is the 2003 version..comes in apint bottle with the caribou silloutted against an artic sundown.
Very very dark mahogany brown beer, almost on the verge of black, nice yet small tan head,,that goes fast to leave good lacing.
Well the aroma is pretty "sharp" you can certainlly make out some of the smokiness..its like a good smoked ham.
Mmmm this is a lovelly tasting beer IF you like Smoked stuff..I do..its niceand lightly ( compared to the Bamberg stuff) smoked in alder..you can certainly taste the woodiness..this has a rather dry finish, yet at the same time its sweet,Nice malts make a show,,thouigh its dominated by the smoke.
Very well done on the palte smooth despite the smokey acridness.
Nice drinking Smoked beer..very good.

2003 edition.  I'd been wanting to try this for years, but it just doesn't seem to make it out my way.  Dark stout like brown, good tan head that slowly fades.  Aroma is clearly smoked, quite reminiscent of a smoked cheese, with some bacon qualities.  Flavors are initially of roated malts, some coffee, and then a rapid twist into liquid bacon.  This is very nicely made, clearly smoked yet not totally overpowering.  The bacon notes have my stomach begging for eggs and grits.  It does get to be a bit much by the end of the glass, but this could be killer with food.
Massive smoke pouring from the bottle, made my clothes smell like campfire. BBQ'd pork flavor, with some dark, bitter chocolate notes. Good, but maybe slightly overdone.

Bottle from Safeway. Deeeeep smoky smell. Ominous black brew, with a sharply receding small, brown head. Very strong smoked flavour, like crispy bacon biscuits, and a lingering dry, charcoal finish. This is rich stuff, and hints athe ABV in the finish. Seems more like a stout to me, and a pretty good one, albeit aggressive.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2005 Aroma is dark chocolate and smoke. Appearance is classic porter, or black with brown hue. Flavor is smoke at initial sip, smoke during sip, smoke after sip. After letting the sip seep into the tastebuds a very fine porter exists with sweet dark chocolate and coffee in even amounts. The palate is overpowered by smoke. Overall my first smoked brew, I was expecting a mild smoke flavor not a forest fire. I would love to try their straight porter.

black brownish black, like brownies.  Smells like smoke, Damn, it smells like my shirt after a basement party, and it has some wood in it.  A big oak charcol smokey burnt sugar feel to it, dont sound good, yet is good, very good. Reminds me of the sauna, the smell of that wood burning.
Dark, hardly any light shows.  Loads of wood smoke in this nose.  Taste is quite smoky, dry and hoppy with a great roasty character.  Very good.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2006 Thanks to jeffc666 for this one! Black with very deep reddish borders. Nose is smoky! Go figure. But theres a little bit more to it. Definitely some burning wood and smoked or processed meat added into the fray. This had a little more hop to it that made it more pleasurable to drink than the Aecht Schlenkerla stuff. Finish is more smokiness and some lighter hoppiness. 

Granted I have already rated this but I had a 1993 Vintage at GABF 2006 and I wrote down a one line rating - FUCKING INCREDIBLE. Nuff said.

Bottle.  Poured dark ebony brown and opaque with a small tan head that diminished yet lingered well.  Aroma is smokey (of course) dark roasted malts, molasses and some hoppiness.  Flavor is rich, sweet, charcoal, tart hops and a lingering bitter finish.  Mouthfeel is smooth, full and lightly carbonated.  Definitely smokey and flavorful.

Bottle:  fairly typical porter look.  Deep, dark brown with a smallish medium brown head.  Aroma was smoky, but not overly so.  Flavor of mostly smoke, but somehow it did not overpower.  Next to no bitterness.  Mild chocolate and roastiness.  A very nice brew.

Very dark. Ruby highlights flashed occassionally, but this was dark enough to be a stout. The head was weak and dissipated quickly. The aroma was smoky, but it wasn't overpowering. I'm not a big smoke fan, so this was a positive. The smoke actually worked nicely in the beer as it melded with the malts nicely. Smoked chocolate and a bit of pear flashes as the beer warms.

I am a lover of a porters and Rauchbiers, so with that said... this beer was made for me.  I really liked the smokey/roasted malt aroma from the first pop of the cap to the end of the glass. Alot more hops than I was anticipating.  Smooth chewy roasted barley flavor with a smoked malt profile, that was not over the top.  I suggest serving this warmer to get the fully monty of flavors that eminate from this one...I think that this would pare nicely with a good steak !

Holy salty pork grinds batman! This smells an awful lot like bacon, salt and pork grinds combined. Definite smoky aspects, dark brown color with significant carbonation and a semi-long lasting soapy head of a slight off orange color. Very full of flavor. Heavy salts and smokes...good roasts. Dry, salty finish, slight tingle of sourness. Very pleasant... This was aged since 1999 so the aging absolutely did wonders. PS... THANKS MITCH~

(2000) Dark, thick looking beer under minimal to zero head.  Smoke is readily apparent in the air and I'm glad there isn't much head or it might be nauseatingly pungent.  Hops only show up in bitterness as this porter is mostly reminding me of burnt malts.  Dry bitter finish.  I think this beer would definitely benefit from some rest in a cellar.

I liked this Smoked Porter its a very well balanced.  Pours Jet Black.  At first taste it reminded me of Smoked Italian Mozzarell.  Smokey, malty, coffee, and lite fruit flavor.  Finnishes smooth, dry, and clean.  Recommended.

This porter pours with a dark brown to black body topped by a medium thick creamy tan head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is full of smokiness with subtle hints of malt, coffee and chocolate.  The flavor is smokey and malty with a touch of roasted coffee.  Medium to full bodied, smooth and slighlty dry.

Black like an Alaskan winter's night.  Mega-thin beige head.  Harsh woodsmoke aroma, like a bottle of artificial smoke-flavored liquid was dumped into my brew.  This so-called "alder-smoking" technique Alaskan Brewing uses is certainly potent, whatever it is.  Roastiness is simply massive, but the smokiness dominates even that.  There's a hint of coffee here, as well.  What makes this beer interesting is the dichotomy between its thinness and the strength of its flavors.  This is indeed more of a porter than a stout.  I can see some hardcore rauchbier lovers getting into this beer.  Look for the subtle whiff of bacon when you taste it.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2004 2003 Vintage sampled Jan 04 Bottle. Jet black, thin beige head, moderate condition. Excellent smokey aroma from the start with chocolate and roasted barley developing with time and a slight beefiness. Hugely smokey in the mouth with a slight metallic edge and some roast barley, but the chocolate and hops of last years batch are much more muted in the 2003. Roasted dryness in the mouth with a lingering hint of woodsmoke. Hugely more enjoyable than the 2002 vintage, much more pronounced sweet smokiness all round. 2002 Vintage sampled Jan 04 8-3-8-3-16 3.8 Bottled, jet black, low beige head and moderate condition. Fruity aromas with hints of berries, roast barley chocolate and coffee, some smokey phenols noticable but at low level. Harsh woodsmoke initialy in the mouth but balanced by some sweet chocolate and roast barley. Sweet in the finish with strange lingering hint of cola. Same batch as previous tasting, hope the remaining five bottles don't go downhill at the same rate. 2002 Vintage sampled May 03  8-3-9-4-17 4.1 Bottled. Black, moderate beige head and moderate condition. Complex aromas that began with dominant chocolate and roast barley that then developed a delicate smokey edge with a resinous herbal note as it warmed. In the mouth the chocolate and roast barley were more apparent that the smoke but it still made its way through into the finish but the roast barley dryness lingered longest in the earthy finish.

Why is this not a top 50 beer? Amazing brew - knocked my socks off. Charcoal nose, dark brown color, low frothy head. Roasted malt with burnt and smokey flavors dominating. Espresso-like finsih. Thinish, but a great great balance. Thanks, Joe!
Great tribute to Shell and Joe who made it possible to drink it. Black big foamy head. Hazelnut creamy. Chocolate flavor. Smoked, like tabacco.

2002 bottle: Smokey ham aroma. Balanced smokey chocolate palate smooth, lingering smoke flavour mildly bitter finish. Starts subtly builds up to a great whack of flavour and then slowly peters out and your ready for another mouthful. Just great.

Deep dark brown, almost black. Diminishing tan head and lace. Nice aroma of smoke, sweet malt, hints of bread, coffee and chocolate. Medium bodied, not quite watery texture, well pronounced smoky flavor, lots of black malt, tangy peat. a bit astrigent but a tasty brew nonetheless.
robust taste mild hint of chocolate and nicely smoked hops and it pours a great head real winner here considering i dont like porters

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2004 2003 16oz bottle-sampled with whaleman.  Pours jet black with nice tan head.  very oily.  Lots of peat smoke, chocolate, slight coffee in the aroma.  Lots of smoked bacon/salt in the aroma.  nice palate-thick and viscous.  Flavor was alot like the aroma-both went hand in hand.  As it warmed, some more chocolate notes came out.  Thanks to whaleman for sharing this one and Buck-dich for send this one our way.
2004-22oz bomber-I must agree with Buck_Dich.  The flavor and aroma on this years is less smokey.  I would have to say that its more chocolate-y and more balanced.  I think that the huge smoke from the 03 was better than this years.  The palate didnt seem as thick as last years.  Still good, but lets see how this vintage ages....
Bottled. Black with a lovely light brown head. Wow!! Toasty, big flavoured. Lovely. Wish I had more of the stuff.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2005 Oily pour and pitch black body. Aroma is of chocolate and meaty smoke. Intoxicating and alluring smell. Tastes like it was cooked on a camp fire. Very roasty malt flavor with subtle hops underneath. Nice full palate. Improves substantially as it warms. Ive had the pleasure of sampling this beer on multiple occasions and I find myself frequently craving it. This is a classic.
Nice dark beer. Smelled purely of smoke and tasted the same way with a syrupy hint.  Reminds me when i was a young buck trekking the plains of nebraska

2003-Opaque black with a reddish-brown hue on the edges.  Head disappeared quickly.  Aroma is smokey with hints of chocolate.  Taste is pretty much the same.  I also taste a little bit of molasses.  A very well balanced beer.  Nice carbonation and good mouthfeel.  Definately top notch.

2003 Vintage, bottle pours black and thick.  I held it up to a lamp; I saw no light.  There was very little head.  The aroma was sweet and smoky.  The flavor is very nice.  Yes, there is the smoky finish, but it is a pleasant culinary smoke, like that of fine smoked salmon.  The palate is quite rich and smooth.  Overall, this porter puts me at so many fire rings I been around with so many friends in the past.  Very good, very nice, I need to order more.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 In my opinion, a perfect beer for the style. Pours a wonderful ash colored head. Smoke flavor without being TOO smoky. Id like to see them make a smoked beer without it being a porter. Just a great brew.

2003: Opaque black color with a small tan head. Strong smoked wood aroma with a hint of sweet dark fruit. Bittersweet chocolate, sweet dark fruit, and strong smoked wood flavors. Very nice smooth, creamy palate with just the right amount of carbonation.

2002: Near black with mahogany highlights.  A medium tan head.  Strong smoke aroma with soy, chocolate, roast and raisin in the background.  Medium creamy palate with light carbonation, very smooth.  Huge semisweet smoke flavor with hints of dark fruit, chocolate and soy.  A long smoke filled finish.  I really enjoyed this one, but it is not something I could drink often.  It was more of a novelty than anything else.  Thanks to Slikwily for this one!

Black with a medium tan head. No lacing. Huge smoke aroma, just like a Rauchbier. Reminds me of the Aecht Schlenkerla brews. Also has some good roasted malt aroma. Flavor is complex, smoked malts, roasted sweet malts and subtle chocolate and coffee flavors. Smooth body and overall a nice brew. Way more smoky than Stone's smoked porter. Nice brew! Thanks CaptainCougar!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: A good dark pour, with a roasty and, of course, smokey aroma.  The smoke is stonger in the flavor, in an almost unbalanced way.  Flavor finishes initially sweet, quickly followed by a good hop rush.  A wonderful beer, and one that will mellow and improve.

Bottle. 2003. dark (not quite black) body with a cocoa colored head that disapates quickly. Aroma isn't as strong as I'd thought. Faint roastiness with a hint of chocolate. The flavor is a fantastic smokey/chocolate/cofee/caramel/creaminess that tingles the tongue. The smoke doesn't overpower, but blends very well (the high alcohol content helps and makes it's presense known). Very smooth and drinkable. Very good beer.

Excellent roasty/smokey aroma, along with some light chocolate/molasses greet the nostrils.  Appearance is equally delightful, very dark brown with a very fluffy light brown head that is fully retained.  There will be significant lacing to accompany this experience.  Flavor is initially very smokey and there is heavy smoke throughout, however there are other elements at play here as well.  There are some hop flavors in the middle, then the smokiness takes over in the finish again.  Very enjoyable.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2004 Vintage 2003, Sampled June 2004
This is not nearly as smoky in the aroma as the 1998 that I just sampled.  It is much fuller and thicker on the palate as well.  It is still quite smoky, but here there is a lot of beer to back up  and balances the smokiness.  This is a nice full beer that is quite rounded.  I must admit that this is much more enjoyable when fresh.  As my palate gets adjusted, I get notes of a sweet malt profile that comes to the forefront.  The finish of this beer dries out considerably because of the pervasive smoke character.
Vintage 2002, Sampled November 20, 2003This beer is one those few, rarely in a life time, mind expanding beers for me.  When I first tried this elixir I was blown away, I was changed forever, and it ultimately lead me to the smoked beer paradise of Bamberg.  This beer will always have a place in my beer sodden soul.Pours a deep dark brown (mostly a black), when roused it produced a dense thick head.  The smoked aroma is immediately apparent as I pour from the bottle to the glass.  There is an aroma of chocolate hidden beneath the smoke.  As I push my lips through the creamy head I get to the elixir beneath.  It is nice & smooth, with definite notes of chocolate and a nice just perceptible pleasing sweetness.  the smoke flavor is not as strong in this slightly aged sample as I remember in fresh versions.  Fairly muted roast character in this porter, the predominant dark malt flavor is of chocolate malt.  The smoke permeates this beer, and it helps to add to a perceived smoothness and a roundness to this beer.  A very well integrated flavor.  this is a classic beer that all beer enthusiasts need to sample at least once.
Vintage 1998, Sampled June 2004
A very smoky aroma wafts from my glass.  This is just intensely aromatic.  The taste reminds me of smoked salmon (sans any fishy component of course).  Any signs of oxidation are clearly not evident, which makes sense as smoke is a good anti-oxidant.  This is much lighter on the palate than when it is fresh.  There is a smooth malty character in the background that is dry and meaty.  The smooth smoke phenolics are dominating in this beer from start to finish.

I know this is supposed to be a family show and what not, but this stuff is fucking awesome!  A quite perfect aroma, that smells of a smokehouse and would go nicely with barbecue, ribs, and steak.  Aroma nicely compliments the the flavor, with a big smokey nose and a flavor that is pefectly roasted, with alot of toffee and caramel, backed by lots of chocolate and coffee roastiness.  Bittersweet finish, that is good to the last drop.

Bottle 2002 vintage: Good nose. Smoke, roasted malt. Nice clean reddish dark brown color.  Little head, disappeared quickly. Smoke, coffee, chocolate in the flavor. Nice smokey, roasty, bitter finish. Very drinkable. A good porter with great smoke flavor.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Black on the pour, head was pretty small, but it did leave some nice lacing.  Aroma is roasty, coffee and bittersweet chocolate.  Pretty standard porter taste with just a slight hint of smoke.
Color is a dark brown with a very small head.  Aroma is mainly coffee and some smoke.  Flavor is roasted coffee and smoke.  Body is medium.

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2017 Bottle (2016 vintage).

Head is initially average sized, frothy, brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark brown to black.

Aroma is moderately malty (roasted grain, dark chocolate), lightly hoppy (flowers), with a note of smoke (wood/meat).

Flavor is moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly alcoholic.

One of very few decent beers from this brewery. The smoke character is plenty noticeable, albeit not as strong as a Rauchbier. Not a lot of depth, and the drinking experience leaves a bit to be desired (kinda watery), but its solid enough.
[2002 Vintage] Very dark black with a small tan head. Huge smokey aroma. Very strong and very pleasant smell. Even bigger smokey flavor. Medium body. This beer is quite nice.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2007 This a beer Ive seen a lot of write ups about in many a food magazine.  Pour dark, stoutish, almost black.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor is smokey.  I can imagine drinking this and eating some fresh smoked salmon, what a meal that would be.  Finish is sweet and smokey.  Very good beer.

2002 bottled edition- Very, very dark brown color overall with deep ruby highlights within its realm of dark fog when held up to the light. Thin cocoa brown head that subsides quickly and leaves clear spotty lace. Smell has lots of good sweet roastyness to it, deep and rich, thick sweetened chocolate layered on top of heavily roasted malts, small hops and a hint of smokey woodish earth lightly showing up as it warms with a note of coffee in it. Taste is smooth and roasty sweet, light bitter sweet chocolate, lightly tangy sweet roasted malts. Well rounded and soft, a small amount of hops pleasantly keeps a nice bittering bite and balance over the roasty sweetness. Some coffeeish senses along with a gentle effervescense of smokeyness sneaks its way past the roasty sweetness as well. There's some dark fruity bread chewyness that reminds of a x-mas favorite of mine, a dark marble rye-cinnamon-cherry bread that makes it a pleasing memorable experience for me. Its not overly complex, it has very subtle qualities and when served at the desired warmer temp the smokey characteristics become a bit more noticeable, but never enough to overwhelm. Feel is smooth and creamy, medium, close to full body, lightly chewy aspect with a sticky roastyness covering the tongue and mouth in the finish; my favorite part of this beer, or for any porter for that matter. A very smooth drinkin' porter that goes down pretty easy. Its not quite as bold or rich as some, but its a definate keeper; worth the effort of finding and a must try for all.
This is a one of those big beers. Dark brown with a frothy tan head. Smooth as silk, sweet and not too smokey. Only Fullers London Porter has more flavors. Yum
2001. Very dark brown with thin tan head. Smoky aroma with a hint of coffee. Full mouthfeel and subdued smokiness. Not as smoky as a Stone smoked porter. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2003 nice thick body and nice aroma.  more 'rural' than the rauchbier, if that makes any sense, i guess it smells more grainy, organic, farmy...well, it is excellent.  but i had to give it only a slightly above average score because it didn't grab me, or keep me, no matter how many i had.  not smokey enough for me.  i guess that's it.  not imported to NY state (another one)

2001: Black hue with an average tan head and no lacing. Very smokey aroma with hints of molasses and espresso. Nice balanced taste, smooth and not overpowering. Hint of tobacco and pumpernickel on the palate. Very dry and soft mouthfeel. Good but not great, a tad overrated IMO.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2014 2002: Pitch black with a dark tan head.  Big smoked wood nose with some coffee aromas as well.  Even bodied, with a smoked wood (and fish) profile that is not overdone.  Very robust and dry, grainy, with some interesting cigar, plum, and cedar flavors.  Finish is slightly dry and quite sweet.  Only noticeable difference in the 2001 bottle was it had mellowed slightly, as expected.
Hard to drink much as it is very rich, but a great beer with smoked almonds. I always pick some up in the fall or winter for those cold winter nights. Great Beer1

I've been letting this bottle sit in my fridge for a while, so I hope it's not like the young bottle I had around Christmas, tasting of smoked ham. Hmmm...this is definitely better. Very smokey - almost a Rauchbeer. Some very nice hints of espresso and dark chocolate prevent the smoke flavor from overwhelming the palate, but allow it to be very robust nonetheless. Nicely rounded, but I'd like to see just a touch more of the espresso/chocolate coming through. Smoked malt is just so intense, it's a bit difficult to handle on it's own.

honey-glazed ham aroma. pretty intense aroma, like sheaf stout if they actually tried to make it smell nasty. rather than extra hops or extra alcohol like most american beers have, this one has extra burnt flavours. flavour softens after a while - ham on rye, maybe there's a depressing book about it. and thankfully the tangy hops don't bland out the finish

This is a very nice porter. Great smoked aroma and taste. I've never had anything quite like it. The nice smoke flavor doesn't overpower the taste but is definitely apparent. Poured very dark brown with tan head that dissolved quickly. Not much lacing to speak of.
This went very well, (ok it's actually going very well, since I'm drinking this with dinner as I rate it? with my pork chop dinner. This is a Must try brew. This was a 2002 and I wonder how much better it could have been If I just let it age, but alas, I love to try new stuff, and this was well worth waiting for.
Thanks to slikwily for providing it.

Wood smoked ham nose.  Black hue with a creamy light brown head.  A mass of complex different flavours.  Coffee chocolate, roasted malt all dominated by the rich smoked malt flavour.  A great complex ale that would not impress any one other than a real disserning ale drinker.

A nice one. Lovely sausagy/hammy aroma and flavour, coupled with some nice roasty/ashyness, some nice chocolate and caramel flavours linger about aswell. A tasty, yet quite subtle smoked porter, i liked this very much.

(2001)smoked meat aroma, coffee and hops. Pours opaque black, carbonation and head are minimal. Thin up front, smokey(burnt wood), sweet flavours come through. Finish is very nice, smooth, tingly alcohol delivery. Not really hoppy. A solid beer.

2001 bottle.  The aroma is strong and calls to you strongly out of the glass.  Hard to describe the smell except that it makes me crave an Alberta Steak.  Light head that maintains a ring around the glass.  Dark brown/black colour with just a hint of light coming through.  Almost stout-like in its dry subtle flavour.  Very nice flavour, finish and body.  The smokiness builds as you drink and the beer warms as opposed to a number of beers that shock initially and then mellow out.  A strong overall beer.
mild smoky aroma, dark black hue with off white head, initially very smoky developing into a sweet fruity malt finish, full bodied, very good stuff
GABF '02 Rumor had it that this was the grand daddy of smoked porters and it is. I had high expectations going into this beer and it didn't disapoint one bit.
Nice smoke flavor, in a lovely dark brown beer.  The envy of other smoked porters.  If you are gonna try a smoked porter, this is the one.
(vintage 2002)Intense smoke and malt in the aroma.  The smoke flavor is upfront and swirls around with the chocolate to a slight bitterness.
Near opaque, like cola. Aroma of caramel and smoke. Taste of well smoked, nutty, malt and vanilla. Somewhat bitter finish. Very good!
Bottled 2002. Poured and smelled good. To smoky for me. To overpowering.

Dark stoutish appearance, but the beer soon goes flat.  The is aroma smoked with deeply burn't and bitter aspects.  The flavour is lighlty smoked with a bitter/watery finish.  A reasonable beer, probably better if you like smoked beers.

(Vertical tasting with 1998 - 2000 samples. Points given above are 2002. 1998 between brackets below.)
Colour: Deep brown - nearly black. Brown yellow head ['98 identical but more pearling inside the glass, and more stable head- 4] Nose yields rich chocolate, mocca, grapes, ripe plums whilst pouring; settled the smoked and cured hamodour raises up - also a nose of glycerine soap.[Chocolate, plums, spicey -cardemom peel- whilst pouring. The smokiness here is really smoked baconrind, sharper. No soapy smell - 8] Rich smoked flavour. definitely wood, also pipe tobacco. Mmm, this IS good. ['98: all the above, but more subdued. There is surprisingly more sweetness apparent. strange, in taste I prefer the younger version - 7] Both obviously very rich mouthfeel. ['98 seems lighter at first, but equals out after a while - 4] Long bitter finish; bitter chocolate, hops, coffee. the younger beer seems somewhat less bitter. 
I can understand why M.J. bombarded this brew into a world classic. It gives the best from both Porter and Rauchbier styles. Holy smoke! [17]

Not as smokey as some of the German smoked beers this is nevertheless a fine beer.It reminds me of slightly burnt chocolate with a very pleasant mouth feel. Thinner in taste than I expected it is still a complex and interesting beer without reaching the hights that I expected.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2003 Now available in Safeway supermarkets in the UK - this award winning and inspirational smoked beer from the Alaskan microbrewery founded in 1986, has proved popular enough to win mass votes for best beer lists on the internet. Malt smoked over alder-wood fires is the key to this beer, and there's a smoke taste for sure, along with a stouty roast malt. The mouthfeel is firm and fat with a little lemon zest. The aroma is soapy at first, then dies away. Flavours can be teased out through the intense smoked malt - an array of fruits that often slip out of reach: now bannana, now strawberry, now lemon. But the combination of all this is dull rather than exciting. A huge, lumbering bear of a beer. That said - it is good ... just, not that good.

Pitch black with a coffee-with-milk coloured head.  Aroma is smokey with a touch of licourice.  Flavours are smokey, coffee and dark chocolate.  Good bitterness at the finish, too.  A damned fine beer!

(2001) Opaque black in color with a bold beige colored head.  Aroma was very smokey and peppery....like beer jerky!  Nice!  Very full in flavor....lots of smoke and alcohol.  Just an all around great beer that does the style justice....would go perfect with a steak dinner.

Bottle.  Chad thoroughly enjoys this beer.  Quite rich, almost imperial stout-ish.  The smokiness really comes through in the aroma and flavor, right until the finish.  Yeah.  Nice appearance, opaque with a big tan head.  The imperial stout of porters!
2002 Bottle.  Milky sweet aroma.  CHocolatey.  Dark and opaque.  Basic porter with good chocolate flavors and a smooth drinkability.  I am barely getting smoked flavors.  Delicious.
Impressive with a creamy head. Very black in color and a nice smoky finish.

Very black color; head was tan with good density; not as annoyingly smoky in the nose as I would have expected. Wonderful chocolate hit in the first sip. None of that "dirt" flavor I get from most porters. Very satisfying. Smoke is not a huge presence.
Nice dark color with light brown head.  Good smell.  Awsome rich porter taste followed by the mysterious smokey after taste.  Great beer.

One hell of a beer. Sometimes I swear I can taste a bit of smoked salmon in this. Almost opaque dark brownish black color with a thick tan head that slowly subsided to a thin ring. Smoky malt aroma. Smoky, malty, roasty flavors abound. Bitter at first, then smoke, malt, and a faint chocolate. Moderate acidity. Medium mouthfeel, carbonation. Coats my mouth with smoky deliciousness! Finishes dry. Smoothes out nicely with aging.
It's an average smoked porter. It's robust, creamy, and smoky. I like it.
I'm not a fan of smoked beers. That being said, this one does a good job of...being smoked. Creamy and malty, definitely robust. Definitely has a most appropriate "bite".

Very creamy and smoky porter. Has a bit of a sharp, cedary taste in there somewhere. Tasteful hops finish it off. The smoke notes seem to play with more a heavy bass timbre than the Stone Smoked Porter, which I actually prefer. Nice porter overall.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2004 2/27/2004, 2002 bottle:  Aroma still has a great smokey presence, even after aging a year.  Body is semi-sweet with some heavily roasted bitter notes.  Crisp, dry warming finish.  Still a nice smoked porter, but could use some finesse in the body.

2/2/2003, 2002 bottle: Heavily smoked aroma more so than Stone Smoked Porter.  This has a sweet malty flavor which is well balanced with a light bitterness.  The mouthfeel is silky and very smooth.  This finishes dry and woody and leaves me wanting more.

Smokey aroma and quite a dark beer.  It has a thick mouthfeel with the smoke evident as somewhat sweet initially, then fading into a dry bitterness.  Slightly grassy and tart.  Bigger ester palate than the smoked lagers I've tried previously.

2002 bottle. Dark brown color with hints of red at the edges. Intense smokey aroma...sweet up front. The flavor was sweet and smokey back and forth. Slight bitterness in the finish, but really I just got smoke from this thing. Thick feel for a porter...nice...creamy.

(2002)As close to perfect as it gets for me.  Chocolate smores by a campfire!  VERY dark in color and not at all able to see through it.  Great head...smoke colored.  Not as overpowering in smoke as the 2001 was.  Small bite of hops but mainly malt in flavor.  VERY enjoyable and the thing that makes seasonal brews the best is that you want them MORE when they aren't in season.  I'm going to swoop up as much as i can before they are gone!!
black with tan head.  roasty, malty, smoky aroma.  not as much smoke as I expected, the flavour was okay, though -  smoke, cocoa, roasty malt.  I'll have to try this again.
Over rated ... what a waste of $$$
Dark brown.  Smokey, almost meaty nose.  Good amount of smoke in the body with a big malty, bitter finish.  Nice smoked porter.

It is nice to see that this beer aroma was nice and softly smoky, nothing over the board. Sadly this was not repeated with the flavour. It was overwhelmed with that smokiness that there was no place left for coffee, bitterness, malt etc. Another one dimensional extreme.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2005 January 8, 2005
Opened a 1998 Smoked Porter. Its still in great shape. The fantasic aroma is still there, the body had mellowed a bit. This is from a 4 pack I bought at the brewery which contained the following vertical (1998, 1999, 2000, 2001)

January 17, 2003
Beautiful smokey, deli, aroma, like good smoked sausage. Jet black w/ a tan. It has a little bite on the tongue
An incredible beer, black and rich - chocolate, malty and that great smokey flavor.  Wonderful with oysters.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2004 2002 Edition: Smells of dark roasted coffee with thoughts of chocolate. Light malt and moderate hop esters. Hints of raisons and wood. Pours dark black with tan head, head does very well. Taste is a little overwhelming at first. Huge flavor, very sweet and even more bitter. All you can think is mesquite. Reminded me of a nice smoked salmon. Flavor calms down in the finish and it is very pleasent, a very well rounded porter. Medium to full body with a creamy feeling on the palate. Soft carbonation and overall well tasting, but not my style.

Update: I'm going to buy a case of this shit and store it until real camping season. This is great, I love smoked beers now and I can't wait to get my grubby little hands on a ton of this stuff.

2004: A bit more acidic than last year but still smoky, perhaps thin?

Dark pour with a thin tan head.Beef jerky aroma.At first sip there is some sweetness that quickly turns to apple wood bacon. Not my brew. I think I will leave the smoked brews for someone else and stick to my stouts.

(2002) Near black body with small mocha head.  Aroma is chocolate at first, complemented by straightforward smokiness as it warms.  Taste is light chocolate up front, some roastiness.
