Toward the back of the throat, the smokiness begins blending in, but ultimately takes over the other tastes.  It carries into the aftertaste, but doesn"t linger.  Rich body.  Maybe it"s because my expectations were too high, but I wasn"t blown away by this beer as I expected to be.  Don"t get me wrong -- it"s a very good beer.  It just misses the greatness I expected to find.

Nice tight, brown head that doesnt hang real long, but there is a small ring of foam to the bottom of the glass.Big smokey nose!Color is a very nice dark brown with dark red highlights showing up as i hold it to the light, nice.Really gettin more drinkable as it warms.The smoke flavor is not overwhelming,also tasting some chocolate malt in the background and maybe some black malt bitterness? Body is medium full.Very interesting brew. On the bottle it says you can age this brew. I might try that? I,d like to thank merc for gettin these brews to me in a timely fashion also.Thanks merc, good doin buiseness witcha!

I got a few of these on trade and i have only one thing to say for this beer and thats "what a beer" nice head,malty,smoky in aroma and flavor finish had a malty lite smoke aftertaste nothing better,for those cold nights when the t.v. is boring

At the end of a great eve sampling single malts the host gave me one of these to try. Yum. To be able to conquer the coating on my tongue was something this did with ease. I only hope I enjoy it as much the next time. Very pleasant smokiness to go with a solid porter.

2002 edition.  Some head, with only a trace ring remaining long.  Strange aroma with various strains coming through: one strain like a cream soda, one like a fortified wine.  Gentle smoked flavor, rather enjoyable (I am predisposed to like this flavor, and I suppose that matters more than anything with this kind of beer.)  The flavors didnt blossom much as it warmed--I expected the opposite, but this was somewhat dull.  Nice palate, somewhat creamy yet with tingling carbonation.  Really lovely.

For such a full bodied style Im surprised at how strongly the smokiness comes through. Its almost rauchbier like in aroma, with distinct sweet smoked malts on the palate. Creamy chocolate and coffee flavors also come through but are repressed a little by the smokiness.

(26Dec2002--on tap) Interesting beer.
Opaque, very thin, receding, non-lacy head.
Beer is almost completely lacking in carbonation, which hampers it severely.  
Perhaps the bar where I sampled this beer is to blame; I will try a bottle ASAP and re-rate.
Not particularly aromatic, though smoke and higher alcohols are present as the beer warms.
Flavor dominated by smoke, with roasty malts also quite present.  
Oily.  Like
Black Butte Porter, flavorful, but not particularly complex.
Bitterness commensurate with sweetness.
I had heard so much about this beer. When I tried it, it was very disappointing. Guess I just dont like the smoked style

The aroma is malty-sweet and filled with mesquite or hickory smoke. Basically, the beer smells like hickory smoked beef jerky! I know this because I eat the stuff all the time. Being a fan of rauchbiers, I really enjoy this type of aroma. Small notes of milk chocolate and coffee; however, the smoke is definitely king here.
This extremely dark, sparkling crimson beer has a small, creamy, khaki colored head. Mostly diminishing.
The stuff even tasted a bit like hickory smoked beef jerkey. It is full of rich, dark roasted malt with heavy smoke and chocolate dominating up front. Perfectly balanced, as the herbal hop bitterness kicks in on the backside.
Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel. Soft carbonation. Medium-length, lightly bitter-sweet, smokey finish. Great beer. Not for everyone. I you dont like rauchbiers, you wont like this smoked porter either. Nothing like Stones smoked porter.
I really like it! I wonder if that goes back and touches some of my germanic roots.  Smokey sausage and a great beer IN ONE!  Real smokey with some great notes of spices too.
smoky roasted aroma, could really use more porter, as Las Vegas Clair exclaimed "That beer is so funky, I can still taste it" personally I just cant stand sausagey beers

2002: Finally...Ive waited a long time to try this.  Dark, almost black with a brown head.  Smells of smoke (duh).  Great velvety, chewy, smoky mouthfeel. The flavor is not as smoky as I expected, but provides a nice backdrop to what is obviously a well made porter.  Thanks to herbjones.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2004 2001:Almost black with a frothy lacey,creamy head.Stays well above average till the end.Lightly roasty,smokey,chocolate,hop aromas.Smoke is subtle and in the background.Slightly vinous also.Palate seemed awfully watery at first,but for the subtelty of this beers flavor,quickly turned,perfectly velvety.Malts and subtle hop are followed by such a subtle smokiness with a rich,oily,sweet finish.Hops seem to come out in the finish as well about half way down.So sublime.I really like it that it was a pint bottle.I was expecting a 12oz.The best smoked porter I have had,so far.
Smokey hoppy chocolate arama.Dark reddish brown aroma.Bitter hops then fireplace smoke then chocolate flavors.Creamy dry hop finish.
Very big and complex beer.Notes of chocolate and subtle hints of carmelized fruits.Very rich smokey flavor.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2003 2002 a black beauty with a thin layer of tan lacing..aroma was of roasted malts, cola like tipping subtly smokey..smokiness comes out strong in the flavor riding a semi-full bodied wave of roasty notes..strong smokey aftertaste..meaty, like beef jerky..there's also fruitiness in the background hinting at peaches & raspberries..its just missing that special kick..could use some more hop bitterness

2001: Dark brown to black. Opaque. Large tan head. Smoky aroma with some malt. Bread, yeast, and some hops in the nose. Wonderfully balanced flavor of smoky malt, firm bitterness, mild roast, and faint chocolate. Very creamy and full-bodied. If it has a flaw, its too much smoke. Tastes like the smoking room at the Big O Fish House smells and thats not a bad thing. A damn fine beer.
This was great. 2002 or 01 bottle. Very smokey strong scent. Somewhat sweet, but balanced well with the dark burnt taste. Cant wait for the vertical tasting in a few weeks. Thatll be a rerate.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2003 Rating #1 Bottle of the 2001 release with a 6.5% abv (7 4 8 3 16).  Black color with a brown head.  The aroma is clearly smoked but also has a sweet malty character.  Rating #2 of the 2002 vintage with 6.1% abv (8 4 8 4 17).  Dark brown to black color with a dark brown head.  A dark roasted aroma with chocolate and a light smoke tint throughout the nose that grows more intense as the beer warms.  A full bodied beer with plenty of chocolate and rich malt flavor and an enjoyable lingering smoke.

GABF 2002: Ive waited a long time to try this beer.  Very dark black but showing alot of red at the edges.  Rich chocolatey and malty aroma.  Plenty of campfire smoke in the nose. Very well balanced dark malt flavors with medium smokiness.  Smooth.  Outstanding.

1999 - Black color, medium head. Smoky aroma. An intense smoky flavor. Beer is made with ‘alder smoked’ hops. Very malty, very intense smoky flavor. Finish is smooth. Aftertaste is smoky and malty. Amazing beer.

2001:  Wow!  I was hoping to get some smoked meat qualities, but instead I got Barleywine toffee and Baltic Porter dark fruit, coconut, and maple.  Still a moderately smoky nose, though more understated then Aecht Schlenkerla.  Perfectly balanced aroma  also incorporates smoked bacon, charcoal, chocolate, charred malt, and a perfect blanket of fruity hops.  Did I mention the tan creamy foam?  The body starts more thinly than I wanted, but the flavors compensate nicely;  licorice and wood are in the forefront.  Rich chocolatey, smokey, coffeeish, and notably dry finish; velvety carbonation; clearly bottle conditioned.  Overall a darn good example of the style.  I just needed more raunchy bacon stink in the nose, more assertive smoked flavors, and a heftier body.  A perfect digestif.  I am off to the stote to grab some Smoked Gouda.  Thanks, Mom!
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: If you like smoked beer (or cheese) you need to try this one.  Strong smoke flavor and filling... comes in 25+ oz , and should be shared.

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2011 Rerate Revisiting this classic after nine years. Just did not quite get the whole smoked concept that early in my rating days.  2010 version - dark black pour, sticky off-white head. Salty, briny aroma of smoked oysters and cured meat. Flavor follows along the same lines - excellent smoked beer. Thickish mouthfeel. I feel as if my journey is complete. Original 3.0 This is probably a very good example of a smoked beer - but the style just did not appeal to me.  I felt as if I was drinking a tin of smoked oysters. It looks good - dark and thick with a heavy head - but I just could not get over the saltiness. I had the 2001 version of this.

Aroma:  Smokey, charred wood; roasted malt aroma with a touch of espresso and sugar.

Flavor:  A curious creamy-yet-chalky texture; lightly sweet with a thread of anise and dried nuts. Smokey, charred wood flavor cannot be missed, but not as strong as I anticipated. Actually lends a kind of stout-like flavor and quality to this beer. Eventhough fairly strong at 6.5% alcohol by volume, a very smooth performer and quite inviting to drink in quantity. Do not, however, serve this beer at refrigerator temperature. Serve at 55ºF. Warms up well and exhibits a softer, fruitier flavor profile as it warms up to a cool room temperature.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2007 Poured from the bottle with a nice thick tan head.  Smelled strongly of smoke, however the malt really balanced out the smoke taste very well. 
The smoke flavor lingers and lingers in the finish.  This is one of my favorite beers, unfortunately the only way I can get it, is through the mail.
Exceptional. A very thick, big beer, w/ a salty smoked malt flavour giving way to a spicy bitterness (chocolate?)--superbly balanced with a subtle complexity.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2009 In the distance, a burning forest is sending over its salty smoke to your nostrilsThe bark melts to roasted embers and molassesIf you put your glass close to the tree, you can taste the light citrusy hopsBubblier and more quenching than Calumet, this is the perfect Smoked Porter to accompany your salmon gravlax...

Im glad I saved one of these... Spectacular. A very long awaited brew gotten just minutes ago at a local market. The smoked aroma is in between the very mild Rauchenfelser and the heavily smoked Schlenkerla Urbock and more on the formers side. The aroma is malt sweetish with ammonia and sweet tobacco wood smoke. The smoke and bitter blend well to lightly balance a malt sweetness over estimated because of the aroma. Best at over 55°F.  Crisp and firm. Brighter and better than the wet smoke character of the Schlenkerla but without the depth and complexity.

This refers to the 1999 version that Ive been cellaring.  Still smokey after all these years.  I think the cellaring may make the flavors blend better than when it was fresh.  Simply of North Americas great beers.
Nice opaque color with dark rich head.  Oily, with bitter chocolate and burnt fruits.  Sit back relax and let the flavors warm.
Ham in bottle. Drink it straight, or use it to make a great fondue - if you can bear to not drink it.
I tried the 1998 and 1999, and the aging mellowed the 98 a little more.  Big roasted and smoky aroma and flavor.  A very good smoked beer...now if only I had some ribs to go with it.
flavors very strong and body is very definte. Very smoky flavor and Aroma. Though I wasnt fond of it I can apprecoate the beer and recommend it to anyone that enjoys that type of beer.

Ive had the 2000, 2001 and a 1996 that someone found in a closet and all were excellent (even after five years of unknown care).  This beer has very complex flavors but does not have that greasey taste that some smoke beers will have.  And there is a recipe out there for a smoked salmon spread that is out of this world...

i was looking forward to this treat, and 2 pitchers didnt dissapoint.  starts out smooth and silky.  the finish is full of smoke that is balanced by an unsweetend chocolate taste.  I cant wait to end a day heli-skiing in valdez with this world class beer

Wonderful...my first smoked beer of any kind and I love it.
I think Ill hold a few bottles aside and try the aging process.

2000 edition. First sip is filled with roasted malts with some chocolate notes as well. The woody (not bacon or smoked cheddar or jerky) smokiness is evident but is definately more mesquite like than most smoke brews. A solid porter base with a thick body mixes with the subtle smokiness. An overall decent smoked brew. Thanks user_ex.

Ahh, the much anticipated smoked porter.  The 2000 bottling was everything that I expected.  Ever so slight smoked aroma and the perfect amount of smoked malt flavour to balance a sweetish porter.  Alaskan is one of those seldom talked about breweries that produces some remarkable beers.

I loved this beer.....great aroma, malty-roasty, smoke flavor is well balanced - very noticeable but not overwhelming. Just a great brew and I love it when it comes in 16 oz size bottles.  To bad I can only get it at X-mas time.
A very impressive beer.  Great porter foundation, and the smoke flavor doesnt try to beat you sily.  A must-try for beer geeks.
not overpoweing smoke flavor goes well with the texture of a porter, a very drinkable, great tasting brew - try it if you can find it.
Not crazy about smoked beers, but this was drinkable. Very smooth flavor with a nice nose.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2004 The beer after disemboguing from the 22-ounce brown bottle takes its rightful place in my glass an atramentous color with a mastodonic tan head that is spumous in texture and the residual lace a thick coating upon the glass. Nose dominated by the bittersweet aroma of toasted grain, sweet malt at the back, crisp and fresh to the senses, with the start sweet and thick with malt, the top full and rich in its feel to the palate. Finish is masterfully acidic, the hops authoritarian in their spiciness, very dry and long lasting after taste, to me this is one of the top 5 porters in all of Beerdom, hell it might even be number one.

This is my favorite beer. Ive even stated that fact on my Bio page at http://beer.about.com . For many, its an acquired taste but well worth the effort. In my experience, vintages more than a couple of years old tend to be oxidized. When fresh, this magnificent beer will amaze you. Dont drink it too cold!  Good beers to you.
